HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Fast-food marketers worry about contests after a rigging scandal.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
ADVERTISERS and agencies are trying to determine how the disclosure that promotional games at McDonald's restaurants were rigged during the last six years -- costing customers the chance to win more than $13 million in cash and prizes -- will affect the growing use of contests and sweepstakes to woo consumers.
 The question to which they anxiously await an answer is whether the widespread publicity generated by the arrests of eight people charged with conspiring to rig the games will cause Americans to wail the 2001 equivalent of "Say it ain't so, Joe!" That was the plaintive cry of a young fan when the baseball player Shoeless Joe Jackson was accused of conspiring to fix the 1919 World Series. 
 Promotional games have become increasingly popular as a way to draw attention to products, services, restaurants, even media. Their appeal is their ability to scratch the primal itch in almost everyone to have fun, and to get something for nothing.
According to the Promotion Marketing Association in New York, an industry trade organization, advertisers spent $1.5 billion on games in 2000, up 9 percent from 1999, and the spending in 1999, $1.38 billion, represented an increase of 15 percent from 1998. 
So nagging doubts about the honesty of such games raised by the arrests, disclosed on Wednesday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, could cripple their business-building potential. That is particularly a concern in competitive fields that have relied on promotions to stimulate sales -- like fast food, the McDonald's market.
"I don't know if there's anybody as dependent as fast food on promotions," said Peter Breen, editor at Promo magazine in Stamford, Conn., an industry trade publication owned by Primedia. " 'Crutch' is an apt term."
"They've really painted themselves into a corner," he added. "Even with this, I couldn't imagine them testing to see if they don't need promotions anymore."
The timing of the news of the fixing of the games -- including the popular annual giveaways by the McDonald's Corporation centered on Monopoly and a sweepstakes based on the ABC quiz show "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" -- is unfortunate as well. That is because marketers traditionally step up sponsorship of such promotions in uncertain or tough economic times.
Indeed, the jingle-writing and boxtop-collecting contests and sweepstakes prevalent from the 1930's through the 1950's have become legendary on Madison Avenue. They even inspired movies like Preston Sturges's "Christmas in July" (1940), in which a clerk is tricked into thinking he has won the $10,000 grand prize in a slogan-writing contest sponsored by a coffee company.
The damage done by the rigging of the contests could undermine the effectiveness of other promotions that may be produced if the economy remains sluggish.
After all, the scandal in the 50's surrounding rigged quiz shows like "21" led to the genre's exile from lucrative slots during network prime-time television schedules for four decades.
"It's not good for the industry," said a top executive at a leading promotional marketing agency, because it jeopardizes the basic premise of contests: that sponsors "make a promise." The executive spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the pending legal issues raised by the arrests.
"Consumers who have been eating Big Macs for 200 days in a row to play a game can say, 'I've been saying for years I haven't been able to win these contests, and now here's proof why,' " the executive said. "They're now going to say, 'Don't give me a game.' "
Claire Rosenzweig, the executive director of the marketing association, said she did not think the McDonald's case would undermine confidence in the games because "this is an extremely rare occurrence."
In addition, Ms. Rosenzweig said, promotional games "are heavily scrutinized and regulated, and self-regulated as well because companies have security measures in place." "I'm sure companies will take a look to see that all measures now in place are the best they can be," she added.
Executives at other fast-food marketers sought to reassure consumers. "We feel very comfortable" with security procedures, said Rob Doughty, a spokesman for the Burger King Corporation in Miami, a division of Diageo.
Besides, "we don't have games as often" as McDonald's does, he said, and when Burger King does sponsor games, they tend to focus on prizes like free menu items rather than cash or cars.
Amy Sherwood, a spokeswoman for Tricon Global Restaurants in Louisville, Ky., said her company, which operates the KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell chains, had "reviewed our own procedures, guidelines and safeguards" for games even though "we don't do many sweepstakes."
Rather, she added, "we're much more focused on food, our core products like KFC's chicken in a bucket and new products."
Bob Bertini, a spokesman for Wendy's International in Dublin, Ohio, said the McDonald's case "would not have an effect on us."
"Unlike a McDonald's, with national promotions everyone gets behind, we have two local promotions a year," he said, and franchisees and company-owned restaurants can choose whether or not they will participate.
Also, Wendy's tends to prefer "instant-win incentives" like games in which customers peel off stickers on food packages or beverage cups, he added, rather than the "collect-and-win" type of game favored by McDonald's. In the latter type of game, customers earn the prizes by collecting, for example, full sets of stamps representing groups of properties on the Monopoly board.
The suspects whose arrests were disclosed by the F.B.I. included an employee at the security department of Simon Marketing, which had been one of three companies holding lucrative contracts to handle promotional assignments for McDonald's. 
On Wednesday, McDonald's dismissed Simon Marketing, which is part of a 26-year-old company based in Los Angeles named Simon Worldwide. The companies worked together for almost two decades.
McDonald's was the largest client of Simon Worldwide, formerly known as Cyrk, accounting for 65 percent of its $768.4 million in revenue last year.
Yesterday, Philip Morris, the second-largest client of Simon Worldwide, accounting for 9 percent of its revenue, dismissed the company, Allan Brown, chief executive at Simon Worldwide, said in a statement.
Simon Worldwide was also dismissed by other clients, he added, but he did not identify them.
The company has hired a Los Angeles law firm, O'Melveny & Myers, to review how Simon Marketing administered the games for McDonald's, Mr. Brown said. "The steps we have taken to get to the bottom of this matter demonstrate that we are doing the right thing under these difficult circumstances," he said.
Already, one lawsuit has been filed against McDonald's, based in Oak Brook, Ill., and Simon Worldwide. The lawsuit, filed in Cook County Circuit Court in Chicago, seeks damages for customers it says were defrauded by the rigged games.
In newspapers on Wednesday, McDonald's ran full-page ads, labeled as "An Open Letter to McDonald's Customers," in which Jack Greenberg, the company's chairman and chief executive, wrote that "nothing is more important to us than your trust." The ad was produced by the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, which has been the lead American agency for McDonald's since 1997.
Frankel in Chicago, owned by the Publicis Groupe, is a leading candidate for landing the promotional marketing duties that Simon Marketing had handled for McDonald's. 
Frankel is the McDonald's retail merchandising agency of record, responsible for everything in stores, like displays at cash registers, menu boards and designing packaging.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The ill-fated McDonald's Monopoly game was one of many promotions used by similar companies. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Variety of Retailers Say Sales Will Remain Slow for Rest of Year 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Kmart and other retailers said yesterday that sales would remain slow for the rest of the year, reflecting consumers' increasingly cautious spending patterns.
 The Kmart Corporation, the second-largest discount chain after Wal-Mart Stores Inc., also reported a narrower fiscal second-quarter loss. The Limited Inc., Intimate Brands Inc. and Men's Wearhouse Inc. each reported sharply lower profits. 
 While they face different pressures, retailers are generally offering discounts as sales growth slows, resulting in declining profits. 
That such disparate retailers reported similar soft sales "speaks to the breadth of the slowdown," said Carl Steidtmann, director of consumer research for Deloitte Research, part of the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche. "I think this will be a weak fall and a weak Christmas."
Kmart said that sales for the quarter ended Aug. 1 fell 0.9 percent, to $8.92 billion from $9 billion in the period a year earlier. It said earlier this month that sales at stores open at least a year rose 1 percent in the quarter. The company, which is based in Troy, Mich., posted a loss of $95 million, or 19 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $448 million, or 93 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
Excluding a pretax $92 million charge to buy the 40 percent of the Internet unit BlueLight.com that it did not already own, Kmart posted a loss of $22 million, or 4 cents a share.
That matched Wall Street expectations, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
Debt the company must pay within a year rose to $116 million from $38 million, and long-term debt rose to $3 billion from $1.7 billion.
For a year, Kmart has been shifting its business to attract new customers and generate steady sales growth by focusing on food and drinks, makeup and hygiene products, the kind of things that customers repeatedly and consistently buy.
But it had said that shift would include a reduction in inventories. Instead, inventories rose to $6.9 billion from $6.6 billion in the quarter a year earlier.
"The changes have yet to bear any financial rewards," said Susan K. Jansen, an analyst at Lehman Brothers.
Regardless of its particular pressures and strategies, Kmart's results suffered from problems common to many retailers.
"We continue to reduce our reliance on advertising, and, with the lowering of prices on 20,000 items as part of our BlueLight Always program, face deflationary pricing conditions," Charles C. Conaway, the company's chairman, said in a statement.
Shares of Kmart fell $1.13, to $10.97, on the New York Stock Exchange.
At Limited, the company reported net income of $34.4 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with $77.6 million, or 17 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Those results matched Wall Street's expectations. Sales fell to $2.2 billion from $2.3 billion. Limited's stock fell $1.27, to $13.93 a share.
Intimate Brands, a Limited spinoff best known for its lingerie chain, Victoria's Secret, said its net income was $68.9 million, or 14 cents a share, compared with $99.8 million, or 20 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales for the quarter, which ended Aug. 4, fell to $1.15 billion, compared with $1.2 billion in the quarter a year earlier.
The Limited still owns 83.9 percent of Intimate Brands, and both companies are based in Columbus, Ohio. Analysts had expected Intimate Brands to earn 12 cents a share, according to First Call. Shares of Intimate Brands fell $1.22, to $13.39.
Men's Wearhouse, based in Houston, reported net income of $10.3 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $16 million, or 38 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. The results matched analysts' reduced estimates. Sales edged up 0.9 percent, to $297.2 million, from $294.5 million. Its shares fell $1.10, to $24.
"The general softness in U.S. apparel sales will likely continue through the third quarter of 2001 and possibly through the end of the year," George Zimmer, the company chairman, said in a statement.
Eliot S. Laurence, an analyst for Jefferies & Company, said the apparel retail business still had a few pockets of strength, including logo T-shirts, men's fashion denim, and fashion denim and knit tops for girls. But the broad areas of weakness, including most men's clothing and all sorts of basic items that fluctuate little with changing fashions, are not likely to improve this year, he said.
"If you have a closet full of basics already, and you're worried about your job, you're not going to squeeze a little to get a fourth turtleneck," Mr. Laurence said.

HEADLINE: Marquee Firm In California Cuts Lawyers 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
Cooley Godward, one of the San Francisco area's highest-flying law firms during the Internet boom, told employees yesterday that more than 10 percent of the firm's lawyers would be laid off.
 The cutback -- affecting 85 of the 645 lawyers as well as 50 paralegals and other members of the support staff -- was one of the first publicly acknowledged and economically driven staff reductions at a big law firm in about a decade. It is also the latest and perhaps the most prominent sign that law firms are vulnerable to the economic slowdown. 
 In an memorandum distributed yesterday, Stephen C. Neal, Cooley Godward's chairman and chief executive, said that "with no foreseeable resurgence in the economy, we are making personnel reductions" throughout the firm. 
Poignantly, the announcement comes just weeks after Vault Inc., which runs a Web site that allows employees to post messages about their workplace, ranked Cooley as the best firm in the country for lawyers and their staffs to work.
"When the downturn hit, it left us with too many" lawyers, Mr. Neal said in a telephone interview. "In response to what was in retrospect a huge spike in demand for our services in 1999 and 2000, we hired and built up capacity."
But the buildup was in anticipation of a continued business boom, he continued, and because that business has failed to materialize, Cooley has too many lawyers and too little work.
"It's easy to say in hindsight that we should have known," Mr. Neal said. "But nobody in the world knew."
He said that morale was a factor in the decision, because associates with no work would not develop in their careers and were unlikely to stay at the firm.
Mr. Neal said that no partners were let go and that members of the firm decided not to cut salaries to retain people.
Cooley Godward will still take on about 85 law school graduates this fall. Their starting salaries will be $125,000 a year.
According to The American Lawyer, an industry magazine, Cooley's profit per partner -- a critical measure of a firm's success -- came to about $905,000 last year.
Layoffs at law firms are not new, and under these economic circumstances are not surprising, said Jim Cotterman, a principal at Altman Weil, a consultant to law firms.
"We've seen this before," Mr. Cotterman said, "and the results that we're seeing now shouldn't be surprising, given that we know what happened the last time there was a slowdown after a period of intense activity."
In the late 1980's, he said, firms raised salaries as the economy grew, just as they did recently. But then in the early 90's, many firms let people go -- and had a tough time both luring law school graduates and, when the economy recovered, enough experienced lawyers.
"They spent the better part of the last decade," he said, "working out of the increases in associate compensation that they had going into the decade. Now we're back where we started from."
News of the layoffs spread quickly yesterday as associates in Palo Alto, where the firm is based, sent copies of the memorandum by e-mail to friends throughout the country. Associates elsewhere reacted with a mixture of relief that they were not similarly affected and fear that their jobs might yet be at risk. 
"It's totally scary," said an associate at a big New York firm who insisted on not being identified. One reason to go to a big firm, the associate said, is stability: most young lawyers think that law firms will be immune to the condition of the economy because they will be cushioned by bankruptcy-related work in slow times and buoyed by corporate transactions during booms.
Another associate at an East Coast firm said, "It makes me feel like my bonus is going to be low." On the other hand, he said, he felt "relatively secure" because the San Francisco Bay Area firms were overly dependent on the technology industries.
At least Cooley openly stated that the layoffs were related to the decline in the economy, said Sheri Michaels, vice president for recruitment at Mestel & Company, a search firm serving law practices. Some firms have laid off associates in recent months but insisted that only poor performers have been affected, Ms. Michaels said.
"Which one is telling it straight?" she asked rhetorically. "I'd rather have Cooley. At least you know what the facts are."
Ms. Michaels said that the layoffs would probably affect Cooley's recruiting at law schools in the short term, but that the impact in future years was difficult to predict. "Their business has been tied to one particular industry," she said. "If that market comes back, the layoffs won't hurt them."

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Rise as Unemployment Benefits Surge 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
The number of workers filing new claims for jobless benefits rose last week and an increase in those continuing to receive payments suggests that the laid-off employees are having trouble finding work.
 "So few new jobs are being created that nearly all of the newly laid-off are finding themselves unemployed," said Steven A. Wood, chief economist at Financial Oxygen Inc. in Walnut Creek, Calif. "These data suggest that payroll employment is likely to be negative for August." 
 In a separate report, a survey of economists by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia forecasts slower growth and higher unemployment this year and next than expected.
Initial jobless claims rose 8,000, to 393,000, in the week that ended Saturday from a revised 385,000 the previous week, the Labor Department said. The four-week moving average of claims, which smooths out volatility in the weekly numbers, rose to 378,750 from 372,000.
The number of people collecting unemployment benefits surged to 3.18 million during the week ended Aug. 11 from 3.05 million the week before. That is the highest since 3.21 million in September 1992.
The report showed some signs that the pace of payroll trimming might be starting to ease. Last week was the fifth in a row that first-time claims stayed below 400,000. Filings had begun exceeding that level in mid-April.
"That claims are still far below 400,000 is quite compelling," said Lara Rhame, an economist at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company in New York. "The economy is so far able to manage this slowdown."
The number of workers continuing to receive benefits, while at a nine-year high, represents a smaller percentage of the work force than it did then. In 1992, when the country was pulling out of the last recession, there were 129 million workers. The civilian labor force has expanded to 142 million this year.
The Philadelphia Fed report showed that economists expected the unemployment rate to average 4.6 percent this year, higher than the previous projection of 4.5 percent. The monthly rate has been either 4.5 percent or 4.4 percent since April. The rate will climb to 4.9 percent next year, the economists say.
The economy probably will have expanded 1.7 percent this year, down from a forecast of 2 percent in May, the survey found. The expected 2.6 percent growth rate for 2002 is down from 2.8 percent in the last survey.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
SHARES OF AIRTRAN FALL 17 PERCENT AFTER PROFIT WARNING

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Shares of AirTran Holdings fell 17 percent yesterday after the company issued a profit warning. 
AirTran, a low-fare carrier based in Orlando, Fla., said it was feeling pinched by the economic downturn, price competition and discounting. In June, Delta Air Lines introduced competitive business fares at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport, where AirTran Airways has 151 daily departures. AirTran flies on the East Coast to 34 cities. The company said its third-quarter profits would range from 2 to 6 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had forecast 5 to 20 cents a share. Shares of AirTran fell $1.22, to $5.96.

HEADLINE: The Incredible Shrinking Surplus 

 BODY:
The surplus seems to have vanished while Washington is on vacation.
 The relentlessly optimistic Bush administration, which released its latest budget projections this week, had to struggle mightily to produce even a tiny nub of a surplus -- $1 billion this year outside of Social Security, based on overoptimistic forecasts and convenient omissions. The Congressional numbers due next Tuesday are likely to be even less heartening. Except for the money in the Social Security trust fund, which both parties have vowed to use for debt reduction, the cushy surpluses of last spring have melted away in the heat of the summer. 
 All this happened in a political vacuum, with Congress off on recess and President Bush himself vacationing in what is now ordained as the Western White House. But the administration is doing no one a favor by pretending that the situation can be solved by a little restraint on the part of House and Senate appropriations committees. In the real world, there is no way Mr. Bush can protect the Social Security trust fund surplus and his recent tax cut program. The sooner Congress is forced to face reality, the better.
The administration still insists that over the next few years it will take in a few billion dollars more than it spends, while saving the Social Security surplus -- but not the Medicare surplus -- for debt reduction. After a few years of close calls, the administration says, the surplus outside of Social Security will begin to blossom again, growing to $575 billion over the next 10 years.
To maintain faith in the surpluses of the future, President Bush is making some far-fetched assumptions. The White House assumes that, adjusted for inflation, the economy will grow by 3.2 percent in 2002. Popular private forecasters beg to differ. The survey of 33 analysts by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia comes in at 2.6 percent; The Economist's survey of 16 major investment banks and consultants averages 2.7 percent; and the Blue Chip Economic Indicators consensus of 53 sources says 2.8 percent.
In addition, the updated budget implicitly assumes that Congress is not going to do anything about the alternative minimum tax. If the targeting of the tax is not fixed by 2004, up to 35 million taxpayers, many from the middle class, will be subject to this onerous levy by the end of the decade. The chances are minimal that legislators will allow their constituents to be hit by something they will certainly perceive as a big tax increase. 
Money to renew investment tax credits and finance additional defense spending, both of which the administration supports, is also left out of the budget. These three initiatives alone could eat up the entire surplus outside Social Security and cast the rest of the government into the red. Washington has a tradition of ignoring policies in the "expected but not budgeted" category, but never to this extent.
Mr. Bush has been telling the nation that the only thing it has to fear is a spendthrift Congress. Both parties have expensive items on their agendas -- a prescription drug program for the elderly, heavy spending on aid to agriculture and the inevitable highway construction programs. It is unrealistic to believe that the president, who seems unwilling to drop any of his own big-ticket priorities, like the missile shield, is going to be able to persuade members of Congress to give up theirs.
Despite what the administration wants the public to believe, surplus funds collected by Medicare and Social Security will almost certainly be tapped to pay for the president's tax cut and general spending for the foreseeable future. If this money were instead used to pay down more of the government's debt, it would lower the cost of borrowing to pay the retirement benefits already promised to today's workers. The only other way to supply these benefits would be through higher taxes. The budget needs more breathing room, but the White House's huge tax cut threatens to smother it.

HEADLINE: RUMSFELD INSISTS BUSH WON'T PARE SPENDING REQUEST 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
Responding to calls on Capitol Hill for paring back the administration's Pentagon budget request, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that President Bush would insist that Congress approve all of his proposed $18.4 billion increase in military spending for the coming year.
 "We need every nickel of that," Mr. Rumsfeld said at a Pentagon news conference. "The president has indicated that defense is a top priority for him, and he intends to be assisting to see that the full $18.4 billion tab that is up there is passed." 
 Shrinking federal budget surpluses prompted two powerful Democrats, Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, and Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, to announce this week that they would not support Mr. Bush's request to add $18.4 billion to his original Pentagon spending plan for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1.
Each senator asserted that paying for the full Pentagon increase would mean dipping into surplus Medicare and possibly Social Security money, which most lawmakers in both parties have declared off limits. 
"He's not proposed any way to pay for it," Mr. Conrad said on Wednesday of the requested increase. "That means the money will come right out of the trust funds for Medicare and Social Security if his proposal were to be adopted."
The dueling remarks set the stage for a battle next month over the shape and size of the proposed $329 billion Pentagon budget. Many Democrats are already using the dwindling surplus to advocate cutting the administration's requested $8.3 billion budget for missile defense.
But it is not just Senate Democrats who are objecting to the size of the Pentagon budget. A number of senior Republicans in the House have also expressed concerns about how to balance military spending against competing demands for money for education and health care.
Representative Jim Nussle, an Iowa Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said he was troubled at having to support a major increase for the armed services when the Pentagon has yet to complete a review of its long-term needs. That review is not due to reach Congress until late September. 
Mr. Nussle said Mr. Rumsfeld was asking Congress to pass a budget based on "guestimates." He added: "That's unacceptable if they are planning on getting more. We're not just going to throw money at defense again."
Echoing an argument made by defense secretaries through the decades, Mr. Rumsfeld asserted today that security was a national imperative and not just another discretionary spending program. 
"The defense is a priority that's distinctive, and the president has indicated that," he said.
On Monday, Mr. Bush told a veterans' group, "Let us have responsible spending from Day 1 and put the national security and education of our children first in line when it comes to the appropriations process."
But Mr. Nussle argued that military spending should not be held sacrosanct. "The defense request is no different from a number of other requests out there," he said. "As we've reminded President Clinton, we will cheerfully remind President Bush that we hold the purse strings."
Mr. Bush's original budget proposal called for increasing the Pentagon budget to $310 billion, up from $296 billion in 2001. The president later asked for an additional increase of $18.4 billion.
But a provision of the budget resolution says that the budget committee chairmen in both houses cannot approve military spending increases that use surplus Medicare money. 
New projections released by the White House on Wednesday showed that Mr. Bush's tax cut and the economic slowdown had whittled the surplus outside Social Security system to virtually zero. That means that the government will spend nearly all of the surplus generated by part of the Medicare system. 
"The president's tax cut is so big that it stops additional money going for any of the president's priorities, including defense, education and prescription drugs," said Thomas S. Kahn, Democratic staff director of the House Budget panel. "He's basically created a fiscal straitjacket."
Gordon Adams, director of security policy studies at the Elliot School of International Affairs at George Washington University, said the new surplus projections would leave less money for the 2003 Pentagon budget, when the administration had hoped to place its stamp on major weapons programs. "The cruel dilemma for the Pentagon is not 2002, but 2003 through 2009," Mr. Adams said.
Mr. Conrad's opposition will complicate the administration's ability to win approval for the $18.4 billion increase. But the White House can also seek to delay, cut or restructure other programs to free money for the military.
One likely target for the Democrats will be proposed spending for missile defense, which Mr. Bush wants to increase by $3 billion. Democrats on the House Armed Services Committee recently tried unsuccessfully to shift $1 billion from missile defense to conventional military programs. Senator Byrd suggested he might try something similar. 
"We don't have to keep campaign promises that we don't make, and ought to be very careful about launching into the unknown with a missile defense system that hasn't been tested," Senator Byrd said.
Despite the Democratic pledges to cut the military increase, Mr. Rumsfeld said he expected to prevail. 
"The need is so serious and so real, and the president's commitment is clear," he said. "I've generally found that there are always some people who are against defense spending at any level. And yet when the votes tend to be done, they seem to find a majority to support a strong national defense. And I suspect that that will be the case this time."

HEADLINE: Levy Says $200 Million May Have to Be Cut a Week Before School Opens 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The budget brinksmanship between the Board of Education and City Hall reached a new peak yesterday as Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy warned that he might announce budget cuts of up to $200 million next week, just a week before students return to school.
 Mr. Levy's warning prompted City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone to lobby Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for the release of additional financing for classroom programs. Mr. Vallone said that the money had been promised if Mr. Levy made substantial administrative cuts this summer and that he believed that the restructuring plan outlined by Mr. Levy last week met that requirement. 
 It was not clear that Mr. Vallone's efforts to broker an agreement were successful. Mr. Vallone portrayed the mayor as moving closer to agreeing to provide more money and said he expected Mr. Levy to present a list today of classroom programs that would get the new money.
But the mayor's office insisted that the only agreement reached yesterday was to review a list if Mr. Levy submitted one and warned that it would review any administrative cuts skeptically. 
In addition, the mayor's office raised conditions that have not been heard in the last several rounds of the budget fight. Anthony P. Coles, a deputy mayor for education, said the mayor hoped that Mr. Levy's plans for additional classroom programs would include the private management of some low-performing schools, an idea that was voted down at five schools in the spring, and the trial use of vouchers in at least one district, which would send children to private schools with public money. .
Mr. Vallone commended parts of Mr. Levy's restructuring plan, particularly the $40 million a year Mr. Levy said would be saved by changing the board's procurement systems. Mr. Vallone added that he has been waiting for more than two months for Mr. Levy to list the classroom programs that would be financed with the money saved by the restructuring.
Mr. Levy has been warning for most of the year that the board faced a budget shortfall if large parts of the budgets outlined by the mayor and Gov. George E. Pataki were adopted. Mr. Levy has said the board's $11.5 billion budget left it $120 million short in city money and $170 million short in state money.
Even after the $100 million in annual administrative cuts outlined by Mr. Levy last week, the board is still $190 million short, the chancellor said. That is the money Mr. Levy says will be required to continue the programs it had last year. 
Although the board's budget increased by nearly $200 million in the fiscal year that began July 1, Mr. Levy says that required cost increases and the effect of inflation mean that the board's spending power is significantly less than it was last year. A cut of $200 million in the board's budget would be equivalent to less than 2 percent of its financing.
Mr. Giuliani scoffed yesterday at the notion that the board could not find that amount of savings. But Mr. Levy said that after his administrative cuts, the only places left to turn were after-school, sports and arts programs; professional development; and weekend programs for academic enrichment.
Mr. Levy said it might not be possible to avoid cutting classroom programs to close the budget gap.
"Classes begin the first week of September," Mr. Levy said in an interview. "It's already late to be planning a budget for a system this large. Next week is the last possible moment to give superintendents guidance on their budgets without causing them untoward disruption."

HEADLINE: Giuliani's Budget 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Charles R. Morris (Op-Ed, Aug. 17) applauds Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's resistance to repeating the "lavish spending" of the years under Mayor Edward I. Koch. The common perception that Mr. 
Giuliani has reined in spending results from misleading city budget reporting practices that omit increased spending on debt service and do not adjust for the transfer of one year's surplus to the next. 
 Accurately reported, New York City spending grew 6 percent a year from fiscal year 1997 to 2001, while inflation averaged 2.3 percent. In a comparable period (1985 to 1989) under Mr. Koch, spending grew 6.7 percent a year while inflation averaged 4.5 percent.
New Yorkers should not believe that the recent growth in the number of police officers and teachers was accomplished with budget restraint.

MARCIA VAN WAGNER
New York, Aug. 17, 2001

The writer is deputy research director and chief economist, Citizens Budget Commission.

HEADLINE: Selling a New Armed Forces 

BYLINE:  By John Hillen; John Hillen is chief operating officer of Island ECN, an electronic trading network in New York. He was a defense adviser to the Bush campaign and is co-author of "Future Visions for U.S. Defense Policy."

 BODY:
Since the Vietnam War, the American defense debate could be characterized as Republicans wanting more of the same (tanks, ships and planes) and Democrats wanting less. There were some important differences between the parties over questions of intervention and strategy, peacekeeping and war fighting, but when it came to military programs and hardware, the political divide was simply a matter of scale.
 George W. Bush, when he was still Texas governor, tried to change all that in a September 1999 speech, calling for a revolution at the Pentagon. It was a speech that said, quite simply, we don't need more or less of the same defense, we need a very different defense. 
 But now George W. Bush's plan to transform the military is coming back to haunt the Pentagon and, in particular, Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld. As a candidate, Mr. Bush proposed the biggest changes in our military forces since the 1930's -- strategic and bureaucratic initiatives meant to move the Pentagon away from an industrial-age outgrowth of our World War II and cold war forces (those magnificent tanks, ships and planes) and toward a leaner, longer-range and more precise force intended to deter and combat the threats of the future.
This transformed military would use advances in computing and information technology to pack more punch than today's forces do, but in very different form. Large and slow-moving aircraft carriers would give way to submarines and other stealthier ships that would deliver much more than a carrier's worth of precision-guided munitions. F-22 aircraft meant for dogfights would give way to long-range bombers and to unmanned aircraft not limited by a human being in the cockpit. Large and cumbersome Army divisions full of tanks and artillery would give way to smaller, lighter, more lethal and more agile formations. All this force would be stitched together by real-time, space-based information systems and applied in new ways.
The military knows this change is coming. Its own planning documents and "vision statements" all refer explicitly to these changes in warfare. But putting the vision into action means short-term pain and wrenching change, neither of which the Pentagon handles well. Moreover, the Congressional Budget Office estimates that even with dramatically increased defense spending the Pentagon will, over the next decade, still be unable to afford sustaining and improving the cold war force.
Now Mr. Rumsfeld is backed into a corner; the political (and economic) bill for trying to bring this agenda to fruition has come due. If Mr. Rumsfeld legitimizes the Pentagon's status quo responses -- more tanks, ships and planes, slightly improved -- to his proposals, he undermines Mr. Bush and keeps the Pentagon in a spiral of steadily deteriorating readiness, rapidly rising equipment replacement costs and increasing strategic irrelevance. If he pushes the president's agenda forward, he faces the iron triangle of Congress, the uniformed chiefs of the armed services, and the defense industry (which, to little notice, roundly criticized Mr. Bush's defense platform during the campaign).
Judging from his recent remarks on the very small percentage of the military that he would change, Mr. Rumsfeld has decided to move slowly. To those who doubt that one can have a revolution in slow motion -- with cautious bureaucrats managing the change -- it looks as if he's throwing in the towel.
But the Pentagon can still be transformed along the lines President Bush laid out in his campaign. Like any radical shift in a big institution, this change would have to be accomplished with a mixture of cunning, compromise and ruthlessness.
The first step would be to fire some generals and admirals. No group in Washington resists change more effectively than the uniformed services, which control more than 85 percent of the Pentagon's budget with little effective civilian oversight. So far, Mr. Rumsfeld has seemed to expect the military leaders who grew up in the old system to be his agents of change. That would not happen in any organization, and certainly not in the military.
Mr. Rumsfeld needs to reach down into the ranks and bring up leaders who can help make the transformation. In his first year as chief of staff, George C. Marshall retired 55 generals and over 400 colonels from the Army as he attempted to remake the force just before World War II. Marshall knew he had to change the Army of World War I to one that could take on Hitler's military innovations, and he knew he couldn't do it with leaders who grew up in the horse cavalry.
Mr. Rumsfeld should also work hard to encourage experimentation, not only with new weapons but also with new war-fighting concepts and new forms of organization. The military has been bemoaning its risk-averse culture for a decade but has done nothing to correct it. Few officers will take unusual assignments or publish controversial ideas. There is a bland corporateness about military culture these days, and no one will risk failure. Yet our military history shows that experimentation -- despite the unavoidable failures that will occur -- leads to dramatic change and success. Mr. Rumsfeld should thrust some mavericks into the limelight.
The old saw is that the military prepares to fight the last war. Under current doctrine, the United States is prepared to fight two: the Korean War and Desert Storm. Almost all of the Pentagon's energies are directed at refighting those wars in basically the same way with the same (if updated) systems. While there is no doubt that America should retain the capability to triumph in such conflicts, it should not shoehorn its efforts into outdated war plans. The pressing military need of the next 25 years will be to get to the future of warfare before the other guy.
Mr. Rumsfeld's biggest mistake so far has been to let others emphasize the costs of losing the cold war force before he articulated the security benefits and other advantages of military reform. For both the defense industry and Congress, he should demonstrate the likely industrial and technological byproducts from creating new kinds of forces and weapons systems. In the era of the cold war military, for example, research for defense purposes developed the use of satellites for communication and created the Internet. Why did the Pentagon start with the bad news?
Finally, Mr. Rumsfeld needs solid White House support. He cannot operate in isolation from politics. After all, we don't have a military for its own sake -- it is simply the means to ensure American security. President Bush needs to lay out a national security plan that describes what we hope to accomplish in the world, against what obstacles, in concert with which friends -- and with what kind of military. And because this military transformation will happen over a 20-year period, the president will need to stretch his vision out to encompass a few decades. Only then will the transformation of the armed forces make practical and political sense.

HEADLINE: Now That the Money Is Gone . . . 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Bush Projections Show Sharp Drop in Budget Surplus" (front page, Aug. 23): 
 President Bush's supporters should see from a graph accompanying your article that the drop in the projected federal budget surplus from $810 billion to $484 billion in 2011 because of the tax cut shows that the tax cut was an economic disaster for all of us. 
Even those of us who are not economists see the fallacy of squandering an inheritance (the budget surplus and a positive state of mind among investors that could have produced long-term stability) for short-term political gain through pie-in-the-sky election propaganda about boosting the economy through tax refunds.
Let's hope that enough American consumers and investors can keep the country afloat until more responsible leaders come to power and return common sense to public office.

EDMUND A. BATOR
Atlanta, Aug. 23, 2001

HEADLINE: Back-to-School Retailer Blues; 
Consumers Now Seem to Be in Belt-Tightening Mode

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Families have been out in force these days at the Briarwood shopping mall in Ann Arbor, Mich. Last week, swarms of young girls and pre-adolescents surrounded the displays of trendy clothes and accessories. But many parents were carefully searching out sales and other bargains.
 Jo Ellin Gutterman, shopping with her daughters, Noa, 9, and Zoe, 13, said the economic slowdown had convinced her to do some things she did not bother with when the economy was in better shape. 
 "We are actually using coupons arriving in the mail," she said. And the family is taking advantage of online promotions: they go to a Gap store, try on clothes they like, and then order them over the Internet, where they are often cheaper. 
Many retailers are bracing themselves for one of the rockier shopping seasons in years as parents and children, teenagers and college students head into stores this month looking for sneakers and shirts, electronic organizers and wide-ruled paper -- all in preparation to go back to school. And industry experts say there is no immediate upturn in sight.
In recent years, many people have stopped buying every sweater and sock they would need for the year in one fell swoop, in favor of buying gradually over several months.
But August still occupies a special place on the retail calendar as the time when stores unveil their fall merchandise and find out whether they have hits on their hands, or merely stacks of stuff that will have to be marked down before anyone will buy it.
This year, though, with a soft economy, the burst dot-com bubble and job cutbacks either announced or feared at many companies, retail experts are anticipating slower sales gains -- except in stores known for deep discounts. And even there, consumers are showing an unusual degree of caution, buying carefully and hunting for sales.
July same-store sales figures fell for most department stores and specialty stores, with single-digit sales growth going to discount stores like Wal-Mart; Costco; T.J. Maxx, a unit of TJX; and Payless ShoeSource.
The federal tax rebates being issued this summer were supposed to inspire people to spend more. But one expert says the effect of the rebates has been minimal at best.
"From what I've seen, back-to- school looks like it is off to a slow start," said Burt Flickinger 3rd, a consultant with Reach Marketing in Westport, Conn. "It looks like consumers are cutting back, trying to use last year's backpacks. In notebooks and other items, they are really shopping the specials much more so than in other years."
Michael P. Niemira, an economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, said the rebate was starting to have some effect on retailers. He predicts that this fall's sales will not be any worse than last year, although there will probably be more promotions to draw customers into stores. But he said there are some indications that consumers may hold off on spending the bulk of the tax rebate for now and wait until the holidays get closer.
Even teenagers, who once headed straight for specialty chains like Abercrombie & Fitch, Pacific Sunwear of California and Gap, appear to be cutting back and shopping a little more in discount stores, according to a back-to-school survey conducted earlier this month by American Express. This year, 39 percent of teenagers described themselves as bargain hunters, compared with 32 percent a year earlier. And they report that they are spending $23 less, on average, than last year.
Some stores, worried about anemic back-to-school shopping this year, are changing how they manage inventory levels. Many have cut back their orders to avoid having too much merchandise on their hands. And experts expect no change in the situation until next year.
"A lot of the retailers are looking through their brands now, trying to understand the cash-flow cycles for each one," said Darrell Rigby, a retail consultant with Bain & Company in Boston. "They are getting very sophisticated about the economics of the products that they move. The ones that aren't moving, or end up needing huge markdowns in order to move them, will be the first to go."
The weak economy is the main source of worry for retailers. But they are also troubled by lackluster products in many areas, including apparel, toys and entertainment, experts said. Customers of the Gap said they wanted more fashion, so the company complied. But sales still went down.
Wal-Mart has found some success in apparel with products like the clothing line linked to Mary Kate and Ashley, the Olsen twins of television and movie fame. But in general, the retail industry is suffering from a lack of hot products, said Seth M. Siegel, co-chairman of the Beanstalk Group, which licenses various entertainment and corporate properties to retailers. The group licensed Mary Kate and Ashley to Wal-Mart.
Fashion trends seem cautious, said John D. Morris, an analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison. "For a while, the designer was dictating to the consumer," he said. "Now we're coming out of that. Teens and college students are saying they want simplicity, they want honesty. They want to take a break from the technology revolution, and everything that's been forced on them."
The biggest style trend for the fall is denim, hardly a revolutionary concept. Denim is appearing in different washes, including potassium, which creates a bright sheen, and with embellishments like painting and embroidery. 
As for toys, "there is no entertainment property like the Ninja Turtles or the Power Rangers," Mr. Siegel said, "and no Tamagotchi or Furby or actual toy property that makes a person want to go to the store today."
Hopes are high for the movie version of "Harry Potter," expected in theaters in November, but toys and other tie-ins to the movie are not expected to sell especially well, Mr. Flickinger said. "The second half of the year and Christmas will be one of the softest in years," he predicted. The fourth quarter of the year generally accounts for roughly two-thirds of all toy sales.
No clear winner has emerged at the movies, either, Mr. Flickinger added. And toy makers have been reluctant to license products tied to coming movies because they have been disappointed by low demand for products like "Star Wars" toys, which failed to generate big sales after the prequel to the initial Star Wars trilogy came out last year.
Some stores are trying to create a big trend. At Target, a discounter known for quirky and stylish products, executives have developed a line of products inspired by SpongeBob SquarePants, the Nickelodeon cartoon series centered around the underwater antics of an anthropomorphic sea sponge. The products, meant to appeal to the teenagers and 20-year-olds who have turned out to be fans of the show, include pajamas, T-shirts and stuffed versions of SpongeBob, the main character.
"They are certainly interested in bringing the teen audience into the store," said Cyma Zarghami, executive vice president and general manager for Nickelodeon. "Bringing in properties that have a cool factor to them helps drive that younger demographic."
Sally Mueller, senior marketing manager for Target, said that the SpongeBob line, which will be exclusive to Target among the discount stores until next spring, is expected to draw in younger boys and girls as well.
Some stores hope to entice consumers with new ways of shopping, like buying online and then picking up the products in nearby stores. Sears, Roebuck, whose sales at stores open at least a year fell 3 percent in July, is reorganizing its Sears.com Web site to accommodate shoppers who said they liked ordering from their computers, but disliked the hefty shipping charges.
Under the new system, they will be able to research and order items, ranging from washing machines and exercise equipment to baby blankets and power tools, and either pick them up in a Sears store or arrange for home delivery, said Dennis Honan, vice president and general manager for Sears Online.
But whether these enticements will draw many consumers to spend at a more robust pace remains a point of debate. While consumer spending has continued to grow, providing the main bulwark for the ailing economy, it has definitely softened. And Mr. Rigby, the Bain consultant, does not think consumer demand will pick up broadly until next year.
But "when, I really don't know," he added. "So much of it depends on whether consumers continue their spending patterns. If they do, it could be early in the year. If they get frightened by all of the layoffs, it could slip later in the year."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
AustralianEconomy Shows Its Resiliency

BYLINE:  By BECKY GAYLORD 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 24 

 BODY:
While most industrial countries are slowing down or worrying about a slowdown, Australia is surprisingly buoyant, the latest economic statistics show. Analysts say the economy here will go on outperforming that of its trading partners for the rest of the year at least.
 Almost every sector is looking up. Home building is on the rise; consumer spending is strong; corporate profitability is improving. Exports are booming, making the trade deficit narrower than it has been in decades. 
 When Australia's economy contracted in the fourth quarter of 2000, its first down quarter in a decade, it proved to be a pause, not a downturn. The causes were mainly domestic, and fleeting, most notably a broad revamping of the country's tax system, including introduction of a general sales tax, which briefly depressed consumer confidence.
But this year, all systems have been go. The economy grew 1.1 percent in the first quarter of 2001 even though businesses were running down inventory in warehouses and store shelves, and economists expect second-quarter figures, due in mid-September, to be strong as well.
Australia's treasurer, Peter Costello, noted in a radio interview this week that Australia's economy had slackened from the buoyant conditions of the late 1990's. "But we're still growing, and we're growing faster than the United States and faster than Japan and faster than Europe," he said.
Two factors straight out of a macroeconomics textbook seem to have done the trick: A timely application of fiscal and monetary stimulus, and the good fortune to have a weak currency at a useful moment. Together they have "firewalled" Australia, insulating it to an extent from slumps in demand elsewhere, said Glenn Maguire, chief economist at Societe Generale's Australian unit.
The effects of interest rate cuts and election-year spending by the government of Prime Minister John Howard are easy to see in the construction industry, among the most vibrant here. Government grants for first-time home buyers helped produce a 30 percent surge in approvals for new homes in May and June. The Australian central bank expects other categories of construction to accelerate, too.
More broadly, consumer confidence has recovered from the dip last year and a new report by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development found generally strong balance sheets and profitability in corporate Australia, especially among exporters, whose products gain a big edge from the low exchange rate. While the Australian dollar has rallied in recent weeks, trading at 53.46 United States cents today, it is down from a high of 59.27 United States cents a year ago. 
Economists say Australia is humming along now in part because its experience of the 1990's boom years was more subdued than in the United States, and did not produce any major imbalances that needed correcting. Neither business investment nor the stock market ran wild. "We didn't get to the same heady highs in the tech boom, so we didn't have to go to the depths" on the way down, said Craig James, chief economist at Commonwealth Securities.
To be sure, there are pockets of trouble, notably from offshore. And the cost advantage of a cheap currency will not be enough to sustain exporters if global economic growth turns really sluggish; miners and manufacturers will suffer if global demand contracts sharply. The main threats to Australia's growth prospects now come from abroad, the central bank reported. 
On the other hand, if global growth picks up as some forecasters hope, the conditions that are now sheltering Australia from the global slowdown could instead cause the economy to overheat, igniting inflation. For the moment, though, the danger seems remote. Those factors, Mr. James said of the stimulants, "are shoring us up, rather than pushing us into overdrive."

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Rose in July, CushioningIndustrial Slump 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 

 BODY:
Americans bought new homes at the fastest pace in four months in July, helping ease the damage to the economy from slumping orders for factory goods, the government said today.
 The Commerce Department reported a 4.9 percent rise in sales, to 950,000 houses at an annual pace, the most since March. The increase was the second consecutive one and surprised analysts, who had expected sales to drop. 
 A decrease of 0.6 percent in new orders for durable goods, also reported by the Commerce Department, came as no surprise. Still, the 2.6 percent drop the previous month was larger than expected and the level of orders excluding the volatile transportation category was the lowest since January 1997.
"Demand for housing products remains very strong," said Pete Correll, chief executive of the Georgia-Pacific Group, the second-biggest maker of forest products like paper, packaging, lumber and plywood. At the same time, "some of our businesses are the worst I've seen in 30 years."
Analysts expected new-home sales to fall 0.3 percent, to 919,000 houses at an annual rate, from June's previously reported pace of 922,000. New homes account for about 15 percent of all houses sold.
The median price of a new home fell to $168,300 from $172,400 the previous month.
A decline in borrowing costs has underpinned demand. The average rate on a 30-year mortgage dropped to 6.91 percent this week, the lowest in almost five months, according to Freddie Mac, the No. 2 buyer of mortgages in the United States.
As for factory orders, decreased spending on computers and semiconductors held them down in July.
Excluding motor vehicles and other transportation equipment, orders fell 1.4 percent in July after decreasing 2.1 percent in June. July orders other than for transportation equipment were valued at $129 billion, the lowest level since January 1997.
The July level of orders for all durable goods, at $182 billion, is the lowest since July 1998.
Orders for chips fell 26 percent in July and were down 56 percent from a year earlier. Orders for computers and related products fell 4.1 percent last month after falling 4.9 percent in June and were down 28 percent from July 2000.
Factory orders for transportation equipment rose 1.3 percent in July after falling 3.8 percent the previous month.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Stocks Surge After Cisco Says Business Is Stabilizing

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks soared yesterday with technology issues leading the way after the computer networking giant Cisco Systems said it saw signs that its business was stabilizing.
 Investors were also encouraged by a government report that said sales of new homes rose more than expected in July. 
 That sentiment contrasted to Wall Street's glum reaction on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates for the seventh time this year and reiterated the possibility of continued economic weakness. Stocks fell sharply that day but regained their footing the following day and ended the week modestly higher. 
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index climbed 73.83 points, or 4 percent, to close at 1,916.80 yesterday. For the week, it gained 2.7 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 194.02 points, or 1.9 percent, to 10,423.17, bringing its gains for the week to 1.8 percent.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 22.84 points, or 2 percent, to 1,184.93, bringing its gains for the week to nearly 2 percent.
Each of the three major gauges reached its highest level since July 12, the day Microsoft said its second-quarter revenue slightly exceeded analysts' estimates.
The rally in technology issues was touched off in part by Cisco, which jumped $1.49, to $18.25, after it said on Thursday that it was reorganizing into 11 technology groups -- its biggest makeover since 1997 -- to streamline and focus its marketing and engineering operations.
John T. Chambers, the chief executive of Cisco, also said that the company was on track to meet its projections for revenue in the first quarter.
"This was like manna from heaven for all of the tech companies," said Alfred E. Goldman, the chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards & Sons. "For them to say they're stabilizing their business, that was a big positive. It is the queen bee in the Internet sector."
Other telecommunications-networking stocks rose along with Cisco. Juniper Networks jumped $1.08, to $17.28; Alcatel picked up $1.45, to $17.50; Lucent Technologies gained 37 cents, to $7.02; and Nortel Networks rose 42 cents, to $7.07. 
The American Stock Exchange's networking stock index surged 17.43 points, or 6 percent, to 308.10.
JDS Uniphase, which makes fiber optic telecommunications equipment, climbed 64 cents, to $7.66.
As it has done for much of the week -- after an industry association said orders for chip-making equipment were stronger in July than Wall Street expected -- the semiconductor sector continued to show signs of strength. Linear Technology rose $2.82, to $42.43; Advanced Micro Devices gained 70 cents, to $15; Intel climbed $1.41, to $29.08; and Altera advanced $1.48, to $29.61. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor stock index rose 34.54 points, or 6.2 percent, to close at 594.91. 
Microsoft advanced $2.93, to $62.05, after the company announced that it had completed development of its Windows XP operating system, which is scheduled to go on sale on Oct. 25. In addition, a federal judge was assigned to decide the penalty Microsoft should face for violating antitrust laws. 
Other software makers gained as well. Veritas Software rose $4.17, to $35.49; PeopleSoft advanced $1.95, to $37.15; and Novell gained 44 cents, to $4.74.
I.B.M. led the Dow industrials higher, climbing $3.99, to $106.99.
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing rose $2.26, to $110.61, and Home Depot gained $1.95, to $49.94. Boeing increased $1.46, to $53.63; Alcoa climbed $1.22, to $39.25; and Citigroup jumped $1.51, to $48.30. 
The Commerce Department provided investors with some unexpected good news about the economy, reporting that sales of new single-family homes rose 4.9 percent, to an annual rate of 950,000 in July.
Economists had expected new-home sales to fall 0.3 percent, to 919,000. July's increase was the fastest pace of growth since March 2000 and the biggest one-month jump since December 2000.
Orders for durable goods in July, meanwhile, met analysts' expectations. Orders for the goods -- relatively expensive, long-lasting items -- slipped 0.6 percent, to $182 billion, the Commerce Department said.
While analysts welcomed yesterday's rally, some cautioned that it might not be sustainable, since the last week in August is usually a slow one and the biggest economic news next week -- the first revision of the nation's gross domestic product for the second quarter -- is expected to show that the economy either experienced no growth or contracted in that period.
"We've all become skeptics of every rally that we've seen in this market," said Francis D. Gannon, senior equity portfolio manager at SunAmerica Asset Management. "Next week is going to be a very quiet week in this market with not much happening. The fear right now is that number could be negative. Actually hearing or seeing it in print for the first time, psychologically, is going to be big for a lot of people."
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday. The 10-year Treasury note fell 11/32, to 100 21/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.92 percent from 4.87 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 18/32, to 98 31/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.45 percent from 5.41 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Arena Debate Complicates Governor Race In New Jersey 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Aug. 23 

 BODY:
It was perhaps inevitable that a plan to build a new arena in Newark for the New Jersey Devils and New Jersey Nets would run into fiscal, public policy and political obstructions. After all, the issue of government aiding wealthy sports team owners with lucrative deals and incentives has left a bad taste in many communities -- and this deal had to work for the whole state of New Jersey. 
 But few could have predicted just how complicated New Jersey's arena politics would become once it veered into the thicket of gubernatorial politics. 
 This week, Republican candidate Bret D. Schundler called for a statewide referendum on the proposed arena, saying that he feared it could end up costing taxpayers statewide should it run into financial problems. The arena's cost, now set at $385 million by the state and the YankeeNets, the teams' owner, would be financed by the state, the private developers and local government. 
The proposal to hold a referendum has led to a collision between Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican, who sees an arena as a key legacy of his time in office, and Mr. Schundler, who has no love for Mr. DiFrancesco and considers opposition to the arena as a potent pocketbook issue in his race against the Democrat James E. McGreevey. 
Most analysts predicted that a statewide referendum on the plan would very likely doom it, as voters who oppose the project and see it as a vehicle for wealthy team owners to soak taxpayers would be more motivated to turn out than would those who were supportive or even neutral.
It has all upped the ante on the Newark arena deal, which has generally enjoyed bipartisan support thanks to Mr. DiFrancesco's efforts. 
It also means a sharper look at plans to replace the Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands complex, where the teams now play, with a Disney-like family entertainment and sports complex, and at proposals for direct aid to a proposed sports complex at Rowan University in South Jersey that was being sought by Jack Collins, the Republican speaker of the Assembly, as the price of his support for the Newark arena.
Dennis E. Gale, executive director of the Joseph C. Cornwall Center for Metropolitan Studies at Rutgers University in Newark, said that until Mr. Schundler spoke this week, "no one has stepped forward to suggest that this is a bad, three-cornered deal for the state."
Others have expressed concern after Mr. Schundler's call for a referendum and his insistence that any project costs not be borne directly by state taxpayers. Assemblyman Richard H. Bagger, the Republican chairman of the Assembly appropriations committee, which is scheduled to consider the measure in a special session early next month, said that he, too, is now concerned about the proposal's fate and expects the committee to rigorously review all its aspects. 
"As things are added to this to get broader support, it makes it harder for some others to support it," Mr. Bagger said. "I am concerned about this and plan to have a watchful eye on each thing that is proposed."
It was against this backdrop that Mr. DiFrancesco, in a hurriedly arranged ceremony, took the offensive against Mr. Schundler and today signed into law a bill that would facilitate new development in Newark that would help generate the sales-tax revenue to allow the proposed arena to support itself.
Under Mr. DiFrancesco's original proposal for both the Newark arena and any replacement development at the Meadowlands that was approved by the Senate in June, the financing would be aided by tax-exempt bonds issued by a state-created entity. Those bonds -- worth $190 million in the case of the Newark arena -- would be repaid by revenue generated by an increased sales tax at the arena and in the adjacent area. 
To promote economic activity around the arena, Mr. DiFrancesco signed a bill today that would provide tax incentives for Atlantic City casinos to invest in entertainment, retail or housing development in urban areas throughout the state. That bill would immediately trigger a planned $20 million investment by the Tropicana Casino in a housing and retail complex here that city officials say will make downtown Newark a 24-hour city once again.
"All of this fits nicely with the Newark arena," said Mr. DiFrancesco in an interview after signing the bill into law. "Those who question whether the funding plan for the arena is realistic are just plain wrong. Even if nothing else happens in Newark, there will be enough generated by the arena to cover the bonds."
Mr. Schundler has insisted that he is not against the arena for Newark. He is, however, skeptical about the acting governor's insistence that it will not add to the state's debt burden and wants assurances that a bailout at the expense of state taxpayers would not be possible. At the very least, he said voters should be asked directly if they are willing to foot the bill if things don't work out. 
In pressing this point, Mr. Schundler has called upon his Democratic opponent, Mr. McGreevey, to explain his support of the arena proposal and show a similar concern for what voters may or may not want to do.
But David P. Rebovich, a political scientist at Rider University, said that Mr. Schundler has done more to discomfit Mr. DiFrancesco than he has to challenge Mr. McGreevey. So far, the Democratic candidate has simply reiterated his support for the arena and said that he accepts the acting governor's assurances that it will not be a burden on state taxpayers.
"It is the Republican establishment's goal to put the arena in Newark," Mr. Rebovich said, "and at a time when he should be shoring up support among fellow Republicans, Mr. Schundler has decided to continue the tack from the primary of engaging that establishment in a fight. At some point, Republicans are going to see him as endangering their legislative majorities in both houses." 
To be sure, there is some sentiment in the state against a Newark arena. 
An unpublished poll of New Jersey voters conducted in July by the state Republican Committee found that 65 percent of those polled disapproved of a new arena financed by sales-tax revenue generated at a new sports complex, said Stephen Salmore, a professor of political science at Fairleigh Dickinson University. He said that it would not be hard for a determined core of opposition to mobilize this sentiment.
Mr. Rebovich disagreed. He said that while the nation is still on the cusp of economic good times, the arena issue and a number of others being pressed by Mr. Schundler resonate intellectually but not practically with voters.
Meanwhile, Mr. Schundler has angered urban Democrats like Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, who supports Mr. McGreevey, and has left fellow Republicans in Essex County who support the arena, like County Executive James W. Treffinger, with little to say.
Mr. James, reached over ship-to-shore communications from a Caribbean cruise, accused Mr. Schundler of fiscal gimmickry in a number of programs while he was mayor of Jersey City and said that his call for a referendum "divides us, rich from poor, urban from suburban." He said he could not remember any more divisive moves by past gubernatorial candidates, either Democrats or Republicans.
Mr. Treffinger was in town, but he was repeatedly unavailable this week to comment on the issue.

HEADLINE: India-U.S. Fight on Basmati Rice Is Mostly Settled 

BYLINE:  By SARITHA RAI 

 BODY:
A Texas company's attempt to patent a type of basmati rice became a touchstone for anti-globalization protest in the 1990's. But the long-simmering issue was largely settled this week, when the United States granted a narrower patent to the company, Ricetec of Alvin, Tex.
 The United States originally granted the patent in 1997, touching a nerve in India, leading to a challenge by the Indian government and igniting demonstrations against what was termed a piracy of emerging nations' indigenous products. 
 After this week's decision, the Indian government said it saw no reason for further dispute. The new patent is limited to a few variants of the rice and will not hamper export of its own basmati product, the government concluded. 
Still, scientists in India are complaining about future problems while evaluating the impact, and opposition politicians are agitating for further action.
The protests in the late 1990's were led by Vandana Shiva, who called Ricetec's claim to basmati rice absurd. She termed the limited scope of the final patent largely a success. But, she warned, "the battle against Ricetec is just the beginning of India's battle against bio-piracy and theft of indigenous plant wealth."
For most Indians, the basmati controversy went beyond the economic impact of one product. Basmati, an aromatic rice used in virtually every Indian kitchen, is considered a national heritage. The long-grain rice, whose grains remain petal-soft and separate after cooking, grows in the Punjab region in the north, and across the border in Pakistan.
In 1997, the United States initially granted a broad basmati patent to Ricetec, which developed several strains of rice marketed under various names as similar to basmati. Of the 20 claims made by the company, most related to the rice plant, with others covering the grain and farming methods.
The American decision created an uproar as bitter Indians expressed frustration that successive governments had let India lose claim to basmati, which had never been trademarked. India and its rival Pakistan said they would fight the patent, calling it a threat to the economic survival of thousands of farmers in the subcontinent. More than 50,000 people demonstrated in front of the United Sates Embassy against the patent.
At the World Trade Organization conference in Seattle, India protested the agreement on trade-related intellectual property rights, which had led to a spate of patents for western companies, including for basmati rice. Another coalition denounced the basmati rice patent at the Seattle meeting, and called on W.T.O. members to accept that the rights of farmers and communities precede intellectual property rights.
At the Summit of the Americas in Quebec, activists protested against the prospect of intellectual property protection that would work to the advantage of multinationals involved in genetic engineering of agricultural products -- like basmati developed over hundreds of years -- at the expense of small farmers in developing countries.
For years, India largely ignored any claim or legal protection for growers and marketers of basmati. A bill has been introduced to recognize produce as belonging to a specific geographical area, but it is still pending before a panel of the Parliament. Given that basmati is not patented by geographic location even within India, the country's international patent appeal appears weak.
For over two decades "basmati" has been used in the United States to describe long-grain aromatic rice grown domestically. This usage went unchallenged by India, so much so that the patent claims were under the plea of "long usage" provided for in trade-related intellectual property rights.
The premium grain stacked up in American supermarkets under brand names like Calmati, which comes from California, and Texmati and Kasmati, which are marketed by Ricetec.
Indian basmati exporters dismiss these varieties as basmati imitations. The distinct aroma and the texture of basmati comes from the Indian soil irrigated by waters from the Himalayan rivers, they say.
India urged the United States Patent and Trade Office in April 2000 to re-examine certain Ricetec claims that India felt posed a threat to Indian basmati exports to the United States. In hundreds of pages of scientific evidence, India argued that its basmati varieties already had the characteristics claimed as unique by Ricetec.
India protested Ricetec's claim to the term basmati, and insisted that the appellation should be reserved for rice grown in a specific region in India. The argument is much like the one that has been used successfully to limit Champagne to France and Scotch whiskey to Scotland.
Ricetec subsequently withdrew some 15 claims. The American patent office just issued a patent on the claims dealing with three strains of the rice developed by the company.
While the government said it was satisfied, opposition politicians stalled proceedings in the Indian Parliament demanding that the government challenge the patent.
On Tuesday, the commerce minister, Digvijay Singh, tried to pacify members of Parliament, saying Ricetec had received only a varietal patent so it could sell its rice as a superior strain of basmati. India could also develop its own different strains of basmati, he said.
Ms. Shiva, the protester, saw the narrowing of the patent as a significant accomplishment. "What remains is a farmers' battle, because Ricetec's strains have been bred from traditional Indian and Pakistani basmati varieties," she said. Activists will continue to urge the government to pursue a trademark battle for the basmati name.
But scientists, including Dr. S. A. Siddiq of the Indian Council of Agricultural Research, remain skeptical about India's ability to thwart piracy of traditional basmati strains. "India exports a million tons of basmati a year, and India is complacent because the Ricetec patent does not hinder that," Dr. Siddiq said.
The issue goes beyond mere protection of trade and export of the rice. "The basmati patent came so suddenly that India has just woken up to the threat to its traditional plant wealth," Dr. Siddiq said. "We have to get our laws in place." 
Ms. Shiva says that allowing multinational companies to patent indigenous produce and knowledge is a theft and has resulted in the revoking of a European patent for the traditional Indian neem tree. Patent fights are on for medicinal turmeric and tamarind.
"Granting exclusive patent rights amounts to stealing economic options of daily survival from the developing world," Ms. Shiva said.
