HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
A Long-Timer's Solution to Boredom: Be a Barnum

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW GUREWITSCH; Matthew Gurewitsch writes about the arts for The Wall Street Journal and other publications.

 BODY:
THAT'S why I loved it. So lurid and preposterous." Such is the verdict of Jo March, supplier of sensational fictions for The Daily Volcano, after her maiden outing to the opera. Still, she has a complaint.
 "Couldn't they print the words on a banner," she asks, "unspool it in front of the stage, so you could read what they were saying as they sing it?" 
 Friedrich Bhaer, her earnest escort, replies, "It never would work, Miss March." 
No need to ask whose side David Gockley would take when Jo pleads for an unscrolling banner. As general director of the Houston Grand Opera for the past three decades, Mr. Gockley has made it his business to press beyond the status quo. How charming, therefore, to hear the exchange between Jo and Bhaer from the stage of Mr. Gockley's company. Of course, as readers of Louisa May Alcott's classic "Little Women" will have noticed, though the characters are hers, the scene is not. It is the invention of the American composer Mark Adamo, whose first opera, after Alcott, was written (to his own libretto) on commission from the Houston Grand Opera. On Wednesday, the Houston production of Mr. Adamo's "Little Women" reaches a national television audience by way of the Thirteen/WNET series "Great Performances" on PBS. As is now routine, the telecast will be titled, as was the show in the opera house.
Titles, perhaps more than any other single factor, have helped "de-demonize" opera (Mr. Gockley's phrase) for hitherto resistant contemporary audiences, so you can bet he loves them. Mr. Gockley is no elitist. Hired as the Houston Grand Opera's business manager in 1970, he rose to the general directorship two years later, still in his late 20's. Under his aegis, a sleepy regional company with a full-time staff of seven, 20 performances of five productions per season and an annual budget of $550,000 has grown into an organization with 120 employees, 60 performances of nine productions per season and a budget of nearly $22 million.
Cook up an idea for broadening the reach or heightening the impact of opera, and he will make it work. Like impresarios everywhere, he understands the necessity of developing new audiences. What he understands better than most is the necessity not only to pique their curiosity but also to capture their loyalty, which often entails serving them in ways that may frighten old-timers.
"Being in one place so long, I need to find ways not to get bored," said Mr. Gockley, a native of Philadelphia, still boyish at 58, on a recent swing through New York. Truth to tell, he sounded slightly bored. He speaks slowly, with long pauses and a faraway look in his eye, as if collecting his thoughts from some Martian twilight zone. As a result, quite a few new acquaintances have formed a first impression of the man (quite false) as closed and cold. "I'm always working at the margins," he continued. "Sometimes I'm criticized for straining the main operations of the company for the sake of what's new and marginal." In the process, the margins move farther out, and the field that is opera keeps expanding.
Over the years, Mr. Gockley's efforts have no doubt struck one or two of his more conservative constituents as lurid and preposterous, not necessarily in Jo March's honorific sense. Behind a corporate Brooks Brothers facade that has long served as protective coloring in his dealings with the city's rich and powerful, he has worked the wiles of an operatic P. T. Barnum, ceaselessly plying audiences new and old with his own buzzy elixir of art and showmanship. He does not stand on dignity. More than once at company parties, staff members have tossed him into a swimming pool.
For the sake of art, he has donned Mozartean silks and powdered wig and a Davy Crockett coonskin cap. In the opening weeks of the Houston Astros' new Enron Field, he walked his 11-year-old son, Adam, onto the mound to throw a first pitch. He has taken Scott Joplin to Broadway, "Nixon in China" to Scotland and "Show Boat" to the Nile. In the teeth of the oil recession of the 1980's, he built the $72 million Wortham Theater Center, a space-age home for the company, complete with auditoriums of 2,400 seats (the Brown) and 1,100 seats (the Cullen), without a penny of public financing.
How did he do it? "Houston has an inferiority complex," he says. "It won't support an also-ran. Houston Grand Opera is the jewel in the cultural crown. That's something the city would support."
But Mr. Gockley's influence transcends his company. In ways seldom acknowledged, his vision has shaped the destiny of opera in America.
A separate essay could be written, for instance, on how Mr. Gockley's preferences in direction and design have infiltrated American opera. The original staging of "Nixon in China," by Peter Sellars, comes to mind, as does the Robert Wilson "Parsifal" (imported from Europe). But it is not only the highest-profile projects that count. The Houston Grand Opera has found a steady secondary market for sales and rentals of its shows. Two of the Cincinnati Opera's four festival productions this summer originated in Houston: Francesca Zambello's "Madama Butterfly" of 1988, already something of a classic; and the "Magic Flute," with which Maurice Sendak's brilliant moonlight career as an opera designer began more than 20 years ago.
Yet inevitably, the handiest measure of Mr. Gockley's spirit of enterprise is his tally of new operas. Last year, the company published an impressive special report, "An American Voice: Houston Grand Opera Celebrates 25 World Premieres," covering the period from 1974 to 2000. Thomas Pasatieri's "Seagull" (after Chekhov) led the way, with Frederica von Stade and Evelyn Lear in the starring roles. Since then, Houston has unveiled new operas by several Americans, including Leonard Bernstein, John Adams, Philip Glass, Meredith Monk, Tod Machover and Carlisle Floyd. But Michael Tippett of England and Daniel Catan of Mexico are on the honor roll as well.
Though hardly the first of the Houston Grand Opera commissions to have an afterlife on other stages, Mr. Adamo's "Little Women" may well go down as the most fortunate of all. Fiercely true to Alcott's spirit as he understands it, Mr. Adamo has treated the letter of her novel with the ruthlessness that distinguishes the artist from the mere adapter. Scored for 10 soloists, an orchestra of 18 and an offstage chorus of two sopranos and two altos, it was tailored to the modest resources of the company's finishing school for young artists, the Houston Grand Opera Studio. In Stephanie Novacek's portrayal of Jo March, Mr. Adamo's heroine, a star was born. Two performances of "Little Women" by students in March 1998 were plenty to persuade Mr. Gockley that the new work deserved a broader hearing. He promptly shoehorned it into the main company's 1999-2000 season, keeping the cast (students no longer) virtually intact.
The story continues. Already, "Little Women" has been picked up by companies in Kansas, California, Colorado and Virginia, with productions to follow in Nebraska, Minnesota and Indiana. Next summer it reaches the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., in a co-production that moves to the New York City Opera in 2003. No doubt there will be other stagings. Star-caliber young mezzos for years to come are sure to find Jo irresistible, and the opportunities for the rest of the cast are juicy, too. Mr. Adamo, meanwhile, is working on a second Houston Grand Opera commission: "Lysistrata, or The Nude Goddess," an explosive farce of sex and politics, after Aristophanes. Beyond that looms an Adamo "Dracula," also for Houston.
Like virtue, the injection of durable home-grown work into the repertory of companies in this country and abroad is (largely) its own reward. But at this stage in the evolution of the form, the main business of any large opera company is the conservation of a mainly European past. If performances of standard repertory at the Houston Grand Opera often seem especially satisfying -- carefully cast, thoughtfully directed, stylishly designed -- the engagement with the contemporary is one reason, as Mr. Adamo points out.
"For a company to commit so much to new work reflects on how you're supposed to see old work," he says. "New work needs to be fresh, communicative, aware of where we've been and where we're going. Houston is the only company that uses new work as a prism through which to view everything else it does."
Early in his tenure, Mr. Gockley got behind the standard audience-building efforts, sending docents (he called them "Aidas") and touring performances into the schools. More ambitious developments more recently promise to be at least as far-reaching. A fact sheet on the company's 46-year history points with pride to its Plazacasts: live feeds from the stage to a giant outdoor screen. The series, now annual, began in 1995 with Rossini's "Cenerentola," starring Cecilia Bartoli. The first such venture by an American opera company, it drew a crowd of 3,000, far more representative of the city's demographics than the audience in the house.
Titles? Everyone has those now. But who else has "Operavision"? No one, according to Mr. Gockley. When viewers in the balcony complained that they couldn't read the supertitles over the proscenium, Mr. Gockley gave them something extra: a system of monitors that display not only running titles but also close-ups of the singers. Mr. Gockley now has one stationary overall camera and two close-up cameras rolling at every performance.
Let Luddites complain that Operavision turns opera into a sporting event. (As if! Does baseball predate television?) Mr. Gockley shrugs. "For the young audiences who can't afford tickets downstairs, video screens are very normal," he says. "They're used to that."
In 1998, appealing to audiences in the tens of thousands, Mr. Gockley unveiled the Multimedia Modular Stage, patterned on the stages used by traveling rock acts. So far, "Carmen," "I Pagliacci" and "Madama Butterfly" have received the stadium treatment in productions that integrate electronically amplified performance, reasonably complete and in the operas' original languages, with live close-ups and recorded video material, both still and moving.
Once again, Mr. Gockley's package is proving its appeal beyond his adopted city. In June, the Houston Grand Opera visited the cavernous Mann Center, in the sylvan outskirts of Philadelphia, with a revival of "Carmen," the original modular stage attraction. Gawky, cat-eyed, got up in a puffy party skirt, Suzanna Guzman inhabited the title role with casual, gritty conviction, her voice part smoke, part velvet. As Escamillo, the toreador, Kevin Short, blazed onstage as if he were Shaft, delivering his big number like the international hit it is.
To eyes and ears accustomed to the opera house, the whole affair felt less like music theater than like a pop concert. Attitude often trumped action, and pictures swamped the performers.
It worked, in a way. But is this, God forbid, what all opera is destined to come to? Or a new mutant, a point of entry for some, for others the whole shooting match?
"For me," the impresario replied on that muggy night, "live opera in the opera house will always be the core experience." Still, don't be surprised if companies around the nation follow him to the great outdoors.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Manhattan; 
Prebuilding Office Space to Attract Small Businesses

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
WITH demand for office space in Manhattan softening, landlords are paying more attention to smaller businesses, which collectively account for a substantial chunk of the office market.
 According to Peter Turchin, a managing director of Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company, leases of less than 10,000 square feet accounted for 1.4 million of the 6 million square feet of office space leased in Manhattan so far this year. 
 One tactic some building owners and managers are using to make their properties more attractive to smaller tenants is prebuilding offices, to help entice tenants with the prospect of saving them the time, inconvenience and expense of converting raw space into usable quarters. Brokers say that prebuilt space commands premium rents, to reflect the owners' investments, and that space in move-in condition rents more quickly than empty floors.
Real estate executives also say prebuilding space, particularly in older buildings, gives an owner an opportunity to present the property in the best possible condition, particularly if most of its offices were built many years ago. 
Many landlords routinely demolish existing office space when a tenant moves out, particularly if the tenant occupied a lot of space and the offices are battered and old fashioned. They market the raw space to prospective new tenants and, typically, make their contribution toward the cost of building new offices -- called a build-out allowance -- part of the lease negotiations.
The tenant then has to select an architect to design the interior and hire builders to get the necessary permits and do the actual work, which can take three to six months.
Prebuilding space is an effective marketing tool, said George P. Fabian, general manager of the Fisk Building on 57th Street and Eighth Avenue, particularly with smaller companies that do not have architects to produce renderings of what space will look like when built. "Most tenants cannot envision what space will look like when it is built," Mr. Fabian said. "Built space is a big marketing plus, and it always was." 
Prebuilt space is analogous to the finished offices being offered for sublet by failed or shrunken dot-coms and telecommunications companies. Such space has the attraction of being ready for quick occupancy. The difference is that the sublets are being offered by companies trying to get out of their lease obligations, while the prebuilds are being done by landlords on speculation.
There is an active prebuilding program under way at the Fisk Building, whose address is 250 West 57th Street. This is appropriate because the building specializes in small tenants, many of them in the media and entertainment business.
"TO many landlords, small tenants are a headache," Mr. Fabian said. "I have 320 tenants, so I have 320 potential headaches."
But, he added, having many small tenants, rather than a few large ones, is a form of insurance in economic downturns since the departure of any single tenant will have little impact on the building's income. "With big-space tenants, you can lose 10 percent or more of your income if a single tenant moves out," he said. "That gives them negotiating power."
The building, completed in 1921 for the long vanished Fisk Rubber Company, a tire maker, is updating its vacant spaces, which range from a few hundred square feet on the upper floors to 7,150 square feet on the third floor, which has been assembled for a larger tenant.
The renovations will include new carpeting, paint, a dropped ceiling and modern light fixtures. One space has a column squarely in the middle, but Mr. Fabian said tenants will simply have to live with it. "This could be a very functional four-person office," he said.
There are size limits on office prebuilds, said Richard Coles, a senior vice president of Emmes Realty Services, which is constructing offices at properties it owns at 535 Fifth Avenue, 545 Fifth Avenue and 19 West 44th Street.
"Spaces from about 800 square feet to about 4,000 square feet are ideal for prebuilds," he said. "Over about 5,000 square feet, the tenant has an architect and a builder and is comfortable with building out its own space."
Because small spaces have a limited number of possible layouts, Mr. Coles said, the prebuilds typically conform to a formula. "We put in as many partner offices as possible, a conference room, a kitchenette, a phone and copier room, and reserve the rest of the space for workstations."
Having the offices available for almost immediate occupancy "is a competitive advantage for a landlord," he said, particularly in the current market with effective rents trending down. A year ago, when rents were rising, tenants were eager to sign up for space well before their existing leases expired to lock in a rental rate before it went higher. Today they hold back as long as possible in hopes of signing at a lower rate.
"Tenants today think they can improve their position by waiting," Mr. Coles said. "As a result they don't have as much time once they make their decision, and that's why a prebuild program can be very successful."
Another small-tenant building with an active prebuild program is the Lincoln Building at 42nd Street and Madison Avenue, which specializes in law firms. (Both the Lincoln and Fisk Buildings are owned by partnerships headed by Peter L. Malkin of Wien & Malkin, hence the similar strategy.)
A typical tenant in the Lincoln Building is a lawyer who realizes he is not going to named partner at a major law firm and is striking out on his own, said Kevin Driscoll, the building's general manager. Tenants like this are interested in offices they can occupy quickly to start establishing their own practices.
"We are prebuilding offices on the lower floors of the building ranging from 1,200 to 4,000 square feet," Mr. Driscoll said. "We have done seven so far -- we'll do 10 by the end of the year -- and most have been rented during construction."
He said the renovations include new windows for the 71-year-old building, new lights and tenant-controlled air-conditioning. Mr. Driscoll said the improvements cost about $60 a square foot and the offices rent for $50 to $55 a square foot on short-term leases of three to five years. Although the leases suit tenants who may expand their operations or merge with someone else in a few years, he said, the alterations are expected to last for 12 to 15 years.
A principal advantage for a small company in leasing prebuilt space is that it does not have to dip into its own capital to finance construction, said Marc R. Shapses, a senior managing director at Julien J. Studley, a real estate services company specializing in representing tenants.
"When you rent prebuilt, you are on a pay-as-you-go basis," Mr. Shapses said. "You do not have to tie up your credit at the bank, and you pay for it in tax-deductible rent."
Although most prebuilt projects are concentrated in Midtown, some owners of buildings downtown are taking this approach as well, real estate executives say. All of the vacant space in the twin buildings at 111-115 Broadway at Cedar Street is going to be prebuilt, according to Adam Foster, a senior managing director of Insignia/ESG.
The buildings, which are owned by Capital Properties, have about 40,000 square feet that are vacant or about to become so. They are being developed as prebuilt spaces of 2,000 to 6,000 square feet, Mr. Foster said. These offices command a rent premium over raw space and, perhaps more important, rent quicker, providing the owner with an early cash flow, he added.
More important, he added, prebuilding offices can show the possibilities of the buildings, which opened at the turn of the last century, in 1905 and 1907. "Many of the existing offices are old fashioned and tired," he said. "This is a chance the show the building in the best light. The quality of the space will reflect the quality of the building."
Landlords offer prebuilt space to small tenants because the businesses' owners are typically in a position to make quick decisions about signing a lease without the lengthy discussions that can take place among layers of management in larger companies. 
"A 4,000-square-foot tenant does not need board approval," said Insignia/ESG's Mr. Turchin.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George P. Fabian, general manager, in an updated space in the Fisk Building ready for almost immediate use. (Krista Joy Niles for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hamburger: A Few Bucks. Getting There: $100 or So. 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL 

 BODY:
IT may not have much cachet among the Hamptons jet set, but Belle's Cafe, a Caribbean-Cajun spot in Westhampton, has something that even the most chic East End restaurants don't: a close-up view of Gabreski Airport's 9,000-foot runway and a clientele of hungry pilots, some of whom travel hundreds of miles just for a few slices of Belle's french toast. 
 Across the street from the Montauk Airport is Rick's Crabby Cowboy, a casual restaurant that serves everything from lobster to hamburgers, and where one popular pilot offers waitresses rides in his single-engine Cessna instead of a tip. 
 Recreational pilots love flying, particularly to find good food -- the "$100 hamburger," given the travel costs involved. 
"With inflation, a hamburger is now closer to $150," said Spencer Kagan, 55, a judge from Marblehead, Mass., who counts Belle's as a particular favorite. "Pilots need destinations to go to, rather than just burning holes in the clouds. So many airfields have great restaurants. We have fun and you meet great people, crazy like we are." 
Mr. Kagan doesn't think much of Belle's ambience, but that is not the point: it's the omelets, french toast and esprit de corps. On a clear weekend morning, he and several friends will rent a single-engine Cessna, fly down for an early breakfast and be back in Massachusetts by noon.
Owen Carr, 41, a former resident of Huntington who also lives in Massachusetts, frequently flies to Long Island to visit family and, of course, to have lunch.
His six-seat Bonanza cruises down the scenic Hudson corridor in about 40 minutes and arrives at Republic Airport, where he and his passengers amble over to the 56th Fighter Group, a popular restaurant with a World War II theme, equal parts eatery and museum. P-47 Thunderbolt and P-40 Warhawk fighter planes can be seen from the back of the restaurant, monuments to a bygone era of aviation.
The 56th, with an eclectic, modestly priced menu, also draws locals, veterans and aviation enthusiasts. Patrons can wear headphones to eavesdrop on flight activity from the air-control tower just outside.
"You won't find these kind of restaurants in your average downtown," Mr. Carr said. 
That's why, four years ago, 28-year-old Doug Fields of New York took Brenda, now his wife, to the 56th on their first date. The young pilot said a fly-in dinner date is a sure way to impress a girlfriend -- and discover if she shares a passion for flying. In the case of Brenda, it was apparently a successful maneuver. 
Pilots like Mr. Fields and Mr. Carr appreciate the importance of good service and easy access to airport dining. Many airports provide pilots with courtesy cars they can borrow for a few hours if there is no restaurant on site or within walking distance.
Pilots can get mini-reviews about fly-in food worldwide on the Web, at www.100dollarhamburger.com. Restaurants are awarded a maximum of five burgers, based on quality, service and location. Both the 56th and Belle's received four burgers.
Beyond the food, Belle's offers entertainment on Sundays, where there is live jazz to go with the french toast. 
Some of the entertainment takes place even before the pilots get to the retaurant. When Mr. Carr lands at Gabreski, his plane is greeted by a "middle-aged man on a bicycle" who direct the craft to its parking spot and offers fuel and aviation maps.
Mr. Fields recalled landing one evening at Grabeski to find a deer blocking the runway. "I thought to myself, I hope it moves, or else I'll be having venison for dinner," he said.
Several pilots agree that for natural beauty, Montauk Airport has the others beat. As a plane approaches the runway, sand dunes appear majestically on the horizon.
Only a block from the Montauk airport is Rick's Crabby Cowboy. Every third Sunday, a group of pilots who call themselves the Breakfast Club fly in for a few hours, devour their eggs and bacon, then fly out.
"It baffles me as to why some people fly so far just to have breakfast," said Mandy Nolan, an assistant manager at Rick's. "Most of these people have a lot of money, they eat what they want, and are big tippers," 
Wes Grady, 56, a lawyer from Dutchess County, used to fly regularly to Montauk for seafood, to Cincinnati for chili and to Oshkosh, Wis., to meet friends. Recent back surgery has kept him out of the cockpit for more than a year, but he is planning his comeback, both in the air and at the luncheon table.
"We could drive down to McDonald's for burgers, but that isn't much fun," Mr. Grady said. "A pilot will fly for any reason and the 100-dollar burger gives us a good reason to get in the air."

HEADLINE: Architectural Trend Still Stirs Passions 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
WHEN David Paterson bought his modest, but open and airy modern-style house in Guilford more than a decade ago, he had no idea that its construction in 1964 had been part of a frenzied architectural movement known as the "International style" that had its origins in pre-World War II Europe.
 Mr. Paterson, a longtime golf pro at Yale University and former director of its golf programs, said he was immediately drawn to the Wingate Road House built by the late Connecticut architect Lauren E. (Pachy) Meyers because of its simplicity and light, and the surrounding woods that could be viewed from anywhere in the two-level structure. 
 The house was built as part of a development of a dozen modern-style homes located in a wooded area overlooking Long Island Sound. About half of the Wingate homes are considered "International," special even among modern homes because of a pristine symmetrical style, flat roofs, an emphasis on large glass windows and austere inside space designs. Most homes of the International style are designed to blend into the natural environment, built in wooded areas and often in natural rocky hillsides. 
Mr. Paterson said that while he had lived in his 2,400-square-foot house since 1990, he had only recently begun to realize how significant the International style movement was and how big a role Connecticut played during its peak era in the 1940's and 50's when many architects around the country came here specifically to design those houses.
He said he began to understand the significance when the former owner of the house who sold it to him tried to buy it back a few years later.
"I love it too much to sell it back," Mr. Paterson said. "I don't know where I would find another one quite like it."
In fact, architectural experts say Connecticut is among several states where the largest concentration of International style houses was built. They said that's because of the state's vast natural woodlands, its close proximity to the New York City architects who designed the homes, and the presence of the Yale University School of Architecture, where prominent architects schooled in the style had studied.
They said that while hundreds of the homes were undoubtedly constructed in Connecticut, including in New Canaan, Stamford, Darien, Ridgefield, Wilton and Orange, there are no exact numbers on how many were built or how many remain.
"Growing up in a miserable, old stone house in Scotland where the winters are dark and dreary and it gets dark by 4 in the afternoon, I was immediately taken with this house because of the massive windows that let in all this wonderful light, even during winter," said Mr. Paterson, president of the Wingate Association. "I didn't buy it because I was following any movement or anything like that, I bought it because I loved the simplicity of the interiors and the extraordinary view of the landscape."
Indeed, that is what attracted many to buy and even design and construct their own International style homes. It is what motivated the architect Philip Johnson in 1949 to build one for himself what has become Connecticut's most well-known International style home -- the "Glass House" on a 40-acre parcel in New Canaan.
"I've lived in this house for more than 50 years and the longer I'm here the more I realize that you have to live in a glass house to truly appreciate Connecticut," said Mr. Johnson, 95. "That's impossible from a regular house."
Ten years ago, Mr. Johnson gave the property to the National Trust for Historic Preservation with the understanding he could stay there and that it would become a museum after his death. The house is already on the National Register of Historic Places.
While Mr. Johnson is not involved in the growing movement to save International style houses -- he said he prefers to spend his time designing new buildings -- others like Richard Bergmann, an architect from New Canaan, have taken up the cause because they said the houses must be preserved.
Some, like Mr. Paterson's Guilford neighbors, Terrence and Lissa MacLaren, are not just passionate about the Wingate Road house they live in, they are also determined to preserve as many of the International style homes as they can because they said the houses represented an important architectural era they are convinced is on the brink of a revival.
Mr. MacLaren compared his three-level, 3,500-square-foot house to a work of abstract art. It is built into a heavily wooded rocky hill overlooking Long Island Sound and was designed by the internationally renowned architect Bruce Arneill of Old Saybrook. Mr. MacLaren and his wife said they particularly enjoyed the living room, which includes upper wall windows called clerestories that allows them to "watch the clouds float by."
"I had been fascinated by the International style house for more than 20 years and when this came on the market a few years ago I knew I had to have it," said Mr. MacLaren, a lawyer who writes law books and has lived in the Guilford area for more than a decade.
The MacLarens have been so taken with their Wingate Road home they are planning to build a similar one in the Arizona desert, where they will relocate as soon as they find a buyer for the house.
That, however, isn't always easy, according to the man who designed it. Mr. Arniell, who said he also came to Connecticut from the Midwest 40 years ago to study architecture at Yale University, said International style homes are not for everyone. 
No one knows that better than Henry F. Miller, a former Yale architect, who is still passionate about the International style house he built in 1949 in Orange.
It was a decade after the 1939 "world of tomorrow" World's Fair in New York and just a few years after the end of World War II when wild anticipation awaited the public viewing of Mr. Miller's "House of Tomorrow," as it was named in a New Haven Register headline. The public viewing drew nearly 4,000 people on May 15, 1949.
By the end of that year more than 25,000 people would pay 10 cents, which went to a local charity, to view the two-level International style rectangular structure with its flat roof and movable walls built into a natural hillside and designed to blend into its 2 1/2-acre woodlands parcel off Derby Avenue.
"At that time I truly believed we would see this style become one of the most popular not only in the United States, but throughout the world," said Mr. Miller, who is a retired architect and also taught at Yale. 
"While the style did become somewhat popular for a while during the 1950's, it never quite caught on the way I had expected -- I guess because most people are used to living in cozy capes or large colonials and never quite embraced this more unique and modest style," said Mr. Miller, whose house was added to the National Register of Historic Places in April.
Vincent Scully, the Sterling Emeritus Professor of Art History and School of Architecture at Yale University, also designed an International style home in Woodbridge around the same time as Mr. Miller and lived in it for years. He said he recalls the passion for the style among some people in the late 1940's and early 50's as "something of a frenzy or madness" they were convinced would catch on with the masses.
"After years of economic depression and war, we were embraced by a strange kind of enthusiasm that everything had to be new and we were certain this style home was the answer because it embodied modesty and simplicity and was built to blend in with the natural surroundings," Mr. Scully said. "Of course, it never quite happened that way as most Americans instead came to embrace the materialism of larger colonial style homes and mansions. Still, I think we created something quite remarkable at the time."

David Patterson says he was drawn to his house, left and far left, because of its simplicity and light, and the surrounding woods. (Photographs by Joseph Kugielsky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND VINES; 
Heading West

BYLINE:  By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
Vincent A. Galluccio, the owner of Gristina/Galluccio Estate Vineyards in Cutchogue, plans to establish a California label and a line of California wines.
 The label, to be called Galluccio Family Winery, will probably be based in the Napa Valley, where Mr. Galluccio hopes to buy into an existing winery. 
 Mr. Galluccio expects to use both operations to complement each other in nationwide marketing.
Very few Long Island wines are sold nationally in sizable quantities. Mr. Galluccio hopes to have Gristina/Galluccio wines distributed in 15 states by the end of 2002.
Shortly after he bought Gristina in August 2000 and began increasing its output, Mr. Galluccio started signaling coast-to-coast ambitions by placing Gristina/Galluccio ads in national wine magazines. He expects to go into other media in the future.
In addition to New York, "Gristina wines are currently available in Connecticut and in Napa and Los Angeles," he said. 
"Distribution goals include Florida, New Jersey, Illinois, Minnesota, Georgia and the Carolinas."
Mr. Galluccio intends to discontinue the production of three low-priced wines on the North Fork and to have them made in California and carry California identities. They are the rose of cabernet; Avalon, a riesling made with Finger Lakes grapes; and Garnet, a red blend, whose name will change.
"We're moving the value-tier wines" -- a trade euphemism for low-priced -- "out of Long Island because it is not economical to make them here," he said. "I want to concentrate on making only premium wines at Gristina."
The shift toward premium wines is partly anchored in Mr. Galluccio's recent hiring of Michel Rolland, Bordeaux's best-known "flying winemaker," as a Gristina/Galluccio consultant. He said he had not discussed any role in California with Mr. Rolland.
Mr. Galluccio said that Gristina's winemaker, Charles Girard, would oversee the winemaking in both places.
"Long Island will be the jewel in the crown," Mr. Galluccio said. "If California were the jewel, it would be 'me too.' "
 HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

HEADLINE: Rebuilding Careers Out of the Ashes 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE DIGRAZIA 

 BODY:
THE special emergency office created to help workers who lost their jobs when the Latex Foam Products factory in Ansonia was destroyed by fire May 14 has been dismantled. Concerned calls from local companies offering to interview displaced workers have dwindled. A special job fair featuring 26 prospective employers was held in June and no others have been scheduled.
 But in the three months since shocked Latex Foam employees watched their livelihoods disappear, about 59 percent of the 190 employees thrown out of work have found new jobs. Community groups and churches have rallied to raise and donate money so workers can pay for food, rent and utilities. The company has said it will rebuild the plant, but has not decided where, although Peter DeMarco, the chief operating officer, said the preference would be to remain in the state, maybe even rebuilding in Ansonia. 
 State labor officials and various job-assistance agencies continue to struggle to find ways to keep workers' spirits up, but said it has been a roller-coaster ride. 
"They've gone through all the stages similar to the grieving process when you lose a loved one: shock, anger, sadness," said Nancie Gray, vice president of marketing and special events for the Greater Valley Chamber of Commerce, one of the job fair's sponsors. "Everybody is handling it differently."
The company's 10-acre plant site on West Main Street in Ansonia still contains scattered piles of twisted metal and charred Latex products. Fire officials said the fire appeared to have started when an oven used to dry wet Latex caught fire. 
Most of the displaced workers are receiving unemployment compensation for 26 weeks, or until they find new jobs. The luckier ones have been receiving severance pay based on the number of years they worked at the factory. Others, according to Carol Sundlin, director of the State Department of Labor's Job Center, are coming in regularly to use the Ansonia office's telephones, computers and fax machines to search for jobs. But others aren't looking at all because they're waiting to see whether Latex Foam will rebuild its factory in the Naugatuck Valley or move out of state.
"I did think more would have returned to work by this time," Ms. Sundlin said. "They have received more help than the average unemployed person. We have bent over backwards."
Part of the problem may be that unemployment is on the rise in Connecticut -- its 3.2 percent unemployment rate is still among the lowest in the nation, but initial unemployment claims were 60 percent higher in July of this year over the same period in 2000. National unemployment claims figures suggest the country's fragile labor market is struggling.
Jim Bradshaw, 34, is part of that struggle. He was a material handler at Latex Foam and was able to find another job about a month after the fire using a revamped resume.
"I didn't have an updated, professional resume before the fire," Mr. Bradshaw said. "I had to create a new resume. The Job Center people helped me make it look real nice and professional. I didn't realize I was that good! I was a lead man for six years and they really played that up big."
He was hired by Spectrum Plastics in Ansonia, one of the local companies represented at the job fair in June. But within weeks he was laid off.
"I saw it coming," said Mr. Bradshaw, who is looking for work again. "I knew the ax was going to fall and it did." He's now working full time as a gas station attendant in a station in Trumbull.
Cory J. Thomas, 24, has had better luck. Like Mr. Bradshaw, he found work through the job fair, but he still has the job.
Mr. Thomas, who had worked at Latex Foam for seven years, was 18 when he dropped out of Ansonia High School and found his first full-time job making cosmetic powder puffs at the factory. Mr. Thomas said he later graduated from Shelton High School and rose through the ranks of machine operator and packer at Latex Foam to become a "team leader," supervising workers in the plant's mattress department.
"I was very comfortable," said Mr. Thomas of New Haven. "Anytime a job opening came up that paid more money, I would jump on it."
In the weeks after the fire, Mr. Thomas jumped on any job opportunity that came his way. He received career counseling and resume-building advice from labor department staffers and created his first professional resume, a concise chronological listing of jobs at Latex Foam that show the upward progression of his career. He placed numerous calls to prospective employers and faxed many resumes.
"If I leave the house at 9 a.m. to go job-hunting, I'm not usually back until 4 p.m.," Mr. Thomas said.
On a Saturday morning shortly after the fire, an upbeat and confident Mr. Thomas spent two hours visiting 17 out of 26 company booths at a job fair at Ansonia High School for the displaced workers.
"I'm going to either fail or succeed here today," Mr. Thomas said as he prepared to stop at the first booth. "I'm happy they are offering this opportunity. Usually, when you send in a job application, you don't get to meet anybody at the company. I like this face-to-face meeting. You get an immediate response."
Indeed, Mr. Thomas was greeted enthusiastically at a number of booths. But no one was more enthusiastic than Patsy Rubbo, general manager, and Marty Kellaher, vice president of sales, at J&L Molding of Wallingford, a manufacturer of plastic molding components for companies such as U.S. Surgical Corporation and Johnson & Johnson.
Mr. Rubbo and Mr. Kellaher said they were looking for candidates to fill three positions. "We're looking for people that seem to have good attitudes, good work ethics and good potential for future growth," Mr. Rubbo said. He pointed to notes he had made on the top of Mr. Thomas' resume: "Good attitude. Hard worker." Mr. Rubbo said: "We noticed Cory has had ever-increasing responsibilities at Latex Foam, which shows constant improvement. He's always had part-time jobs and schooling, so he's constantly trying to better himself. He just shines."
Mr. Rubbo said that there was no immediate opening for Mr. Thomas, but that he and Mr. Kellaher thought he had the potential to manage a new third shift the company is considering.
Two weeks after the fair, Mr. Thomas said he had received calls from six employers, four from companies represented at the job fair including J&L Plastic, and two from his own job search.
"Money-wise, they're all a little more than what I was making," Mr. Thomas said. "For a while I didn't hear from anybody, then all of a sudden, everyone was calling."
Mr. Thomas has since been hired as a full-time cable installer at Tele-Media of Southwestern Connecticut in Seymour.
"I'm really sorry the plant burned down, but if it didn't, I wouldn't have ventured into something else," he said. "All in all, I would never want to go through this again."
Bardhyl and Vjollca Ajoka, a young married couple who moved to the United States from Albania a year ago, also lost their jobs when the plant was destroyed. The Ajokas received a job offer in the weeks since the fire, but instead chose to receive unemployment compensation benefits and concentrate on their dream of getting an education in computers. Mr. Ajoka said that while the fire that ended their eight-month stint on the same shift as foam-mattress cutters was a "tragedy for the business," it was not a catastrophe for the couple, who are permanent residents hoping to become United States citizens.
Mr. Ajoka said they had no immediate worries about being evicted from the house they rent for $550 a month in Ansonia because their landlord, a fellow Albanian, has told them not to worry for now and pay what they can. The Ajokas, who were teachers in Albania, are receiving a total of $152 a week in unemployment compensation, Mr. Ajoka said.
In the meantime, the couple has completed about half of a 54-hour computer-training program at the Waterbury branch of Hartford's Goodwin College, where they will attend classes for nine weeks. Their education in basic Microsoft Windows, Word, Excel, PowerPoint skills and how to navigate the Internet is being paid for by a federal back-to-work program administered by Job-Link in Bridgeport, said Mary Jane Mulvey, a skill development counselor.
Goodwin College has worked hard to make sure the Ajokas fit in, said Peter Travers, director of the college's "One-2-One" training program. Because the couple has only one car and because they prefer to attend classes together, the school has arranged for them to alternate with their instructor between classes and computer labs.
"Bardhyl will be in class for three hours, while Vjollca will be in a practice lab, then vice versa," Mr. Travers said. "They want to get back to work as quickly as possible. Then, when they find work, they want to continue to go to school. They have a hell of an uphill battle. They will have a tough time finding work because of cultural differences." Mr. Travers added that he thought the couple had "a tremendous amount of courage."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Housing for Artists -- and a Spur for Downtowns

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to housing, artists who have not achieved star status may find themselves living in the 21st-century equivalent of the proverbial garret. 
 But growing enthusiasm about the reuse of neglected and abandoned buildings across the country has been providing opportunities for such properties to be turned over to artists as live-work space, financed by a patchwork of public, corporate and private money. Such ventures are seen as contributing to the revival of troubled downtown districts. 
 In Connecticut, the latest on a short but expanding list of properties designated for conversion for artists' use is in Bridgeport, where the 100,000-square-foot former Read's department store, built in 1925 and abandoned 20 years ago, is to be reconfigured into 63 live-work units for visual artists, writers and musicians.
Together with the renovation of a rundown 75,000-square-foot hotel and shopping arcade, Read's will form the nucleus of a block of shops, restaurants and offices bounded by Cannon, Main, John and Broad Streets. More important, the artists and their families are expected to bring round-the-clock vibrancy back to a downtown that is moribund after 6 p.m. 
Read's is the latest project to be undertaken by Artspace Inc. of Minneapolis, a nonprofit agency that opened in 1979 as a housing referral service for displaced artists. Today it provides long-term live-work space for artists at below-market rates in 12 buildings that it owns and operates around the country.
"ALL our projects are in substantial, usually historic, buildings converted from some other use," said Sarah Parker, communications manager for Artspace. 
Each building has a waiting list for tenants, and the Bridgeport project, according to an Artspace survey of artists within a 30-mile radius, will draw from 45 Connecticut towns, from Westchester and from New Jersey. Interest generated by word of mouth has also come from Rhode Island, Vermont and Texas. There have been inquiries from three times as many artists as there are units. 
Read's is an important piece of a development strategy conceived by the city seven years ago, said Michael Freimuth, Bridgeport's director of development. "We were looking for a niche in the region," he said. "We focused on arts and entertainment, education, government and intermodal transportation to bring people into the city." 
To that end, Housatonic Community College moved downtown from the outskirts in 1997; the Ballpark at Harbor Yard, home of the Bridgeport Bluefish baseball team, opened in 1998; and the Polka Dot Playhouse was relocated in 1999 from a forlorn location at Seaside Park to a handsome theater remodeled from a bank building on State Street. In addition, an ice hockey arena near the ballpark is nearing completion, and a new Superior Courthouse and Juvenile Courthouse and Detention Center are to be built by the state. A high-speed ferry is planned to Stamford and New York; it is to be linked on land with the rail line and improved bus service.
Saving Read's from demolition was the unexpected result of the city of Norwalk's rejection two years ago of an Artspace plan to convert a former lock factory into artists' units. The building has since been redeveloped as offices and retail stores under the name Norwalk Art and Technology Center, which reflects the building's partial use in the past for artists' studios.
Seeking another venue to replace the Norwalk site, C. William Kraus, an independent consultant who was Artspace's volunteer negotiator, was referred to Robert Halstead, property dispositions manager for Bridgeport's tax-delinquent and foreclosed properties. Mr. Kraus was squired around to several sites, and Read's, with its 4.6-foot-wide-by-8-foot-high windows, 12- and 18-foot-high ceilings, solid brick exterior and concrete-over-steel construction, was the indisputable choice.
A proposal for the conversion was presented to State Senator William Finch, president of the Bridgeport Economic Development Corporation, which was in charge of developing that block. Impressed by the idea and by Artspace's reputation, Senator Finch said, "We lobbied the City Council and the mayor hard, and we were able to convince people who came to public hearings that Artspace tenants reflect the local population, and that as many minority businesses currently in the arcade will be retained as possible."
Read's $11.5 million conversion is to be designed by Crosskey Architects of Hartford. The exterior will look as it did in 1925, down to the wide green awnings that roll up in winter. The brick will be repointed and the windows restored. Each residential unit will be different -- some square, some rectangular, some L-shaped but all facing the outside. Doors will be four feet wide to accommodate artists' needs, and broad interior spaces will become informal galleries on each of the five floors. A 4,000-square-foot public gallery on the street floor will house major exhibitions.
Twenty one-bedroom units will contain 1,100 square feet each, 24 two-bedroom units will have 1,300 square feet and 19 three-bedroom units will measure 1,600 square feet. "We want the artists to have plenty of room to be creative," said William Crosskey, head of the architectural firm. 
Rents, pegged to artists' incomes, will range from $260 to $820 a month, according to Sarah Constant, president of Mission First, a Washington-based group that is Artspace's financial consultant and development manager, working as a liaison with architects, contractors, environmental and historic consultants.
THE city gave the Bridgeport Economic Development Corporation $2.5 million to acquire five parcels on the block by eminent domain: Read's; the hotel and arcade; a vacant parcel; a small parking lot; and the Pollock Building, which will be demolished. Ownership of Read's will be transferred to Artspace for $1 when the conversion is completed.
Two months ago, the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority approved a low-interest mortgage financing loan of $2.74 million and low-income and historic tax credits of $8 million. In addition, more than $540,000 has been raised privately from the Greater Bridgeport Area Foundation, the Bridgeport Special Services District, the Melville Foundation, the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Southern New England Telephone Company, the Culpepper Memorial Foundation, the Edward C. Moore Foundation and United Illuminating. Bridgeport Economic Development expects to supply final designs and construction pricing within six to eight months, enabling the tax-credit deals to be closed. Meanwhile, environmental remediation of asbestos, lead paint and the residue of a colony of pigeons will begin in the fall, Ms. Constant said. 
Read's was considered for artists' housing five years ago by Peter Shapiro, a Hartford banker, and his partners, but the city was not amenable to the idea. Urged to open a similar project in Hartford by his daughter, a singer in Minneapolis who lived in an Artspace building there, Mr. Shapiro and his group found an 84,000-square-foot former factory on Asylum Street. Tai Soo Kim Partners, Hartford architects, renovated the abandoned 1910 building into 43 live-work artists' apartments at a cost of $6.5 million. It opened in 1998 as a for-profit enterprise and is fully rented. 
Based on the Hartford area's median income of $54,858, rents are calculated at 60, 50 and 25 percent of the median. "We get a developer's fee of around 8 to 10 percent of the project cost," Mr. Shapiro said, "and minuscule profits from rents, which we draw on for promoting art exhibitions in the 3,500-square-foot street-floor gallery." 
His second project, in a former 100,000-square-foot factory in Norwich, opened in March and is 90 percent full. Rents, at 60 percent of the median, range from $214 to $775 for one to three bedrooms. Twelve market-rate units out of 58 units are priced from $695 to $925 for one to three bedrooms. 
"We have been approved to proceed in Willimantic," Mr. Shapiro said, "and New Britain has expressed interest." While Artspace of Minneapolis is not directly involved in his ventures, he said, "Artspace serves as a stem cell for all these projects around the country."
In 1989, Sharon T. Griffis, director of the Griffis Art Center in New London, opened Sapphire House, a 1929 private residence that she restored for artists, and a separate building used twice a year when an internationally known artist, writer or composer is invited for a residency. It is equipped with cable, phone, library, computer and other amenities. Sapphire House has 10 one- and two-bedroom apartment-studios, some with 30-foot-long rooms, renting for $450 to $650 a month including utilities. 
The enterprise was financed with about $1 million in private funds, Ms. Griffis said. "We are nonprofit, so we don't pay taxes, and we are self-sustaining through rents, gallery sales and donations," she said. "We haven't had a vacancy for two years."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.; 
In a Nutshell Lies One Firm's Fruit

BYLINE:  By DIANA DRAKE 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
To get to the Cardolite Corporation, you have to navigate this city's manufacturing strip along Doremus Avenue, trundling over railroad tracks, hoping to avoid the misplaced nails and groaning 18 wheelers common to the gritty industrial district.
 Welcome to the nuthouse. 
 Cardolite -- which employs 70 people and has around $20 million in annual sales -- manufactures chemicals derived from the liquid in the shell of a cashew that are used in epoxy, coatings, friction, printing, rubber, wood and specialty polymer industries.
Focused on enhancing and expanding the use of the oil, the company imports about 10,000 tons of nutshell liquid a year, mostly from Brazil and India. Nearly half of Cardolite's business is done overseas -- in Asia and Europe.
"It flowers once a year and after it flowers the fruit comes out," explained Anthony Stonis, who owns Cardolite has been in the business for 16 years. "After the fruit comes out, the seed comes outside it. That's the cashew nut." 
Other than providing a tasty party snack, the nut, or more specifically the oil that surrounds the nut, is a crucial commodity to the specialty chemical industry. The black liquid found between the nut and the cashew shell is known as cashew nutshell liquid in the chemical industry. The unique properties of cashew liquid, which has its roots in New Jersey with a chemist named Mortimer Harvey and a company called Irvington Varnish, make it especially reactive with other chemicals.
Compared with a company like Dupont, which had annual revenues last year of $28.3 billion, Cardolite is one of the smaller businesses. And these days, life is not so easy. "Trying to keep our niche and not be a big company is difficult," Mr. Stonis admitted. "These are very challenging times."
Indeed, the specialty chemical business is often a barometer of the economy in general.
"If the economy gets sick, the specialty guys get a cold first," explained Hal Bozarth, executive director of the Chemical Industry Council of New Jersey, which is based in Trenton.
Mr. Bozarth, whose group is made up of 100 members, said New Jersey had always been home to several specialty chemical companies as against the larger manufacturers, which are situated primarily in Texas and Louisiana.
The specialty chemical business, which employs about 90,000 workers in New Jersey alone, has for last few years been going through what Mr. Bozarth refers to as "a major upheaval" as an increasingly global market has led to more competition.
"You have increased competition and a flat economy," said Mr. Bozarth. "All companies like Tony's are struggling to stay competitive."
In May, for example, Rohm & Haas, a Philadelphia-based chemical company, announced that it planned to close a part of Morton International, a speciality dye and marker producer that had operated in Paterson since 1946, resulting in the loss of 90 jobs.
And the cashew nutshell liquid industry, while highly specialized, has become more crowded in recent years as larger companies like Vantico, a division of Ciba Specialty Chemicals, recognized the profit potential. For the most part, however, Cardolite and Palmer International of Skippack, Pa., dominate the American market, importing the lion's share of the 20,000 tons of liquid produced annually for North America.
While Cardolite supplies much of its chemicals to the epoxy coatings industry for use in the boat-building business, Palmer focuses primarily on friction particles for the automotive sector, though each company at times competes directly with the other in both areas.
Stephen T. Palmer 3rd, chief executive of Palmer International, a family-owned business that employs 100, described Cardolite as well respected in the industry and a leader in the epoxy business. "Global competition has meant tremendous pressure to lower costs," Mr. Palmer said. As for his own business, Mr. Palmer began funneling resources into new product development.
Mr. Stonis, too, emphasized the necessity of research and development. Customers like Vijay Datta, technical director of ICI Devoe Coatings in Cleveland, praised Cardolite's research efforts.
"Nobody has as much in-depth knowledge of the chemistry of nutshell liquid as Cardolite," said Mr. Datta, a pioneer in the development of products using cashew nutshell liquid whose company buys Cardolite's chemicals to make coating for industrial maintenance uses on bridges and storage tanks. "Other people are just catching up to get me-too products."
Still, several years ago Mr. Stonis realized that innovation alone was not enough to stay ahead of the increasing competition in Cardolite's epoxy line.
"When Vantico snagged a major client of ours, the writing was on the wall," said Mr. Stonis. "We decided unless we do something it's a house of cards."
In a risky move, Cardolite significantly lowered its prices in hope of maintaining its lead. As a result, he said, prices are today 60 percent of what they were five years ago.
"We figured if we make these products more competitively priced, more people would switch to them and use them over other technologies," he said. "That has happened, not as much as we hoped, but it has happened."
Life as president of a specialty chemical company has been a series of tough strategic decisions in the past 10 years, none of which has made Mr. Stonis regret the decision he made in 1985 to buy Cardolite from 3M of St. Paul, Minn. At the time Mr. Stonis, a chemical engineer, was managing a plant in Antwerp, Belgium, for Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, for whom he had worked since 1969. Mr. Stonis was eager to move up from plant manager, having lobbied for and missed three promotions as managing director of a 3M subsidiary.
"The message to me was, 'It's over, Tony. This is you. Plant manager for the rest of your life,' " he said.
But Mr. Stonis had other plans. He had worked for 3M's cashew nutshell liquid plant in Newark in the 1970's and saw the potential -- especially for the cashew-derived epoxy curing agent developed by 3M in 1972. When he heard the operation was up for sale he watched the progress, figuring it would be snapped up in months.
After two years passed and the business was still on the market, word began to trickle out that 3M was ready to make a deal with anyone who showed interest. Mr. Stonis stepped forward and, in an example of a leveraged buyout popularized in the 80's, agreed to a deal in which 3M would finance $1 million of the $3 million needed to buy the plant and get it running, and Mr. Stonis would have to find the other $2 million.
After countless rejections Mr. Stonis finally won the ear of Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia. But days before the agreement for a working capital loan was to close in December 1985, a skittish Fidelity Bank said it would only proceed if 3M agreed to a short-term guarantee, which it did.
Suddenly Mr. Stonis had what he had wished for, the top position at a $7 million business with about 50 employees. Now what? Anybody could have done well from 1985 to 1990, admitted Mr. Stonis. The business had a strong market position and lots of momentum.
"We just took orders and made stuff," he said.
But by the early 1990's, Cardolite had to become more aggressive if it was to advance to the next level. Mr. Stonis hired an independent chemical consultant, Tom Hartley, to help him figure out how to expand the business. Mr. Hartley showed Mr. Stonis how to shift his management style from a production and manufacturing role to a more customer-focused approach. In turn, Cardolite has become more market-driven.
These days Mr. Stonis spends about 40 percent of his time traveling to countries like India, Brazil and Vietnam, where the production of cashew nutshell liquid is growing.
"It takes a guy like Tony Stonis to succeed in this industry," observed Mr. Bozarth. "He's on the cutting edge of technology and is always out there looking for new customers. He's much closer to the ground than a Dupont executive would be."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Anthony Stonis, left, owns Cardolite, which uses the liquid in a cashew shell to make specialty chemicals. The company has felt the effects of competition and the economic slowdown, Mr. Stonis said. (Photographs by Emile Wamsteker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS; 
Spirit Quest

BYLINE:  By DAVID CORCORAN; Questions? Comments? Recommendations? E-mail the New Jersey section at njdine@nytimes.com

DATELINE: MILLBURN 

 BODY:
ONE look at its New American menu and its hip, Deco interior, and you can see the kind of restaurant Martini is trying to be. Every town could use one, and Millburn especially so -- not only for its own affluent, food-smart residents but for the before- and after-theater crowds that flock to the Paper Mill Playhouse, a few hundred yards up the road.
 Martini looks out at Main Street through many-paned windows, and it makes a cheery, bustling first impression. You're greeted by an amiable, black-clad host. If you like, she'll steer you to a table in a loud and lively front room dominated by a bar and a big martini glass of blue neon. If you've made a reservation, you'll be taken to a track-lighted dining room where the noise is muted and the focus seems to be on serious food. 
 In either room, the server brings a menu with a long list of martinis apparently named during a terminal attack of the cutes: the Yoohoo-tini, the Woo Woo-tini, the Bellini-tini and many more. Despite their names, these drinks (at least the few we sampled) are hearty and restorative. Unfortunately, things go downhill pretty rapidly from there.
When I first visited Martini, on a Sunday afternoon after a Paper Mill matinee last month, I was pleasantly taken aback by the chef's name on the menu: Pat Kotsonis, who had done a terrific job last year with Maize, the new restaurant near the Performing Arts Center in Newark. And our first appetizer, four big ravioli encasing lobster, scallops, spinach and shiitake mushrooms under a mantle of good tomato sauce, bore the Kotsonis imprint. They were aggressively flavored with tarragon, but the herb didn't obscure the star ingredients. Even the chewy, saffron-scented pasta made a contribution.
But that was the high point of our two visits. Whether or not Mr. Kotsonis was actually in the kitchen that Sunday, nothing else came near the level of those ravioli. And by the time of our second visit, a few weeks later, his name had vanished from the menu. Lee Jorge, a co-owner, told me that Mr. Kotsonis had moved on and that a team of young chefs was now running the kitchen.
If these people are a team, they need to start playing like one. While another appetizer of fried calamari and an entree of crab cakes were both decent if forgettable, the big production number on our first visit -- a special of red snapper over a black-bean salsa -- was a mess. The salsa, with accents of banana, pineapple and red onion, left a pleasant glow, but the fish, dusted with spices and spread with what might have been chipotle mayonnaise, was amazingly devoid of flavor or texture. And pizza and macaroni and cheese, fun food featured on the front-room menu to appeal to diners like the two 15-year-olds in our party, were tough and characterless.
The star of our second visit, this time on a Friday night in the dining room, was the Martini seafood tower, a gigantic martini glass filled with crushed ice, shrimp, raw clams and oysters, and the tail and claw of a small lobster. It looked impressive, even a little daunting, but when we unpacked it, it proved to be mostly glittery promise. Though the clams and oysters were briny and assertive, the shrimp and lobster had a slightly damp texture that suggested time in a freezer. The texture, however, wasn't as troubling as the price: $32 for an appetizer that barely served two. Tuna tartare, more modest and reasonable at $9, was a better choice. 
Steak, at $28 the most expensive of the main courses, delivered the most value. Billed as sirloin aged for 21 days, it lacked the flinty tang of aged beef. But it was generous and well prepared, and the topping of blue cheese and onions held our attention. By contrast, spaghetti primavera had all the excitement of a home economics lesson, a sodden pile of pasta, tomato sauce and miscellaneous vegetables that couldn't be redeemed by its few stalks of fresh, springlike asparagus.
The kitchen's uncertain relationship with seafood was on display in a highly touted special, salmon with blueberry sauce on a cake of wild rice. Blueberries, it turns out, are not a bad foil for salmon; the flavors played off gently against each other, and rosemary and peppercorns supplied distinct accents of their own. Too bad the fish was overcooked and dry. Shrimp and scallops -- again, their texture made me suspect they'd been thawed -- sat atop a pile of "risotto." (The quotation marks are the menu's; it's not clear what they signify, other than gumminess.) 
For dessert, a big plate of fresh and well-chosen berries needed nothing more than sweet whipped cream and a spoon. Fruit soup, served on our first visit but not in evidence on the second, was said to have been infused with 20 herbs; all we could pick out were two spices, clove and cinnamon, and a lot of sugar. Still, it was bracing. 
Chocolate souffle, light and moist, came with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and some fresh raspberries. It was fine, but it would have been finer if the server hadn't delivered its accompaniment of chocolate sauce 10 minutes after the rest of the dessert -- to the wrong, and baffled, diner. Strawberry shortcake benefited from sweet, lemon-scented shortbread, fresh whipped cream and a welcome, unexpected kick of fresh basil and balsamic vinegar. If only the berries had been fresh, rather than macerated and soggy. And lemon tart was a heavy, eggy production that wasn't worth the calories or the $8 price tag. 
Martini is clearly a restaurant in transition, a new place struggling to find its footing against a brace of competitors. It is trying to please a lot of people with a lot of different formulas. Maybe it's trying just a little too hard. If it found a clearer focus, it would find a ready audience.

Martini
40-42 Main Street, Millburn
(973) 376-4444

FAIR

ATMOSPHERE -- Two places at once: a noisy, cheerful barroom and a quieter, slightly somber dining room.

SERVICE -- Agreeable, if sometimes confused.

SMOKING -- Allowed in the bar.

WINE LIST -- Standard. The bar offers a long list of martinis and other spirits, like single-malt Scotches.

RECOMMENDED DISHES -- Lobster ravioli, fried calamari, tuna tartare; sirloin steak; fresh berries, fruit soup, chocolate souffle, strawberry shortcake.

PRICE RANGE -- Appetizers: $6 to $14 ($32 for the seafood tower for two); burgers, pizza and sandwiches: $7 to $12; entrees: $16 to $28; desserts: $5 to $8.

HOURS -- Open daily. Lunch and Sunday brunch: 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. Dinner: 5 to 10 p.m. Late-night menu: Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 10 p.m. to 1:30 a.m.

CREDIT CARDS -- All major cards.

RESERVATIONS -- Recommended for the dining room.

WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- Via a ramp.

RATINGS -- Poor, Fair, Satisfactory, Good, Very Good, Excellent, Extraordinary.

Ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction to food, ambience and service, with price taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.

HEADLINE: PULSE; 
Urban Development

BYLINE:  By Ellen Tien 

 BODY:
This fall, even apartment dwellers on the lowest floors can enjoy views of the New York City skyline at street level, in the form of painted and beaded clothing and accessories, jewelry and, yes, fragrance bottles.
 At Shop Noir, an airbrushed Manhattan collection includes cotton dresses ($300), canvas fisherman hats ($90) and metallic leather handbags ($195) studded with rhinestones and emblazoned with the ultimate urban outline, reminiscent of the graffiti-art craze of the 80's. 
 To achieve a skyline waistline, Olive & Bette offers a black leather belt with a decorated buckle ($250). In a more architectural vein, the bottles for the most recent fragrance lines of DKNY and Christian Dior were both inspired by silhouettes from the city horizon. 
And at Saks Fifth Avenue, the skyline fairly skyrockets, with a $160,000 diamond bangle bracelet by Memoire Paris, a $5,000 necklace by Jennifer Eden Montgomery and a $3,960 beaded wedding gown by Helen Morley, designed to commemorate the opening of her new bridal boutique in the store.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF; 
Forecasting Winner To Receive Pace U. Award

BYLINE:  By Stephanie Rosenbloom 

 BODY:
It may be 18 months before the economy rebounds from the current slowdown, in the view of Maria Fiorini Ramirez. She speaks with authority, as the winner of The Wall Street Journal's forecasting survey for the first half of 2001. 
 Ms. Ramirez, who heads her own consulting firm in Manhattan, is a 1972 graduate of Pace University, which has campuses in Westchester and New York City. In December, she will receive the university's Lubin Alumni Achievement Award. 
 Ms. Ramirez, 51, said she never considered going to college anywhere else. 
"There is no other university as close to the financial center," she said, referring to Pace's Manhattan campus. "If you want to hear the heartbeat of the financial community, Pace is closest to it." Pace was also closest to Ms. Ramirez's home in Brooklyn, enabling her to work and earn her degree and not lose too much time commuting. She graduated in three and a half years with a bachelor's degree in business administration and economics.
Her current economic forecast?
"We are in the grinding stage for the next six months to a year and a half before things get better," she said, predicting that tax revenue at the state and local levels will grow at a slower pace and corporate earnings will begin to rise in the early part of next year. 
Ms. Ramirez lives in New Jersey, but she and her husband have thought about moving to Westchester.
"We almost bought a house in Westchester in the 70's -- and in the 70's I thought it was expensive," she said with a laugh. "Of course, that would have been a good investment!"
 Stephanie Rosenbloom

HEADLINE: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/NONFICTION; 
Corrupt Police, Lunchtime Theater, Latin Ballplayers

 BODY:
A COLD CASE
By Philip Gourevitch
Farrar, Straus & Giroux
($22, hardcover)
 The Four-One precinct, when Rosenzweig started out as a patrolman there, had one of the highest crime rates in the world. "A fun place to work," he said. But he quickly found that many of his colleagues thought it was more fun to let the criminals work for them. The New York City Police Department back then was what he politely called "interesting" -- rife with men who regarded the badge more as a license to corruption than as a bond to public service and who took as their motto the infamous quip attributed to former mayor William O'Dwyer: "A cop who doesn't know how to make a buck out there shouldn't be a cop." 
 It wasn't as if everyone in the Four-One station house was on the take, but Rosenzweig, whose after-tax pay came to $95 a week, heard officers boasting that they collected as much as a thousand dirty dollars a month and that they never spent unpaid overtime hours in court because they hardly ever arrested anyone.

TALK STORIES
By Jamaica Kincaid
Farrar, Straus & Giroux
($23, hardcover)
Just the other day, we tried having our lunch while watching a Theatre at Noon production of Maria Irene Fornes's play "Dr. Kheal" at St. Peter's Church, which is on East 56th Street, and this new way of having lunch was far better than anything else we had tried.
There are two shows put on every weekday -- one at a quarter past 12 and the other at a quarter past one. We took the early show. We got to St. Peter's at noon sharp, taking our lunch along, as we had been given to understand we should do. At the door, we learned that there was no admission charge but that donations were invited. We made out donation, walked in with a sandwich (ham salad) and a soft drink (ginger beer), and hoped for a good time. We got a good time.

MAMBO MONTAGE:
The Latinization of New York
Edited by Agustin Lao-Montes
and Arlene Davila
Columbia University Press
($24.50, paperback)
Despite perceptions of segregation as a Southern phenomenon, New York City staged a significant part of the U.S. segregation drama throughout the 20th-century era of Jim Crow baseball, 1906-1950. More Major League and Negro League organizations called New York City home than any other North American city. Latinos appeared on each of the city's Major League teams before the breaking of baseball's color line in 1947: The New York Yankees, the New York Giants and the Brooklyn Dodgers. 
Their appearance on these teams started with Cuban-born Angel Aragon's brief stint with the Yankees in 1914; players such as Adolfo Luque, Miguel Angel Gonzalez and Jose Rodriguez followed during the 1910's. Latinos' first regular participation in black baseball circuits occurred in 1906 with the appearance of the Cuban Stars.
Over the nest four decades, Latinos appeared on several Negro League clubs that called New York City home: the Brooklyn Royal Giants, the Lincoln Giants, the Cuban Stars, the New York Black Yankees and the Brooklyn Eagles -- which moved to Newark after the 1935 season. Home of these different big league clubs, New York City served as a primary point of entry for Latinos into North American professional baseball.
Upon examination, the history of the New York Cubans and the social interactions of Latinos in Harlem unveil the manner in which the "Latins from Manhattan" were exposed to the social and economic realities of race and segregation in a northern city. . . .
Harlem was home to not just African-Americans but also Antiguans, Trinidadians, Puerto Ricans, Dominicans and Cubans. . . . Together they forged an "intra-racial ethnic community" that served as a creative center for black culture. In writing Harlem's poetry or stories, as did Countee Cullen or James Baldwin; . . . collecting black cultural artifacts, as did bibliophile Arturo (Arthur) Schomburg; or playing professional baseball, as did Rodolfo "Rudy" Fernandez, Harlemites blurred the binary notion of home and diaspora.

LIVING AT THE EDGE
OF THE WORLD: A Teenager's Survival in the Tunnels
of Grand Central Station
By Tina S. and Jamie Pastor Bolnick
St. Martin's Press
($24.95, hardcover)
After a few days in Bellevue I'm starting to feel really good. My arm still hurts and I still have the infection, but my stomach is getting used to being full again, I'm rested, my mind is clear of drugs.
It's kind of enlightening. Because when you're living with crack you're oblivious to everything but crack and how to get it. And when you've been off it three or four days, you start seeing things around you, taking in everything that's happening. Things that other people take for granted. Eggs and toast in the morning, and how good ice water tastes when you're thirsty. A funny show on TV that makes you laugh. Something nice a nurse says. Hot showers and feeling clean all over.
It's like somebody's pulled off your blinders. You see the sun come up, you see the sun go down. You know there are days and then nights and then days again, it's not all one long day until you come down off your binge.
