HEADLINE: Hope Comes In Peaks And Valleys; 
Artist's View of New Haven Preceded Changing Times

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
In the late 1970's, right around the time that the Armstrong tire factory was closing down, the last movie flickered onto the screen at the Bowl Drive-In a few miles away on Route 1. In a single, cold gust of change, Gene Wells lost both his tire-making job and his family's hallowed tradition of drive-in movie night -- no more work on the tire line, no more evenings with the kids piled into the car in their pajamas. It was the end of an era. 
 More than 20 years later the abandoned screen of the Bowl still stands -- listing a bit as the weeds grow around it, but enduring nonetheless. And Mr. Wells endures as well. After Armstrong, he landed a job at Yale University, as a custodial services manager. His is the matter-of-fact voice of a man who has seen the hard things that life can sometimes dish up. 
 "I liked it," he said of his job as a tire builder. "But then they closed up, and when they close up you got to go." 
The Northeast is celebrated for the cycle of its seasons: flaming fall foliage, deep-woods winterscapes, dense green springs and languorous summers when the humidity thickens every breath. But times changed here in a way that was linked more to the human presence than the hand of nature. In a place where an artist once stood, a city flowered, and then fell.
The precise spot where Frederic Edwin Church set up his easel in 1849 is not known -- the closest approximation today is atop a former landfill that did not exist back then. The Boston Post Road, which later became Route 1, was the main thoroughfare, and the field where the Bowl would one day rise was a few hundred yards away. Church, who was still on his way to fame as a Hudson River School artist when he stopped by New Haven, showed farmers bringing in their hay -- a picture of hardy economic independence and optimism against the backdrop of ancient stone. It was summer and the nation was young.
Within 25 years of Church's visit, New Haven had tripled in size, and dozens of factories had sprung up, pushing out the farms. The Elm City, as it was called then, specialized in fine mechanical work -- clocks, locks, carriages and guns. But then the factories themselves mostly departed. Things like slaughterhouses, breweries, rubber plants, scrap yards and landfills took over the Route 1 corridor, called Allingtown.
West Rock remained unchanged in the distance, and the West River -- the foreground of Church's painting -- continued its meandering way to Long Island Sound. Allingtown became an economic and urban borderland.
Mr. Wells, 63, the son of a Caribbean sugar worker who came to New Haven in the early 1920's, grew up in a time that had a similar borderland quality. The great black migration from the South had only begun. Manufacturing jobs were ample, but times were still hard. His father, Al Wells, who was born on the island of Nevis, got work as a cook.
Gene Wells said his grandchildren just laugh when he tells them about how he and his friends would get a new $2 pair of sneakers and wear them until the word "Keds" had become simply "ed," and how they would then put cardboard inside to cover the holes and make the shoes last even longer. 
Bicycles were an important part of growing up then, Mr. Wells said, and he would sometimes ride with his friends to the summit of West Rock, just to stand for a few minutes and look out over their city. 
"Sometimes in the summertime at night everybody would be riding their bikes," he said. "Your bike was a big thing: polished chrome fenders, chrome wheels, and -- what do you call them? -- streamers on the handlebars."
No one he knew then could actually afford a new bike, he said, and so part of the game was building one from parts you could trade or find. "You'd get the wheels from somebody, and hopefully you had a frame with a handlebar so you didn't have to worry about finding that," he said.
Mr. Wells's father worked for a time at Yale University, cooking in one of the residence halls. And it was at Yale after Gene started working there, too, in 1981, that he stumbled upon the Frederic Church painting, copies of which can be found, he said, in various places around campus. He recognized the view, he said, from his bike rides as a child -- somewhere around the Orange Avenue Bridge between New Haven and West Haven. 
He was also pursuing a new hobby then, photography. So one day he drove to the bridge, took his camera and snapped his own view of West Rock, more or less like the painting. Mr. Wells is modest about his hobby, though. He keeps his photos in a drawer and it was only just this summer that his wife, Dorothy, finally persuaded him to replace the 20-year-old camera that he had complained about for years.
"She kept saying, 'Get yourself a new camera, get yourself a new camera,' and I'd say, 'It's not the camera, it's the photographer,' " he said.
Getting to know his new Nikon, shooting pictures in his yard, is now the project for the fall days ahead, he said.

The Outlook Is Bleak
Just south of the landfill hilltop that offers Church's West Rock view there is an automobile salvage yard called Classic Used Auto Parts, which has been in business under various names and owners for about 50 years. It is a place of hard edges and ancient rust. A mountain of tires dominates one edge of the property. Cars in various states of cannibalization squat behind a metal fence. 
Classic is a hectic, old-fashioned business where prices are shouted from behind the counter for a set of hubcaps or a rebuilt transmission, and dickering after that is the accepted norm. One of the employees goes shirtless, the better perhaps to display his piercings and tattoos. Burglaries are a chronic problem, said Tony DeLucia, who took over the place several years ago. 
Mr. DeLucia, a former antiques dealer, sees a long winter ahead for New Haven. He said he held out some hope that a recent effort, led by Yale, to recast the city's image as Connecticut's arts and culture capital could bring more tourists, and there has been talk for years about an emerging biotechnology industry. But none of those things, he said, can offer much comfort to the low-income people who are his core customers. New Haven has lost about 25 percent of its population since 1950, when it peaked at 164,000, according to census figures.
"I don't see the long-term outlook in terms of opportunity for the less fortunate to be any greater with what's going on," he said. "Culture doesn't offer much and high tech doesn't either, unless you've got a degree. Let's face it, the only kind of jobs that low-skilled people are going to get are manufacturing jobs and things like that, and manufacturing is a dead issue."
Mr. DeLucia's father, also known as Tony (technically, the father is Antonio and the son is Anthony), has an even more bleak view.
The elder Tony, 66, a retired construction crane operator who grew up in the city, the youngest son of an Italian immigrant who sold fruits and vegetables from a pushcart, said he had long since given up all hope about New Haven coming back to anything the way he remembers it. Not that the city or its political leaders are to blame, he said -- all small cities are in the same pickle.
"There may be an answer out there," said Mr. DeLucia, who comes by the shop most days to help his son, or just to sit a while. "But I don't know of it. Almost every city this size seems to have great ideas to try and turn it around, but it never works. It never works."
Down on Route 1, car washes, auto-detailing shops and fast-food places fill the spaces between vacant lots. A statue commemorates the Battle of New Haven during the Revolutionary War, when residents burned the bridge over the West River to keep the British from crossing. (The soldiers simply went around, crossed the river near West Rock, and took the city anyway.)
Historians say the old Post Road, although still a major artery through the area, was a fading presence in Church's day, too. Steamships and railroads were making the rutted road a means of last or cheapest resort. The inns and taverns that had grown up to serve the commercial travelers of earlier days were doomed.

The Outlook Is Bright
The string that had been lying lax on the water suddenly went taut. That meant a crab had locked its claws onto the piece of chicken somewhere down in the river, and that in turn put into motion a little family minuet of coordination and patience.
Ismael Castro was on string duty. Gently, hand over hand, he pulled the string in -- too fast and the crab would let go, he said; too slow, and it would get dragged on the bottom and fall off.
Bernice Velez stood waiting, stooped over with her net extending a few inches above the river.
The moment of truth came when the crab got close enough to see -- close enough that the chicken chunk was about to scrape on the mud. That was when Ms. Velez played her part -- a quick swooping capture with the net.
This was how the Castros -- Ismael and his three children -- and Ms. Velez, his fiancee, were spending a week's mid-August vacation: crabbing on the West River a mile from their house in West Haven.
It was not fancy and it cost almost nothing, but everyone seemed to be having a ball. The muddy brown creek just north of the Orange Avenue Bridge -- the foreground of Church's painting -- was their playground.
Partly, Ms. Velez said, the fun came from mastering something new. They moved to the New Haven area only a year ago from Danielson in Connecticut's northeast corner. They had never gone crabbing until this summer. Everything, she said, still felt fresh.
When they fumbled and lost a crab, as they often did, they could laugh about it.
"We decided to start something new, to take a chance," said Ms. Velez, referring to their relocation to New Haven. "And it's the best move I've ever made."
Mr. Castro, 32, was born in Puerto Rico and was living in Brooklyn when he and Ms. Velez, 39, who grew up in Manhattan, met in an Internet chat room about 18 months ago. She was already living in Connecticut then, and he joined her in Danielson before they moved here.
Now they are planning a wedding next year at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Manhattan, where Mr. Castro works as a facilities coordinator, setting up for the jazz performances and services that have made the church famous.
Part of what brought them to New Haven, they said, was its cultural and ethnic diversity. Northeastern Connecticut, though it was pretty and green, was not right for them. Ms. Velez's 17-year-old daughter, Chasitie Cruz, started floundering in school. There was a racial tension in the air, and at least once she had the letters "KKK" scrawled on her locker.
Ms. Velez, who works as a cashier in a local shop, said that Chasitie wants to go to Yale someday.
But Chasitie said that for now, she was just happy to be here. School has become a welcoming place again, she said, thanks in part to a great guidance counselor. She has a job she likes in the evenings at a family arcade.
If she should get into Yale to study social work or psychology, her two main interests at the moment, that would be great.
If not, she will look for another option, she said. Her life and hope are intertwined, and perhaps, in that link, there is hope for old New Haven, too. 
"I see a lot of opportunities," she said.

In Art's Footsteps
The paintings of the Hudson River School are portraits of the Northeast, captured at a time when 19th-century America was re-examining its ideas about nature. The landscapes helped spur tourism and environmentalism. 
This is the ninth of 10 summer articles in which The New York Times returns to the places illuminated by Hudson River School artists.
The final article, from Catskill, N.Y., will look at the power of an artistic vision. Thomas Cole, painting from underneath Kaaterskill Falls, created a reverent new vocabulary of how the natural world should be considered. But at the same time, he helped turn nature into a commercial product. He painted the wilderness, but perhaps his greatest impact was on the city where his art was sold: New York. His legacy lives on, but it's more complicated and ambivalent than he might have imagined.
The articles and additional materials are available on the Web:
www.nytimes.com/nyregion

HEADLINE: And Not a (Free) Drop to Drink 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Ted C. Fishman ("A Simple Glass of Water," Op-Ed, Aug. 23) laments the replacement of free tap water with costly bottled water throughout the United States. This is a global phenomenon. 
International financial institutions and multinational corporations are pushing privatization plans that transform water from a common resource available to all into a commodity for purchase. 
 The result: low-income communities around the world are forced to seek water from polluted and untreated sources, leading to needless deaths from waterborne diseases.
For these reasons, international human rights law recognizes the right to water as an essential component of the rights to life and health. Government and business should also recognize that the right to safe drinking water must neither be bought nor sold.

JULIAN LIU
Brooklyn, Aug. 23, 2001

The writer is communications associate, Center for Economic and Social Rights.

HEADLINE: Huge Default Unsettles Turkish Economic Reform Efforts 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
A local company owes a huge debt to Motorola, and the dispute is threatening to disrupt Turkey's efforts to restore foreign confidence in its economy.
 Motorola, the American wireless technology giant, is getting help from the American government and former senior American officials to try to collect a $2 billion debt from the Turkish company, Telsim, the country's No. 2 cellular phone company. Telsim is owned by a Turkish family whose fortune has been battered by the nation's economic problems. 
 The loan helped Telsim buy Motorola products, but Motorola says the Turkish company has been in default since June. Telsim also missed a payment on a $719 million loan from Nokia, the Finnish technology company. 
Marc Grossman, under secretary of state for political affairs and a former ambassador to Turkey, and the American embassy in Ankara raised the issue with Turkish government officials, according to an American official. 
The official described the contacts as routine. The matter is sensitive, however, because Turkey is a NATO member and ally whose economy has been battered for seven months.
The International Monetary Fund and World Bank have pledged $17 billion in emergency loans to Turkey and the Bush administration has praised its efforts to adopt financial reforms and attract new capital from foreign investors and lenders. The steps are viewed as essential to the country's economic and political stability. 
But financial analysts cautioned Turkey's recovery effort could be damaged if the Turkish government appears unable to protect foreign investors like Motorola and Nokia in a private commercial disagreement.
Along with getting administration help, Motorola enlisted two former senior officials and a prominent investigative agency, people involved in the business dispute said.
One of the former officials was identified as Brent Scowcroft, national security adviser in the first Bush administration. Mr. Scowcroft, a consultant in Washington who has worked for Motorola in the past, is chairman of the American-Turkish Council, an influential business group. 
The other is Mark Parris, American ambassador to Turkey until last September when he joined a Washington law firm. Mr. Parris is in Turkey now to discuss the matter with business and government officials, the people involved said.
Kroll Associates, an investigative agency based in New York City, was hired to look into the assets of the Uzan family, which owns privately held Telsim and about 100 other businesses.
Attempts to reach Telsim officials and Uzan family members were unsuccessful. A spokesman for Motorola said the company was pursuing all of its options in attempting to collect the loan, but declined to discuss specifics. 
The Turkish government has not discussed the dispute officially. A senior official said the government was concerned about potential fallout among foreign investors and hopes that Telsim will begin making payments.
Telsim paid the government $500 million for the cellular phone license in 1998. Motorola and Nokia lent money to Telsim to buy telephone handsets and other equipment from them. The collateral was mainly Telsim shares.
Motorola's problems became public last month when The Financial Times reported that Telsim missed a $728 million payment in April. Motorola said it had demanded that the entire $2 billion be repaid and Telsim had refused.
The American company said Telsim also violated its contract by issuing new shares that diluted Motorola's collateral from 66 percent of Telsim to 22 percent. Nokia stopped supplying equipment to Telsim after it said the company failed to repay $240 million on a $719 million loan.
The Uzan family's wealth was estimated at $1.6 billion by Forbes magazine earlier this year, though many sectors in which it has interests have been hurt by the economic decline. In addition to Telsim, the family owns banks, media properties and companies in the cement, steel, energy and construction industries.
When private investigators began examining the family's assets this summer, the Uzans filed civil suit in Turkish court. The suit demanded the detention of executives from Motorola and Nokia, claiming that the investigators had caused security problems for the family. A person close to Motorola said that the tactics were legal and routine and that the suit had not been pursued.
The Uzan family has been in a dispute since 1994 with Turkey's Capital Markets Board, which regulates its financial markets. The board accused the Uzans of transferring assets from two publicly traded electricity generators they controlled to their other businesses.
The family has denied the charges, which have not been resolved.

HEADLINE: White House Notebook; 
Bush Ventures Off Ranch to Court Steelworkers

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WEST MIFFLIN, Pa., Aug. 26 

 BODY:
It takes a lot to lure President Bush off his beloved Texas ranch as his working vacation dwindles to a close, and with it the end of morning intelligence briefings on the front porch and hours of work on the project that has consumed his summer, using a chain saw to create a path to his favorite canyon, a cathedral in stone that is one of the most distinctive features of his ranch.
 But today, with less than a week remaining at Crawford, Mr. Bush flew here to the Irvin Works, the core of the old United States Steel Corporation, now part of USX, to picnic with steelworkers and tinker with his other summer project: taking back a base of voters who have traditionally gone Democratic. 
 So there was Mr. Bush, eating barbeque with union leaders who last fall had pictures of Al Gore on their walls in a state that Mr. Bush lost, talking about the crisis that is again engulfing the American steel industry. All around him were the steelworkers, pressing Mr. Bush to speed ahead with an investigation that could result in large, protective duties on steel from countries accused of "dumping" their products in the American market. 
That decision is largely out of Mr. Bush's hands: It must be made by the International Trade Commission, an independent agency. Still, Mr. Bush knew just what workers wanted to hear: that he would act later this year to block foreign imports of "dumped" steel, which the industry and the union blame for the loss of 20,000 jobs in 18 months. The workers noted that Mr. Bush, by beginning the action against Japan, Korea, Russia and other nations, had already pressed the issue further than President Bill Clinton did -- though during the boom years of the Clinton administration the mill that loomed behind Mr. Bush today was running at capacity.
"Today we're running at 40 percent of capacity and losing $41 million a year," said Ross W. McClellan, the president of the local chapter of the United Steelworkers of America, who sat next to Mr. Bush at the picnic. Mr. Bush, Mr. McClellan said, "made an impression that he is going to help us." That was just the impression Mr. Bush wanted to make, just as he wanted to avoid saying he would support legislation in Congress that would cut off many foreign steel imports and possibly violate international trade laws. (He also skipped his traditional paean to free trade -- those are fighting words in this part of Pennsylvania.) So Mr. Bush hailed the once mighty United States Steel Corporation, formed by J. Pierpont Morgan a century ago (the ostensible reason for today's celebration) and told the workers that even if the cold war was over, they still manned the economic and military ramparts.
"If you're worried about the security of the country and you become overreliant on foreign sources of steel, it can easily affect the capability of our military to be well-supplied," Mr. Bush said. The company said he was the first president to visit a steel mill in three decades.

So He's Not Babe Ruth
There was another reason for Mr. Bush's visit to Pennsylvania today: He is the first president inducted into the Little League's equivalent of the Hall of Fame. Then again, he appears to be the first president who ever played Little League baseball. The honor came as Mr. Bush attended the Little League World Championship in South Williamsport.
"I qualified by the fact that I was the first president ever to play Little League baseball," he told reporters last week, conceding that perhaps that did not put him on par with the "first guy to hit 60 home runs," a guy named Babe. Then again, the Babe never made the leap from the stadium to leader of the world's unchallenged superpower.
"What the heck?" Mr. Bush said. "What's the difference?"

Meanwhile, at the Ranch
The game was not even over when Mr. Bush and his wife headed back to the ranch. And anyone who dropped by on Saturday morning and saw him cutting up dead trees with a small chain saw, would immediately understand his rush to get home.
"I'm in my element here," Mr. Bush told some visiting reporters on a recent morning. And to hear his aides talk, the mix of meetings and trailblazing not only makes him happier, but also helps him focus on his work.
He met Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, military and national security leaders for six hours on Friday afternoon, without interruption, without schedulers, without members of Congress in the waiting room.
One of Mr. Bush's closest aides said, "We can get far more done here than in the White House," taking the White House message that the president is not on vacation, he is just not in Washington to a new level. C.I.A. briefings are on the porch, overlooking an artificial lake that Mr. Bush had dug so he could go bass fishing. More than a few conferences take place during hikes.
He is even eating differently, except for the kielbasa at the steelworkers' picnic. One consumer of the ranch cuisine reports that Mr. Bush and his wife, Laura, have used the summer to move to a low-fat diet: "There's less Mexican food on the table," the insider reports. The workday is shorter, "but much more conducive to real discussion" about budget strategy, Vladimir V. Putin's negotiating strategy and an upcoming trip to China.
Mr. Bush revels in the fact that the Secret Service lets him drive his own car on the ranch, which is strictly forbidden back in Washington at his other house. "I love to get in the pickup truck with my dogs as the sun is setting, go look for game," he reports. He shoots doves, he said, but he draws the line there. "I don't want to shoot the turkeys. I like turkeys." His dog Barney, a small terrier that a reporter once mistook for a black throw rug, is a happy hunter as well. Barney has spent the summer perfecting his skills at an old Texas sport: chasing armadillos, which burrow in Mrs. Bush's new gardens.
Barney clearly has no interest in going back to Washington on Thursday, and Mr. Bush does not sound markedly more enthusiastic. "We like living in the White House," he told a reporter who asked if he dreaded the return. Then, he began waxing philosophic again about the canyon to which he was clearing his trails, saying the spot brought him inner peace -- of a sort.
"It's a wonderful spot to come up in here and just kind of think about the budget," Mr. Bush said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush using a chain saw to cut up a dead tree on his Texas ranch on Saturday. "I'm in my element here," Mr. Bush has said. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. READY TO END SANCTIONS ON INDIA TO BUILD ALLIANCE 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is moving on a broad front to strengthen relations with India, a nation it views as a neglected and potentially important strategic ally and trading partner in Asia. 
 The most dramatic step the administration will take, officials say, is the almost certain lifting of American economic and military sanctions imposed on India in 1998 for its test of a nuclear weapon. 
 Senior administration officials say Congress will be asked to lift the sanctions when it returns next month. Some of the most senior legislators, including the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, favor the move. 
Senator Biden said in an interview that he had sent a letter to President Bush last week expressing his support and indicating that the sanctions could be removed in time for a possible meeting between Mr. Bush and Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, in New York in late September. Mr. Bush is also planning a visit to India early next year. 
The sanctions were symbolic as much as practical, the officials said. Lifting them now would remove a significant irritant to closer ties. But it would also signal that the United States -- after being surprised and chagrined by India's nuclear test three years ago -- had little choice but to accept that India, the second most populous nation, had elbowed its way into the nuclear club. 
The reversal is not as awkward as it might once have been, given the administration's own opposition to a nuclear-test-ban treaty and its desire to build a missile shield against what it increasingly seems to regard as the inevitable spread of missile technology and weapons of mass destruction. 
In short, as one official said, the United States had to face the fact that India was a nuclear power and that "the genie could not be put back in the bottle." 
One senior official said the administration was also likely to ask Congress to lift some sanctions against India's neighbor and rival, Pakistan, which detonated its own nuclear weapon in a tit-for-tat test just weeks after India did. But Senator Biden said he was not prepared to go along with the request for Pakistan, which has since come under military rule. 
In the most direct explanation of the administration's position, Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, told an audience in New Delhi earlier this month, "The United States wants to treat India realistically for what it is -- a major country and an emerging power. 
"We want to engage India in a strategic dialogue that encompasses the full range of global issues," he added. "The United States appreciates that India's influence clearly extends far beyond South Asia."
Mr. Zoellick, the first member of President Bush's cabinet to visit India, said Washington wanted to work with India on fighting terrorism and the spread of nuclear weapons, promoting human rights and protecting the environment.
He also urged India to drop its resistance to the start of a new round of trade talks by the World Trade Organization, in Doha, Qatar, in October. India's strong voice on behalf of developing countries contributed to the breakdown of the last round, in Seattle in 1999. 
Another high-ranking Bush official, Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage, said this month in Sydney, Australia: "India is a nuclear power. There are a lot of reasons we ought to engage with India, and we're going to."
Mr. Armitage noted that the Indian-American population in the United States was "very high-tech oriented, very organized, very politically astute, a very helpful" factor in American politics. 
In urging the lifting of sanctions, senior Bush officials said, they are not seeking a quid pro quo. They say the end of sanctions will itself produce a closer dialogue and, for example, possibly lead India to tighten its controls on the manufacture of material for nuclear weapons. 
The sanctions bar military exports to India and any exports to companies believed to be connected to India's nuclear program. Lifting them now would open the way for joint military operations and the sale of nonnuclear weapons technology to India. 
The warming trend toward India, which led a nonaligned movement during the cold war and had friendly relations with the Soviet Union and now Russia, is not new. A visit by President Clinton to India in 2000 went a long way toward breaking down years of mistrust. But Mr. Clinton's efforts to improve ties were complicated by India's nuclear test. 
During his presidential campaign, Mr. Bush spoke of India as an important but needlessly ignored country, and praised the Indian-American community, one of the wealthiest in the United States and one that includes generous donors to congressional campaigns. 
In particular, officials said, the Bush administration is pleased by India's openness to what has become the president's major foreign policy goal: missile defense. 
During a visit in April, the Indian foreign and defense minister, Jaswant Singh, was invited for a surprise tete-a-tete with President Bush. Officials said Mr. Singh was sympathetic to key elements of the administration's missile plan, even though some experts have warned that a shield could set off an arms race across Asia if China builds up its arsenal in response. 
But the deputy secretary, Mr. Armitage, and others went out of their way to declare that the relaxation toward India was not motivated by a desire to create a counterweight to China. "Whenever you try to establish a relationship with a country which is based on a third country, then you're doomed to failure," he said. 
Senator Biden agrees. "I don't view this as playing India off China," he said. "There are all kinds of reasons to treat them as they are -- a great nation." 
Indeed, India and the United States share a potentially broad range of security interests, particularly given India's location on the Subcontinent, which bridges the Far East and the Islamic world. 
Both nations have an interest in countering Islamic extremism, particularly in Pakistan, which New Delhi and Washington have each accused of receiving weapons technology from China. India has also accused Pakistan of supporting Islamic militants in disputed Kashmir. 
And though its relations with Beijing have slowly improved, New Delhi has long been conscious of the need to balance against China, which the United States sees a fast-emerging strategic rival in the Pacific. 
In the long term, strategic planners preparing for China's expanding military presence see a new friendliness between the United States and India as potentially very helpful. Among the top American officials to visit India in recent months was Gen. Henry H. Shelton, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. 
"How much do we care about India, qua India, or because it's close to China?" asked George R. Perkovich, an arms expert at the W. Alton Jones Foundation, a philanthropic group based in Charlottesville, Va., who has written extensively about India, suggesting that China was indeed on the administration's mind as it thinks about India. 
In addition, both India and the United States have expressed an interest in reducing tensions over Kashmir, over which India and Pakistan have had several military conflicts. With the addition of nuclear weapons to the region, Mr. Clinton said, the Subcontinent had become "the most dangerous place in the world." 
By lifting the sanctions on India, Senator Biden said, the United States would be "setting an example for Pakistan," a reference to India's relatively good behavior on selling nuclear-related materials to other countries. Pakistan has a poorer record, administration officials said. 
The United States has also been frustrated by Pakistan's inability to restore a democratic government since Gen. Pervez Musharraf took power in a coup in 1999, and India's place as the largest democracy dovetails neatly with Washington's interest in promoting democracy abroad. 
Aware of the possibility of creating an "India only" policy, however, American officials said Pakistan, a strong ally in the 1980's, should not be relegated to the dust heap. "This is not an either/or game with Pakistan," one senior official said. 
In particular, officials acknowledged that Washington does not want to alienate Pakistan for fear of encouraging Islamic extremists there or giving them reason to strengthen ties to the fundamentalist Taliban government in Afghanistan. 
"The United States is not interested in Pakistan becoming more under the influence of Afghanistan," said Mr. Armitage. "There has to be a way out for Pakistan. We're going to play an effective role." 
While officials said the administration would seek to remove the sanctions imposed on Pakistan in 1998 because of its nuclear tests, other sanctions -- including those imposed after General Musharraf's coup -- would remain in place.
Finally, officials said, the administration sees India as an enticing trade partner, but one that must do much more to reform its economy. Mr. Zoellick urged India to do so, noting that the United States was responsible for 15 percent of India's international trade. 
"You will not be surprised if I observe that the emerging strategic relationship between our two great democracies will not be resilient and growing if we fail to draw our economies closer together," he said. "I am seeking close governmental cooperation on trade -- bilaterally and for the global trading system." 
Mr. Bush has appointed a new ambassador in India, Robert D. Blackwill, to cultivate ties. Mr. Blackwill was one of a handful of close foreign policy advisers, known as the Vulcans, who guided Mr. Bush during his presidential campaign. Moreover, Mr. Blackwill was the boss of Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, when they both served on the National Security Council for the president's father.

HEADLINE: Sales of Existing Homes Fell 3% in July 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
Americans bought fewer previously owned homes in July, the National Association of Realtors reported today. But the level of sales remained strong, suggesting that the housing market will continue to be a pillar of support for the struggling economy.
 Existing-home sales fell 3 percent in July from the previous month, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.17 million. 
 Even with the decline, economists said sales in July were solid and noted that existing-home sales had been hovering near record levels in recent months.
"Existing-home sales faded a touch in July, but don't even think that is an indicator that the housing market is finally starting to tank," Joel Naroff, an economist at Naroff Economic Advisors, said. "The level of activity can be unambiguously characterized as very strong."
And with mortgage rates now below 7 percent, the outlook for sales continues to be bright, economists said.
Last week, the government reported that sales of new homes surged 4.9 percent in July.
In today's report, economists said the drop in existing-home sales reflected the fact that some prospective buyers were put off by the choppy economy and felt insecure about their jobs in light of mounting layoffs that have been announced over the last several months.
"Psychologically, there's some impact when people are thinking about trading up and buying a house," said David Lereah, the association's chief economist.
Though July's sales pace of 5.17 million was the lowest level this year, it was 7.3 percent higher than the 4.82 million sales rate in July 2000.
By region, sales fell 8.9 percent in the West, to a rate of 1.33 million in July. In the South, sales declined 1.9 percent, to a rate of 2.07 million, and in the Midwest they edged down 1.8 percent, to a rate of 1.12 million. But in the Northeast, sales rose 3.2 percent, to a rate of 650,000.
The drop in overall sales in July pulled prices down a bit from the previous month. The median existing-home sales price, meaning half sold for more and half for less, dipped to $150,800 in July from $152,200. But prices were up 5.2 percent from July 2000.
In June, sales of previously owned homes slipped to a rate of 5.33 million, but that matched the fifth-highest level on record, registered in December 1998.
The biggest reason the housing market has held up well during the economic slowdown is because mortgage rates have been low.
In July, the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 7.13 percent, down from 7.16 percent in June and well below the 8.15 percent posted in July 2000. Last week, mortgage rates dipped to 6.91 percent.
"This is providing opportunities for first-time buyers who are fundamental to the overall health of the housing market," said Richard Mendenhall, president of the real estate group.

HEADLINE: No. 2 Official at I.M.F. Offers a Bleak Forecast 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
The world economy is skirting the edge of a recession, harmed by Japan's predicted contraction and the rapid slowing of the United States economy, the International Monetary Fund's No. 2 official said today.
 The significant slowdown is exacting a toll on emerging-market economies like Turkey and Argentina that are trying to recapture investor confidence and pull out of their own recessions, the official, Stanley Fischer, said. 
 "We might well escape what you'd call a global recession," said Mr. Fischer, who is retiring as the I.M.F.'s deputy managing director this week. "But it's very, very uncomfortable, and it's particularly hard on growing and emerging-market countries." 
The I.M.F. has recently downgraded its outlook for three of the world's five largest economies: Japan, Germany and France. Many private forecasters have also warned that the world outlook has dimmed in recent weeks.
Mr. Fischer's assessment echoes the negative tone of the recent I.M.F. reports.
The fund warned that the dollar might be in for a sharp depreciation because of an unsustainable trade imbalance of 4.5 percent of gross domestic product. And it kept its forecast for growth in the United States this year at 1.5 percent, down from 5 percent last year.
The fund also cut its forecast for Japan, saying its economy would now contract 0.2 percent this year, instead of expanding 0.5 percent as predicted in April.
The I.M.F. last month also lowered its growth outlook for Germany this year to 1.25 percent from its forecast of 1.9 percent in April, a sign that the global economic decline is lasting longer than the fund expected when it said earlier this year that the world economy would expand 3.2 percent.
Critics of the I.M.F. say that the simultaneous fall in Europe, Japan and the United States shows the negative effect of global integration of trade and capital.
Today, Mr. Fischer played down the importance of those criticisms while saying the rules of the flow of global finance need to be reworked to reduce volatility.
"We need to work on reducing volatility in capital flows to emerging markets, and we are working on that," he said. One way to do that, he said, is to change the international rules guiding the flow of capital.
"I would love to find a legal system that is more conducive to helping countries" that cannot afford their debts, he said. "I suspect the fund in the next few years is going to be exploring this issue very, very hard, and I suspect that it's going to be very, very difficult to get agreement on it."
In other remarks, Mr. Fischer said Argentina would most likely get more international aid to help with its plan to swap some of its $130 billion in debt for safer, lower-cost securities.
The I.M.F., which agreed to an $8 billion bailout of Argentina last week, has pledged to speed up $3 billion in payments to encourage a bond swap or buyback.
"I don't think $3 billion is the end of the story," Mr. Fischer said. "They will need more than we're providing."
Mr. Fischer also said Argentina's policy makers must fulfill a pledge to cut out new borrowing to emerge from its current crisis with its credit intact.
"Everybody wants to see whether they can implement it," he said. "The pressure is on."
Mr. Fischer dismissed suggestions that the country would be better off defaulting to emerge from under its current debt crisis, as many independent analysts have counseled. That would destroy investors' faith in Argentina, he warned.
Defaulting "is not something that doesn't cause a huge mess," he said.
"There is no clean way to do it," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Toyota puts music at the center of a big cross-media campaign built around the 2002 Camry.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THEY say music hath charms to soothe a savage breast, but hath it charms to stimulate additional sales in a cloudy economic climate for an already popular automobile?
 That's the $160 million question being posed by Toyota Motor Sales USA and its agency, Saatchi & Saatchi Los Angeles, as they ready what they are calling the largest campaign in the 43 years Toyota has been in the American market. The campaign -- involving artists as diverse as Lyle Lovett; Earth, Wind and Fire; John Lennon; and the Go-Gos -- will peddle the 2002 version of the Camry, the bread-and-butter Toyota midsize sedan that has been the nation's top-selling passenger car for the last four years. 
 The campaign is indicative of the intensification of efforts to sell products in competitive categories like automobiles as consumers demonstrate increasing reluctance to spend while the economy sputters. The Japanese-based automakers like Toyota have been maintaining or increasing the size of their marketing budgets -- and have recently been gaining market share at the expense of their American-based rivals. 
A central aspect of the Camry campaign is Toyota's buying of commercial time and advertising space configured in customized packages from three media giants: AOL Time Warner, the Conde Nast Publications division of Advance Publications and the MSN network of Internet services operated by the Microsoft Corporation. The packages include elements that bundle together disparate media properties; the packages at AOL Time Warner, for instance, involve cable television networks, magazines and Web sites.
"We've been trying for a number of years to have the big media conglomerates talk to us as one instead of in pieces," said Steve Sturm, vice president for marketing at Toyota Motor Sales USA in Torrance, Calif., part of the Toyota Motor Company.
"It was a struggle to get them to do that when they had more business than time and space to sell," he added. "Now that the environment is a lot more competitive, the worldwide conglomerates are saying, 'This can be stronger if we put it all together,' and we can have a much bigger launch than we would have if we bought all the segments separately."
The ads appearing in the cross-media packages as well as in the traditional outlets bought one medium at a time are meant to help Toyota cultivate interest among car shoppers who do not usually consider Camry, particularly men in their 30's and 40's, while retaining its traditional appeal to its core buyers, women in their 40's and 50's.
"Music seemed to be the best unifying element, the best way to get to all the different consumer groups," said Scott Gilbert, chief executive at Saatchi & Saatchi Los Angeles, also based in Torrance, the longtime Toyota agency that is part of the Saatchi & Saatchi division of the Publicis Groupe. "I was interviewing people for openings last week -- the market's very much alive out here -- and the first three said, 'I hate country music' and the fourth one said, 'I love country music.' When it comes to music, there's no one answer."
The cross-media parts of the campaign "make Camry feel like it's everywhere, like it's important," Mr. Gilbert said, "like an event, a rock concert, a concert tour."
There's that music thought again.
The music initiatives for the redesigned Camry, carrying the punning theme "Making tracks," include a multimedia enhanced compact disc with songs by artists like Mr. Lovett and the Go-Gos and links to the artists' and Toyota's Web sites; sponsorship of the MTV Video Music Awards and VH1 My Music Awards with the MTV and VH1 divisions of Viacom; an ad insert in seven Conde Nast magazines centered on the compact disc, which will be sold to raise funds for a new Camry Music Education Fund; an ad insert in the Sept. 24 "Music Goes Global" issue of Time magazine, which will also appear in nine other Time Inc. magazines; sponsorship of "Come Together: A Night for John Lennon," a special on the TNT cable network; and sponsorship of music news and feature reports on the "Showbiz Today" and "Showbiz This Weekend" programs on the CNN cable network.
"We've had a couple deals with automakers, but nothing of this magnitude," said Bob Pittman, co-chief operating officer at AOL Time Warner, which owns Time Inc., TNT, CNN and other properties that Toyota is buying for the Camry campaign like the Web sites of Entertainment Weekly, Fortune, Money and People.
One reason, he added, is that "the ability of a media company to provide a complete package, and do the coordination, is increasingly important to advertisers" -- and that was "one of the motivations for the merger" of America Online and Time Warner that formed AOL Time Warner.
As for concerns that cross-media packages concentrate too much power in the hands of a handful of media behemoths, "I don't think anyone these days is too concerned about the concentration of power in the sellers' hands," Mr. Pittman said, laughing. Other advertisers buying cross-media packages from AOL Time Warner include Bank of America, Philips, Qwest, Samsung and Swatch.
The Camry campaign, which will present a new sporty model named Camry SE aimed at the younger, male car buyers, is the first that will feature a revamped Toyota ad theme. "Toyota. Everyday," which lasted for two years, is being replaced by "Get the feeling," echoing the popular "Oh, what a feeling" theme that ran from 1985 to 1989.
"Get the feeling" is intended to "play off the emotional aspect of the new Camry," Mr. Sturm said, adding: "We have a car -- wider, longer, faster, more fun to drive -- that consumers have told us has made them go from needing a Camry to wanting a Camry. From that point of view, we felt we needed to do the launch in an emotional way."
Music, needless to say, stirs emotion, almost as much as did "Toyota. Everyday," which had grammarians debating whether Toyota meant "Every day," for ubiquity and dependability, rather than "Everyday," for ordinary and plebian.
Saatchi & Saatchi executives hope that the Camry campaign, now getting under way, will help damp down widespread speculation in trade publications that Toyota Motor Sales USA is unhappy with the agency's work.
"I don't lose sleep any more" over the speculation, Mr. Gilbert said. "All we can do is do the work, and do it well."

HEADLINE: A Young Heir Has New Plans At Old Company; 
Bill Wrigley Is Aggressive In Meeting Rivals Head-On

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 275 

 BODY:
For 38 years, William Wrigley carrying on a long family tradition dating back to the 1890's -- was in charge of the chewing gum company founded by his grandfather. He was healthy, it seemed, certainly wealthy, and thought to be wise in the way he managed the famously secretive company, the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company. He was expected to lead Wrigley into the new century.
 But in March 1999, when Mr. Wrigley died at the age of 66, the $2 billion business empire was left to the fourth generation of Wrigleys, another William Jr., then a 35-year-old company executive who was largely unknown to investors and Wall Street analysts. Some worried about diluted family ambitions, others simply doubted the young Wrigley was ready to run the company. 
 Yet two years after taking over, the young man, who is known around the headquarters here as Bill Wrigley Jr., is being applauded for aggressively pushing the company to reinvent itself with a host of new products and marketing initiatives. 
After years of stagnant volume growth in the United States, Wrigley -- the maker of Doublemint, Juicy Fruit, Big Red and Winterfresh -- is benefiting from brisk sales of sugarless chewing gums and gaining against its two biggest rivals, the makers of Dentyne and Carefree.
The company is also selling breath mints and gum pellets in the United States for the first time. And in perhaps its boldest venture yet, Wrigley is moving into the health product business by creating a division that aims to use chewing gum as a palatable way to deliver a wide range of remedies to consumers, everything from cold relief to cavity prevention.
Analysts say Mr. Wrigley has become something of a risk taker in a company that long prided itself on being conservative.
"His father said, 'If it ain't broke, don't fix it;' " said one executive whose company works with Wrigley. "The son is, 'It works but let's find a better way.' "
One thing that seemed to be broken was the domestic market for chewing gum, which had been slumping for years. Bill Jr.'s father established his reputation by strongly expanding the international business and following a simple mantra: volume, volume, volume.
Now, the young Wrigley is trying to update the major brands, jazz up the Wrigley advertising and plant the seeds for older Americans to get their over-the-counter drug delivery through chewing gum. The new mantra might be: value, value, value.
"I see my role as taking a late 19th-century company and bringing it into the 21st century with guns blazing," Mr. Wrigley, who has granted only one press interview since becoming chief executive, told Forbes magazine.
The first product to come out of Wrigley's health division is Surpass, an antacid chewing gum that it introduced in February. The company plans to spend close to $50 million over the next year to promote and market Surpass as a chewy and tasty alternative to other antacid products, like Rolaids and Mylanta.
The company is also experimenting with a cold-relief gum in Canada. And this month, Wrigley said it would team up with Procter & Gamble, the maker of Crest toothpaste, to create a chewing gum that would offer added dental benefits.
These moves, and a bold new marketing campaign, seem to have restored confidence in Wrigley. Shares of the company have soared 36 percent in the last year, rebounding from a sharp decline in the months after Mr. Wrigley was appointed. The stock closed yesterday at $50.90, down 8 cents.
"This company has introduced more domestic initiatives this year than in all of the last decade that I've followed them," said John McMillin, a veteran food company analyst at Prudential Securities. "Bill Wrigley's been far more aggressive than I thought he'd be."
Some Wall Street analysts warn that it is still too early to tell whether Wrigley can persuade customers to trust it to deliver a pharmaceutical product. They also say Wrigley faces the prospect of big challenges from the likes of Pfizer, the drug giant that now owns the Dentyne, Chicklets and Trident brands, and Hershey Foods, which recently acquired the Carefree and Bubble Yum brands.
But even the skeptics say that Wrigley is largely unrivaled in the global marketplace.
"Not many companies can say they have 50 percent of the world market, no debt, very high returns and that kind of brand awareness," said Eric Katzman, a food analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown.
One problem with investing in Wrigley, though, is access to good information. Top executives have very little one-on-one contact with Wall Street analysts, and Wrigley does not offer earnings guidance, which is highly unusual for a Fortune 500 company.
Wrigley executives say the company does not play to the press, Wall Street or to the quarterly ups and downs of the stock market, but focuses instead on long-term strategy and profit growth.
"We're an investment company," said Ronald V. Waters, Wrigley's chief financial officer. "The focus is on maintaining the track record."
The Wrigley family, which has overwhelming control of the company through its 56 percent share of the Class B stock and about 21 percent of the common stock, is extremely private. William Wrigley rarely granted press interviews or met with Wall Street analysts. And Bill Wrigley Jr., now 37, who works on the 16th floor of the company's landmark headquarters in downtown Chicago, seems equally reclusive.
What is known is that he is the youngest of three children from the first of William Wrigley's three marriages. He received a bachelor's degree in economics from Duke University in 1985, joined the company later that year, and worked as an assistant to his father and as a marketing and top executive in Canada and then was tutored in a variety of positions here in Chicago. 
Bill Wrigley Jr.'s older siblings went their own way, but retain a stake in the company, according to a spokesman for Wrigley. His brother Philip went into banking and his sister Alison runs a California vineyard.
Mr. Wrigley is married with three children. He is described by friends and associates as personable, unpretentious, and someone who likes to delegate. He has a deep voice, and speaks slowly, sparingly and quite deliberately.
The best evidence of this can be seen at the company's annual meeting each spring, which is one of the few times ordinary investors, the press and Wall Street analysts get a glimpse of the inner circle.
Shortly after taking office, Mr. Wrigley began recruiting top executives from Gillette and Procter & Gamble, who were trotted out as a team for the first time this year. The moves were something of a departure for a company that usually elevates from within.
Mr. Wrigley, despite his comparative inexperience, showed that he can map a game plan and stick to it. Since he took office, the company has bought back millions of shares, created the health division, bought part of a gum technology company and acquired Velamints, the maker of sugarless breath mints.
"Almost everything they said they were going to do a year ago, they've executed on," Mr. Katzman at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown said. "That's rare."
The company's major competitors have not yet signaled any moves into health products, but they are staking out ground in the mint business and creating gums that promise added dental benefits.
Trident Advantage Mints and Trident gum promise to whiten teeth and reduce plaque. Arm & Hammer sells Dental Care gum with baking soda. And there is even an Aquafresh gum.
That may be why Wrigley made a deal with P.& G. and why it is going to try mints. "It's a natural for us to go into the mint category," Mr. Waters, the chief financial officer, said.
Indeed, Wrigley seems to have little choice. For several years, sales of sugared gums like Juicy Fruit and Doublemint -- a category in which Wrigley commands a 75 percent share -- have been falling across the board. Now they are being hurt even more by the growing popularity of high-intensity breath mints, like Altoids. One survey showed that teenagers now chew an average of seven sticks of gum a week, down from 10 sticks a week in 1996, according to Teenage Research Unlimited, a market research company in Northbrook, Ill.
More and more young people want powerful mints, market researchers say, instead of just mint-flavored gums.
"Wrigley brands are at the top," said Michael Wood, an executive at Teenage Research. "But there is no doubt the category is being threatened by mints. Teens chew gum for breath freshening, and that's what they are getting with breath mints."
Wrigley has been pushing new brands into the American market, like Eclipse, its first pellet gum; Everest, packaged in a tin box like Altoids; and Extra Polar Ice, a powerfully flavored chewing gum. All these brands are growing strongly.
Wrigley has also introduced a more aggressive advertising campaign. The television spots for Big Red, Winterfresh and Doublemint are more provocative. Some feature animated hip-hop characters rapping. More recently, the company signed the tennis sisters, Venus and Serena Williams, who are now being featured in the company's "Distinctively Doublemint" ads.
The campaigns -- created by the Chicago office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group and the company's longtime agency -- are a marked departure for Wrigley, which had been known for softer, more conservative tones -- the "double your pleasure, double your fun" style.
There has also been new packaging, new online promotions and a giant new billboard planned for Times Square.
In response to all this, sales of Wrigley chewing gum jumped 10 percent in the United States in the first half of this year and global sales were also up about 10 percent, despite the adverse effects of the strong dollar.
Wrigley is even stronger abroad. More than 60 percent of its sales now come from outside the United States. It has a remarkable 90 percent of the chewing gum market in Germany.
Wrigley is strong in Asia, too, where it sells about $250 million worth of chewing gum a year, according to Prudential Securities. Some analysts expect that figure to balloon to $1 billion within a decade or so.
The company, some say, was built in the mold of Coca-Cola. It has managed to keep prices extremely low for decades by increasing volume and reducing manufacturing costs, making it difficult for competitors to enter the market.
"It's an easy company to understand," said Anne Selkovits, a portfolio manager at Gray, Seifert & Company. "It's not like Gillette, which went out and bought batteries and other things to keep the growth going."
Still, there are always things to worry about. Suppose candies and mints seriously erode the chewing gum market? Suppose delivering health care products through gum fails? 
The young Bill Wrigley seems very much aware of those prospects, analysts say, and that may be why the company is rolling out so many new products and why it is preparing to sell to an aging population -- people who might want to chew on gum rather than take a pill that delivers pain relief, soothes a sore throat, relieves an upset stomach, or perhaps cleans and whitens teeth.
How far might such innovations go? No one really knows. But an older investor rose at the annual meeting in March to put Bill Wrigley Jr. on the spot. 
"My one request is, that being older now, that should you develop a Viagra-flavored health care product, I would like to be among the first to know," the man said.
The audience roared with laughter. Mr. Wrigley smiled calmly. "I think," he replied, "the possibilities are endless."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Major Gauges Fall as Shares Again Fail to Extend a Rally

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday in lackluster summer trading. Investors feared the rally on Friday would fizzle like other advances this year as corporate profits continue to shrink and the economy sputters.
 "There is a lot of uncertainty out there and people are cautious," said Tony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Kirlin Securities. "Since May, every rally has failed, and people are afraid this will be the same." 
 The buying of weakened stocks like computer chip makers briefly pushed the main gauges into positive territory in the early afternoon, but they gave back those gains and closed lower across the board.
"Every trading rally has been an opportunity to pare back, and people take profits," said Tony Rosenthal of TimesSquare Capital Management. "Investors are scared." 
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 4.39 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,912.41. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 40.82 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,382.35. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index shed 5.72 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,179.21.
On Friday, the main gauges posted their biggest gains in more than six weeks with the Nasdaq rising more than 4 percent after Cisco Systems said business was stabilizing and strong sales of new homes indicated that consumers were holding up a crucial sector.
But the latest economic data offered little support after the National Association of Realtors yesterday reported that sales of existing homes fell 3 percent in July.
Home Depot, a Dow component, took a hit after the report, falling 95 cents, to $48.99.
Semiconductor stocks were helped by news that Intel began selling a processor that runs at two billion cycles a second. That doubled the speed of computer chips in only 18 months. It rose 7 cents, to $29.15.
The Philadelphia semiconductor index rose 1.9 percent, closing at a three-week high. Semiconductors have been rising on recent data showing improvement in orders and suggesting the industry's worst downturn in decades is bottoming.
Financial stocks, in particular interest-rate-sensitive regional banks, added to last week's losses on fears the Fed's effort to cut interest rates was nearing an end. Staten Island Bancorp fell $1.77, or 6 percent, to $27.71, and Washington Mutual lost $1.75, or 4.6 percent, to $36.25.
"It might be giving an early clue that the Federal Reserve is either done lowering rates or one interest rate cut away from that," said Barry Hyman, chief investment strategist at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum.
More layoffs stung the market after the farm equipment maker Deere said it would close several plants and cut 1,975 more jobs, bringing total layoffs to 3,225. Deere fell 4 cents, to $43.91.
Blockbuster sank 7.29 percent after Barron's reported that the growth of video on demand over the Internet may slow video rentals. Its stock was off $1.60, to $20.35.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Bond prices fell with expectations that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates once more to head off a recession.
"The risk of a recession is so costly that the Fed can afford" to cut rates again, even at the risk of igniting inflation, said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo.
The price of the benchmark 10-year note fell 3/32, to 100 18/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.93 percent from 4.92 percent on Friday.
The 30-year bond fell 9/32, to 98 22/32. Its yield rose to 5.47 percent from 5.45 percent.

HEADLINE: Front Row 

BYLINE:  By Cathy Horyn 

 BODY:
Dust Off Your Ungaros
Emanuel Ungaro, the French couturier known for his catwalk Jezebels, is taking over the armory on Lexington Avenue the evening of Sept. 5 to celebrate 35 years in fashion. There will be dinner and dancing on a pink plexiglass floor and, of course, lots of guests dressed in Ungaro, new and vintage. About 400 people are expected.
 Mr. Ungaro, who began his career in the workrooms at Balenciaga -- his name, written by hand in ink, can still be found among the dress labels in the Balenciaga archive that Gucci recently acquired -- has mellowed, if slightly, from marriage, fatherhood and years of pleasing women. Balenciaga, who abruptly closed his doors in 1968, said, in his only known interview, that fashion was "a dog's life." A spokeswoman for Mr. Ungaro said yesterday that nowadays he preferred to spend his time with his family, going to galleries and reading Proust. 
 But these are modern competitive times, and no designer can afford to rest on his laurels mulling over the fates of Swann and Charlus. In the 1980's, Mr. Ungaro's big numbers captured the extravagance of the era: a tartan ball skirt worn by Lynn Wyatt, the Houston socialite, still stands out in memory. His ready-to-wear was a mainstay of any good boutique. But a lot of those boutiques are gone, minimalism has ruled, to the approval of serious-minded working women, and Mr. Ungaro has sometimes had a time-warp quality. 
Slowly, he is trying to change. He is working closely with a young assistant, Jean-Batista Valli. He has made his ads more provocative. According to his spokeswoman, sales have doubled in the last year, in part thanks to a new London boutique. And like many older designers, Mr. Ungaro is being discovered by the younger crowd, including the Hilton sisters and Sarah Jessica Parker. Among those expected at the party is Zoe Cassavetes, whose mother, Gena Rowlands, was dressed by Mr. Ungaro for her 1980 movie, "Gloria," and who had the good sense to keep some of the clothes.

Passing on Coverage
At a time when fashion coverage seems to be anybody's game, including the tabloids and those feisty young sleuths at Hintmag.com, regional newspapers are having second thoughts. 
Among newspapers not sending reporters to the spring collections in New York, which begin Sept. 8, are The Houston Chronicle, The Times-Picayune of New Orleans and The San Francisco Chronicle.
The economy is the reason. "We're in our third round of budget cuts," said Linda Griffin, fashion editor of The Houston Chonicle, which until last spring published a weekly eight-page fashion section. But declining ad revenues have clipped Ms. Griffin's wings. She stopped covering shows in Europe two years ago, and for the first time in more than a decade will not be at the New York shows. 
"The large advertisers want to be in the front section of the paper," she said. "You can beat them over the head with a high heel, but they're not going to change."
Fern Mallis, executive director of 7th on Sixth, which runs the shows in Bryant Park, said: "It's unfortunate that the state of the economy is preventing some out-of-town editors from coming to the shows. But I don't think it's going to impact coverage." According to registration figures, 16 of the top 20 daily American newspapers are sending reporters, and attendance has increased in all categories, notably among Web sites. 
But those numbers tell only part of the story. James O'Byrne, the features editor of The Times-Picayune, said he questioned the wisdom of sending a reporter and a photographer to New York, at a cost of $9,000, when there may be other ways of covering fashion. "It's the economy, but it's more than that," Mr. O'Byrne said. "Even if things were to get bright and rosy tomorrow, I would never go back to the way we were doing it." He suggested that while readers want fashion news, they were not dependent on a local editor to explain the finer points.
Dotty Lane couldn't agree more. Ms. Lane is the fashion writer at The Record-Courier (circulation: 26,000) in Kent, Ohio, and she faithfully covered the New York shows for 30 years. But in 1999, she gave up. "Designers used to take the time to talk to you and explain what their inspirations were," she said. "But now the trends on the runways are the same ones you catch on television -- tight jeans and T-shirts."
So Ms. Lane decided to give New York fashion a pass. "In the last few years, I was really just coming to see my friends," she said.
So what else is new?

HEADLINE: Standard Media Inc. Files for Bankruptcy 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
Standard Media Inc., the parent company of the once high-flying dot-com magazine The Industry Standard, filed for bankruptcy protection today, one week after it ceased publication and laid off most of its staff.
 Clerks at the federal bankruptcy court in San Francisco confirmed the filing, which sets the stage for the court to supervise the sale of Standard Media's assets, including the magazine's subscriber list, trademarks, computers and office furniture. 
 Officials at Standard Media declined to comment on the filing. But the company's chief operating officer, Ann-Marie McGowan, was quoted on the company Web site as saying there was "considerable interest" in the remaining assets from both investors and media companies, some of whom might be interested in restarting the magazine.
At the height of the dot-com heyday, The Industry Standard employed more than 400 people and regularly published magazines that exceeded 300 pages.
But the drastic reversal in dot-com fortunes hit the magazine's advertising base hard, and negotiations for further financing from principal investors including the trade magazine publisher International Data Group collapsed.

HEADLINE: Preserving a Hair-Raising Relic of the Cold War 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW WINDSOR, N.Y. 

 BODY:
They called it the blockhouse, and from the outside at least, it lived up to its name. It was a windowless square with no distinguishing features except for a single beige stripe around its middle.
 The four-story building was constructed of lead-reinforced concrete and was tucked behind a hill on a United States Air Force base in this small town 60 miles north of New York City. Since the building was hard to camouflage, the designers did the next best thing, making it so nondescript that few but those with a security clearance to get inside knew what went on there. 
 Now, the structure and its mysterious past have captured the imagination of two residents of the nearby town of New Paltz.
The two residents -- Susan Zimet, 47, co-director of the Hudson Valley Media Arts Center, and Karl Rodman, 65, the president of River Valley Tours, an educational travel organization -- hope to turn it into a museum to commemorate what they see as the next era ripe for nostalgia: the cold war. They will call it the Cold War/Peace Museum.
"People need to see this and know what was going on right in their own backyard during that time," Ms. Zimet said.
Beginning in 1958, the building, once known as the Semi-Automatic Ground Environment Direction Center and called SAGE, played a crucial role in America's defense against a possible Soviet air attack. It housed part of the military's first major computer-based command and control system.
Data from far-flung radar sites were transmitted over phone lines to computer consoles at this and 21 similar centers nationwide, where Air Force personnel scanned the skies, prepared at the touch of a button to intercept enemy planes with remote-controlled surface-to-air missiles.
After serving as the hub of Northeast air defense for more than a decade, the SAGE Center on the Stewart Air Force Base closed in the late 1960's, its technology made obsolete by the proliferation of intercontinental ballistic missiles. Tracking ICBM's required more sensitive radar and faster computers. It has sat ever since, largely empty and deteriorating, on the grounds of what is now Stewart International Airport.
Ms. Zimet and Mr. Rodman envision a museum that would not only explain the building and its technology, but also examine the impact of the cold war on all aspects of life in both the United States and the Soviet Union. It might also have a full-size theater that would show continuous screenings of cold war movies like "Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb" and "Seven Days in May."
Other potential exhibits include a life-size reconstruction of a family's backyard bomb shelter and a collection of oral histories from military personnel and civilians.
Ms. Zimet and Mr. Rodman are trying to raise $200,000 by Dec. 1 to finance feasibility and concept studies. They have been discussing their plans with Ralph Appelbaum Associates, a Manhattan museum design firm best known for the Holocaust Museum in Washington, and Economics Research Associates, an entertainment consulting firm.
The museum project is among a growing number of efforts to preserve sites related to the time when fear of nuclear annihilation gripped America.
Francis Gary Powers Jr., son of the U-2 pilot whose reconnaissance plane was shot down over Russia in 1960, plans to open a museum on a former Nike missile base in Lorton, Va. On Long Island, a group wants to save the nation's last remaining intact Air Force radar tower and antenna, situated on state-owned land at Montauk Point. In New Jersey, the federal government is restoring another former Nike missile site at Fort Hancock on Sandy Hook peninsula in hopes of turning it into a national park.
America is increasingly fascinated by the cold war, partly because enough time has passed for most people to truly consider it history, said Robert Sharlet, the Chauncey H. Winters professor of political science at Union College in Schenectady. Yet the cold war is still a vivid memory for nostalgia-prone baby boomers who participated in duck-and-cover drills at school and monitored the space race, he said.
"In a sense, everyone who lived through the cold war is a cold war veteran," Professor Sharlet said. "Now that all the unpleasantness is history and the memories are sanitized, I foresee cold war toys, T-shirts and bus tours of old" Strategic Air Command bomber sites. "Nostalgia is a terrific marketing tool, and pop culture is a great earner."
Nevertheless, those interested in saving cold-war-related sites are not finding their task easy. Built to be functional, not beautiful, old radar towers, hulking concrete computer centers and outdated missile bases can be a hard sell for those who favor preserving them.
Also, many of the properties have been stripped of the electronics that were arguably their most interesting feature. At the New Windsor site, one floor is now home to a company that makes chocolate lollipops by hand.
Upstairs, all that remains of the storied technology are the hulking air-conditioning units that once cooled two identical computer systems, each with approximately 50,000 vacuum tubes. In the command center, where air defense strategy was plotted, are two painted Plexiglas maps indicating the status of potential targets of enemy bombs.
In its heyday, the system featured the largest and most expensive real-time computer program every built. Designed by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Lincoln Laboratories and constructed by I.B.M., it pioneered technology that modern computer users now consider standard, including dial-up telephone modems and the mouse. Its advancements helped create today's airline reservation systems.
"The SAGE computer was a marvel not seen in civilian circles," said Chris McWilliams, a retired Air Force major who worked as a radar operator at the New Windsor site from 1957 to 1960. "Compared to the older manual radar consoles, the SAGE consoles looked like something out of Buck Rogers."
Ms. Zimet and Mr. Rodman hope that the New Windsor building's role in history and its contributions to modern computing will help draw a crowd. They believe that a cold war museum in New Windsor will tie in with existing local historic military sites, particularly the United States Military Academy at West Point, which attracts 2.5 million visitors a year.
"I took one look at this and knew that its history and significance were too great to do anything but make it into a museum," Ms. Zimet said. "The goal is to have them walk out with their hair standing up on the back of their necks and realizing that at any given moment, we could find ourselves back in that situation again."
