HEADLINE: East Takes Center Stage as Yale Focuses on China 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO

 BODY:
When the 1,300 Yale seniors assembled in the university's ornate Woolsey Hall for their graduation this year, they did not hear a speech about the moral quandaries facing their generation or the responsibilities they shoulder as Americans. They heard a speech about China. 
 It was hardly a surprise at the Ivy League institution, where a fascination with China dates to the 1850's and where one of the most popular classes is a course in modern Chinese history taught by Jonathan Spence. 
 In 1854, the school offered a bachelor's degree to Yung Wing, the first Chinese native to graduate from any American college. "He flew on the wings of the wind. His hat went off; his queue burst from the pins and streamed out behind him," a classmate wrote, describing Mr. Yung in a football game. 
In the following decades, dozens, if not hundreds, of Yale men traveled to China to spread the word about Christianity, including the father of Henry Luce, the founder of Time magazine who had a lifelong interest in China. In 1901, a missionary project called Yale-in-China was founded that would later build a teaching hospital and a middle school in China's province of Hunan.
Today, Yale is even more involved with China, with programs including AIDS education in Hunan and a waterfront revival project in Shanghai, though the impetus is less missionary than Yale's intention to become a truly global university. 
Why China? 
"China matters because one-fifth of the world population lives there," Yale's president, Richard C. Levin, said in his graduation speech.
And China, says Jeffrey Garten, the dean of the Yale School of Management, is "the second most important country in the world."
"To work with China is a conscious decision at Yale," said Mr. Garten. "Over the next decade, China is going to be a major player in the world economy. Whatever happens in China will have a big impact on the rest of the world, and we obviously want to be involved." 
Harvard, the University of California at Berkeley and Columbia all have programs in Chinese studies and have sponsored research trips to the country, but few universities have been involved as directly in China as Yale.
Yale Law School has started a China Law Center, which conducts workshops for Chinese legislators and legal scholars in hopes of helping to establish more equitable laws.
For six years, the Yale School of Nursing has conducted AIDS education in Hunan, training nursing instructors who teach about AIDS and H.I.V. According to the Chinese Ministry of Health, there has been a rapid increase in the number of people who are H.I.V.-positive. 
And professors at the management school are trying to bring together members of the Securities and Exchange Commission and their Chinese counterparts to talk about the expanding Chinese stock market.
Yale has not stopped dispatching its college graduates to China either. Through the Yale-China program, a cultural and academic exchange whose precursor is Yale-in-China, dozens of recent graduates have spent years in China teaching English and spreading information about American culture.
At Yale in the last academic year, 312 people from mainland China made up the largest number of foreign students. While most study science at the graduate level, a few high school seniors are admitted each year on full financial aid. Many, who come to the United States as teenagers, see their lives transformed.
"My life is now filled with new ideas, new people and new experiences," said Qinan Tang, a junior.
But courting China, a nation with a rich history that was subject to colonial occupation from 1840 to 1945, is harder than transforming lives. The Chinese are suspicious of Westerners, and the relations between their government and the Unites States has often been hostile.
"Being based in a university has a lot of advantages," said Paul Gewirtz, director of the law center. "It disconnects us from the ups and downs of the relationship between governments." The April spy plane incident, for example, did not hamper Yale's relations with China. Perhaps, Mr. Gewirtz said, an exchange with scholars appears less threatening to the Chinese than one with the government. And Mr. Gewirtz is very attuned to Chinese sensitivities. He tries to make sure that the seminars for Chinese legislators and scholars are not sermons. 
So far, Mr. Gewirtz and his Yale law colleagues say they are seeing positive results. On a visit to Beijing in July, his group was invited to a reception at the Great Hall of the People (usually reserved for national leaders) and later discussed Western licensing laws -- regarding government regulations -- with its host, the Office of Legislative Affairs. 
This month, Mr. Gewirtz was visited by Chen Guangzhong, a Chinese scholar on criminal law and a main architect of the widely applauded 1996 Chinese criminal procedure law guaranteeing many defendants' rights. Mr. Chen and his fellow scholars explored the exclusion of illegally seized evidence and the right to silence during a police interrogation at law center workshops. 
On another front, Wang Honghong, a Hunan nursing teacher who attended Yale's AIDS workshops in her home province, said she learned about handling the side effects of AIDS treatment and reducing chances of transmission from mothers to babies.
Some Yale officials say that China is not the only party that may change because of this liaison. "In the long run, I think China will have more influence on Yale than the other way around," said Nancy Chapman, director of the Yale-China Association. 
"The fact there are hundreds of Chinese students present on campus has transformed the university. And the Chinese values and culture certainly lead Yale people to question their own assumptions."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Students from mainland China make up the university's largest foreign population. At right, devastation of the Yale-in-China campus in Hunan province in 1942. The program is now called Yale-China. (Yale-China Archives); (Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

 INTERNATIONAL A3-11

Israeli Forces Take Over Arab Area in West Bank
Israeli tanks and soldiers took control of parts of Beit Jala, a Palestinian town south of Jerusalem. Israel called the operation necessary to protect its citizens. Palestinian officials denounced it as a "reoccupation" of areas supposedly under their control. It was the first time Israel had entered a Palestinian-ruled zone for an indefinite stay. A Palestinian security officer was killed and more than six Palestinians were wounded. A1

The Bush administration urged Israel to withdraw and called on the Palestinians to stop shootings and attacks from Beit Jala on Gilo, on the southern edge of Jerusalem. A10

U.S.-British Attack on Iraq
American and British warplanes attacked two military command posts in southern Iraq. It was the latest effort to debilitate Iraq's increasingly aggressive air defense system. Officials asserted that the attack had nothing to do with the loss of an American reconnaissance plane near Basra the day before. A10

U.S. Wary of a U.N. Agenda
The Bush administration is engaged in a strenuous effort to influence the agenda of a special United Nations conference next month on the rights of children so that the session's final declaration does not appear to lend support for abortion counseling, American and United Nations officials said. State Department officials said that no matter what might occur in ongoing negotiations, the administration was not considering boycotting the session. A11

More NATO Arms Collections
Hundreds of ethnic Albanian fighters lined up to hand in their weapons to NATO troops at a rebel training camp in Brodec, a village in western Macedonia. It was the second day of NATO's weapons collection operation and, without a hitch, several hundred more weapons, including three ground-to-air missiles, were consigned for destruction. A6

Belarus Chief Rails at West

NATIONAL A12-19

Economists Say Surplus Faces Greater Pressure
New budget projections from Congressional analysts and the White House show that the Bush administration is almost certain to have to dip into the Social Security surplus to pay the government's bills, prominent economists said. And because Congressional analysts may base projections only on current spending, their report does not factor in further big spending increases that would accompany plans for a national missile-defense system and a Medicare prescription drug benefit. A14

Driver Safety Changes Urged
The National Transportation Safety Board said a 1999 New Orleans bus crash that killed 22 women had resulted from the driver's poor health and the failure of the doctors who had examined him to try to take him off the road. The board recommended tighter standards for medical exams that bus and truck drivers must pass every two years and for procedures to help employers find out about applicants' drug problems. A16

DNA Leads to New Suspect
Oklahoma investigators said DNA evidence, which exonerated Jeffrey Pierce after he spent 15 years in prison on a rape conviction, had led them to another man serving time for rape and burglary. They did not identify the inmate and said he might not be charged because the seven-year statute of limitations had expired in the 1985 rape case. A12

Charges in Pilots' Deaths
Frank Brady, 50, of Redwood City, Calif., was arrested on suspicion of murder in the deaths of two pilots whose firefighting planes collided over a wildfire. Officials said they were investigating whether Mr. Brady and Richard Mortensen, 43, of San Pablo, who was being held on previous warrants, were running an illegal drug lab where the fire began. A18

On Monday, the federal government moved to declare the municipal landfill in Frenso, Calif., a national landmark; yesterday, it backed off after it was disclosed that the dump, the nation's first sanitary landfill, is a Superfund cleanup site. A12

HEADLINE: Diverging Views About Policing, Race Policy, Taxes and Education 

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate of the Democratic candidates for mayor, as recorded for The New York Times. The debate was organized by the New York City Campaign Finance Board for candidates who receive public money, and was sponsored by WPIX-TV (Channel 11), WNYC-AM Radio (820) and Newsday. It was moderated by Kaity Tong, co-anchor of "WB11 News at 10." The candidates were questioned by Brian Lehrer, host of WNYC's "On the Line"; Les Payne, deputy managing editor at Newsday; and Jim Watkins, co-anchor of "WB11 News at 10."

Q. Let's say just hypothetically the squeegee men think that with the Giuliani administration gone, for them the coast is clear. Please tell us the steps you would take.

FERNANDO FERRER: A Ferrer administration wouldn't give squeegee guys or aggressive panhandlers any reason to believe that they can harass or aggressively panhandle any New Yorker. . . . One of the important aspects of quality of living in this city is a city that preserves and protects everyone's individual sense of safety and security. But having said that, we also need a Police Department that inspires the trust, confidence, support and respect of every New Yorker. A police commissioner who has a sense of balance about those things, who will continue to bring down crime but also bring down those negative contacts between people and the police that serves them.

MARK GREEN: If there's an uptick in some intersection that some so-called squeegee men are back, it's not the hardest thing to invest officers in that corner to stop it. What is more important is to come up with a strategy to keep on not just low, but even lower. And so I am such a strong proponent of more community policing with more cops on the neighborhood beat. . . . Until and when we lower the barriers between cops and communities, especially communities of color, we'll never continue our crime reduction as we must.

ALAN G. HEVESI: There cannot be one step back in the fight against crime. There has to be a continuous effort to sustain the police force at its current levels with new deployments, with new technologies. And included in that formula is an absolute requirement that we do not retreat when it comes to quality-of-life crimes as represented in your question by the squeegees. . . . I will eliminate the decency commission. But when it comes to fare-jumping and squeegees and graffiti, we will sustain that effort to make sure that everybody in New York gets the idea that we're not retreating at all on crime.

GEORGE N. SPITZ: The problem is that the Democratic Party has become too conservative. These squeegee people need help. And I favor looking into some of the programs that they do in the Scandinavian countries, and getting them into the mainstream of the Democratic Party. These people need help, and the government should give it to them.

PETER F. VALLONE: I've worked alongside three different mayors to make sure that this is the safest city in the country. I'm the one who conceived the plan in the first place to put 10,000 more police on the streets. There's absolutely no way I'd ever let the city slip back the way it was with squeegee men or anyone else. Under my community-policing plan, I would make sure that the police that are assigned to that area, or any area in the city, not only know the area and know the problems of the area, but know the people in the community.

Q. Secretary of State Colin Powell announced that he's not going to go to the U.N. global conference on racism in Durban. And as a mayor, would you, at some level, have sent a delegation to this conference? . . . And what is your specific position on reparations for slavery in the United States?

VALLONE: I would think that the mayor is second only to the president in terms of world recognition. And it strikes me that I would do whatever I can to understand how serious the problem of racism is. But within the jurisdiction that I have as mayor of the city of New York, one of the things that I've just done is to try to get the truth of whether or not we have such things as racial profiling that exists in the city of New York by passing a landmark disclosure bill in which we will have our police -- every arrest that's made in the city, every single stop and frisk that's made in the city. I want our police to be ambassadors of good will, and I want -- I'd work with representatives of every color, every corner, every culture of this city.

FERRER: The decision by Secretary of State Powell saddens me. But the Bush administration, in fact, has been asleep at the switch on, for example, the commission on human rights at the U.N. letting slave-trading nations like Sudan be in the driver's seat. We have a moral obligation as a nation to speak up and speak out on human rights and civil rights abuses all over the world. And the mayor . . . should be stepping up to this one as well because the sons and daughters of those countries live in the five boroughs of this city. Let me say a word about racial profiling. It's good to have a law that counts numbers. It's better to have a law banning it. That's what I proposed a month ago.

GREEN: Since that conference says that Zionism is racism, which is absurd, the United States had a right to say, "Get rid of that, and now let's talk about racism." . . . I don't know a greater evil in the world than the slave trade in Africa and America. I worry that 150 years later, reparations is an unworkable and divisive way to cure it or to pay down the debt. The way to do that is smaller class sizes, more children on health insurance since it's black and Latino children and families that are most discriminated.

HEVESI: My first speech as comptroller . . . was a call to end any form of bigotry in this city. . . . The U.S. should be participating in a conference that deals with the issue of racism. And I know Peter Vallone didn't intend to create a different impression than he did when he said, "We have to find out if there's racial profiling." There is. Not on the part of the department, not on the part of any particular command, but in individual cases. The question of reparations -- I . . . succeeded in obtaining restitution . . . from European governments for Holocaust victims. We provided reparations as well to Japanese-Americans. Reparations does not mean everybody gets a check.

SPITZ: I think I'm the only candidate running for citywide office who takes a balanced point of view towards the Mideast. I'm opposing the Israeli occupation policies, the land confiscation, the collective punishments and the assassinations. I'm proud that I'm an Orthodox Jew, but I believe Palestinians have a right -- have a right to live. And I think that our policies, U.S. policies, have been exacerbated by New York City mayors . . . taking extremist stands on this issue.

Q. Mr. Ferrer, in recent years we had a temporary income tax surcharge to pay for building up the police force. You've proposed restoring that surcharge to pay for after-school programs. Mr. Hevesi has proposed restoring it for education. . . . Why is that a good idea in as heavily taxed a city as this?

FERRER: It's one and a half points of a personal income tax surcharge that would result in a daily savings to the average working family of four pennies a day. Since being mayor is about choices . . . the choice I would make is to give every working parent the guarantee that their child, by dismissal time, is still in front of adult supervision, out of harm's way and learning more. . . . If it's between a trivial personal income tax surcharge tax cut and after-school programs, I gladly make the choice for kids.

GREEN: We are a very high-taxed city, which can hurt growth. And the last moment -- the worst moment we should think about raising taxes is on the brink of a potential softening of the economy or recession. I appeared with Mayor David Dinkins last week; he was the creator of the after-school programs called Beacon schools. I want to increase them. It would cost $25 million, which could be paid for by the -- indefensible $300 million overtime budget at the Police Department. I have hundreds of millions of savings in productivity gains and labor savings and e-government that can and will be invested in smaller class sizes and more after-school programs. If at the end of that we need more revenue, I would invest it in our kids, even at the cost of increased taxes. But that's the last, not an eager first option.

HEVESI: You really have to have experience in dealing with budgets to make the kind of commitment that we just heard from Mark Green. The reality is that if the economy goes sour, we're going to have to make some very heavy choices and there'll be real austerity. The truth is, it was in a recession that Peter Vallone and David Dinkins did raise taxes, the 12 1/2 percent surcharge on the income tax, for policing. And it worked. And my position is that, while we supported a whole range of tax cuts including eight business tax cuts, four of which we recommended during the boom times, what I have said is if we needed to as a last resort, if money from the state in the campaign for fiscal equity case doesn't come through, then a restoration of that same 12 1/2 percent surcharge earmarked for education so we don't lose another generation of kids is appropriate.

SPITZ: Before the war -- and I lived here before the war, even worked here before the war; this was a mean-spirited city compared to today -- mediocre restaurants and stores, 1 percent sales tax, no income tax, built Queens College, Brooklyn College, libraries were open till 9 every night, free tuition in the universities, expanded park space 50 percent, go on and on. Today with a vibrant multiculture society we have -- and an 8 1/4 percent sales tax and no -- and a huge income tax, we can't even pay our teachers properly or police or fire properly.

VALLONE: In terms of a surtax, I'm the one that instituted the surtax together with Mayor Dinkins. . . . And I also promised that I would give it back in 1998 and would not raise one single tax since. I kept that promise. We have the money back, the mayor wanted to use it to move Yankee Stadium from the Bronx to Manhattan. I said absolutely not. I haven't raised a single tax, have made -- I reduced occupancy taxes and other obnoxious taxes in order to encourage business in the city. The worst thing that we could do now is, when we have a $1 billion surplus, is to chase good businesses out of the city by talking about raising taxes again.

Q. Mr. Ferrer, you've promised to raise the salary of city teachers by 30 percent across the board. . . . How do you specifically plan to finance this, especially given the fact that other unions -- police, fire -- are going to line up?

FERRER: First, a bold and very large raise for teachers. I want to treat teachers as the professionals they are. But I also want to demand more from the profession: more accountability, the ability to remove an unfit or unqualified teacher promptly now, and year-round training and teaching for teachers. And I've shown time and time again how I'd pay for that, within the budget, within savings of the Board of Education.

GREEN: There's no more important challenge . . . than to fix our broken school system. . . . I've visited 50 schools one by one myself to learn what works and what doesn't. And what I heard from teachers and principals is we need a big deal with our teachers. Pay more, especially bonuses for improved performance if they're going to a lower-performance school, if they tutor younger colleagues.

HEVESI: The formula for good education . . . is simple: smaller classes. It's geometrically better to have 18 kids than 25 or 30 in a class. A qualified, certified teacher in every class. Parents trained to help their kids learn. And safe schools. And nothing more critical than having a certified, qualified teacher in every class. . . . We have to have a closing of the gap in salaries between the teachers in this city and the surrounding suburbs. The differential is 25 percent right now.

SPITZ: My local school board: 65 patronage jobs in a luxurious schoolhouse. . . . What kind of morale can the teachers and the parents have when you have a situation like that? . . . We have enough money to pay the salaries of everybody if we cut the patronage, the contracting out of all our system.

VALLONE: I think it's time that we understand to get rid of the Board of Education as it exists -- the politics of the Board of Education is interfering not only with the education of the kids but many other things, including the monies that have to go into the classroom. What we have to do is to have a plan, a realistic plan which would give $500 million more a year to our school system, together with the $1 billion that is now owed to us by the state on an annual basis.

HEADLINE: City Will Close Office Running Foster Program 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
New York City's child welfare commissioner said yesterday that he would close the city office that directly runs foster homes in Manhattan and Staten Island because it had scored at the bottom of a systemwide performance evaluation -- far below the worst-performing nonprofit foster care agency under contract to the city.
 The commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, said the administration of foster homes for the city-run program's 280 children would be transferred to better-performing agencies, mostly private ones, by Sept. 30. Most of the children will stay in their present foster homes. 
 The office for Manhattan and Staten Island, one of four in different boroughs under Mr. Scoppetta's direct control, was rated unsatisfactory on measures like how often caseworkers visited children, how swiftly families were reunited and whether children received needed medical care. 
Mr. Scoppetta said the decision to shut the 42-year-old operation showed that the city was applying the same tough standards to itself that it applied to the private agencies that provide most foster care beds in the long-troubled system.
"Better if an agency is performing so poorly to close it," Mr. Scoppetta said, noting that the office's score of 50 percent was 9 points below the score of a private agency that he had already threatened to shut down. "It's a very important message to the community, including our own people." 
But some child welfare veterans worried that the decision to close the office rather than fix the city-run operation was a step backward. They recalled past periods when the city's dependence on private agencies left many children, especially black children, with no home at all. 
"Being totally dependent on the private sector does not give the city the leverage to assure quality services for children," said Marcia Robinson Lowry, a veteran child welfare litigator. "Certainly that's the history of child welfare in this city." 
Mr. Scoppetta did not disagree. He said it was "extremely important" to keep the city in the business of what is known as direct foster care services so that "in the unlikely event that there's a need to expand foster care, there will be a way to do it." But, he added, "we want it to be a quality service."
The office being closed, which is in Harlem, is one of four operated by the city's Administration for Children's Services in its Direct Foster Care Services. One, in Queens, scored 76.4, better than most of the private foster care agencies, including well-endowed institutions like New York Foundling and the Children's Aid Society. But those in the Bronx and Brooklyn had unsatisfactory scores of 61.7 and 61.5 on the new evaluation, the most comprehensive ever.
Mr. Scoppetta said that the director of the Bronx office had been demoted and transferred and that a new Brooklyn director had been named. The director for Manhattan and Staten Island resigned, he said.
While some child welfare veterans praised the decision as the end of a longstanding double standard, others asked why Mr. Scoppetta had not acted sooner to fix city-run programs with management problems that were well known when he took office more than five years ago.
"They have a long history of having caseloads that are too high and workers who are not adequately supervised and not held to standards," Ms. Lowry said, noting that Mr. Scoppetta's widely praised improvements in worker training and supervision mainly affected child abuse and neglect investigators, not direct-care workers or the workers at private agencies.
"The city has made top-level management changes, theoretical changes and policy changes," she said. "But I think this shows a lack of attention to the level where children and families live."
For more than a century, New York City's foster care system has been one of the nation's most privatized and the one that most relied on religious agencies. The city did not venture into publicly provided foster homes until 1959. It entered the field reluctantly, propelled by the needs of hundreds of black and Hispanic babies who were waiting in hospital wards for foster homes after being rejected by the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant agencies that controlled all publicly subsidized foster home beds. 
The city's first plan was to reopen a ward of a defunct tuberculosis hospital on Long Island for the babies' care, Justine Wise Polier, a family court judge at the time, recalled in her memoirs. Well aware of the damage to babies in such settings, Judge Polier came up with an alternative: the city should pay approved welfare mothers to board an infant, simultaneously improving each family's economic condition, giving the mother useful work, and saving the babies from institutional neglect.
"At that time, the private agencies were not following their responsibility for placing children irrespective of their racial and ethnic identity," said James R. Dumpson, who was then the city's director of social services. "That's how we got into public service."
Faye Moore, director of grievances for the caseworkers' union, said the above-average performance of the Queens office showed that the city was capable of providing good care for children. She said the union, which represents the 58 workers to be redeployed to other assignments, had complained about management in the Harlem office for years.
"Every time they had vacancies in other boroughs for child welfare specialists, they would pull from this office, so there was a constant lack of staff," she said.
But Mr. Scoppetta said the downsizing of the city's direct-care operation made sense in light of the steep decline of the city's foster care population over the last decade, to about 30,000 from a 1991 peak of 49,100. 
In the case of "an unforeseen catastrophe" like a new kind of crack epidemic, he said, the city may have to reopen the Manhattan office.
"But we're not planning for the catastrophe that may or may not appear on the scene in the next 10 years," he said. "I'm absolutely convinced we have too many children in foster care."

HEADLINE: Hiker From Brooklyn Is Found Dead in New Hampshire 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN

 BODY:
It was supposed to be a 15-minute hike in the White Mountains of New Hampshire, about 10 miles from the synagogue that Abraham Hauer managed for the many Orthodox Jews who vacationed in the area.
 Mr. Hauer's wife, Milka, stopped to rest after about five minutes, and her husband said he would be back in 20 minutes. But Mr. Hauer, who lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, never returned. After two days of searching by New Hampshire Fish and Game Department officers, the state police and hundreds of Orthodox Jewish volunteers, his body was found yesterday in the woods in Franconia. 
 The police said it appeared that Mr. Hauer, 53, who went on the walk toward dusk on Sunday, wandered off the path and was trying to find his way by thrashing through the woods. On Monday, searchers found his vest, about 200 yards from the body.
"Apparently he became disoriented and slipped and fell, and more than likely succumbed to the weather conditions," Sgt. Timothy Hayes of the New Hampshire State Police said. "There was no indication of major injury."
The medical examiner did not immediately give a cause of death, and the body was released to the family. 
Mr. Hauer's body was brought back to Brooklyn for the funeral. Today, shortly after midnight, about 400 people filled Rodney Street in Williamsburg -- the men on one side, the women on the other, according to tradition -- outside the Satmar synagogue, where the ceremony took place.
Burial was to follow in Kiryas Joel in Orange County, in keeping with Jewish custom that the deceased be buried within 24 hours. 
Temperatures on Sunday night were down to the high 40's in the area, and it rained on Monday. "If you are not properly dressed or used to it, it can take a toll," Sergeant Hayes said.
Acquaintances described Mr. Hauer as someone who enjoyed good views and regular walks, but not an experienced hiker. The sergeant said Mr. Hauer may have been trying to head for the sound of traffic, because three highways pass through the area. He was hiking in Franconia Notch, a narrow passage through rocky terrain, which could easily distort the sound of cars, making them seem closer then they were.
"It's a perfect echo chamber," Sergeant Hayes said.
The trail, which leads up the mountain to a ledge with panoramic views, is considered an easy hike.
Mr. Hauer managed the Arlington Synagogue in Bethlehem, N.H., an area popular with vacationing Orthodox Jews. He took over the synagogue about 10 years ago, and led prayers there three times a day, said Miriam Ausch, who lives in Williamsburg and was in Bethlehem yesterday while on vacation.
She described Mr. Hauer as a kind man with a ready smile. "Everybody he met, he greeted," she said.
Mr. Hauer's disappearance drew hundreds of Orthodox Jews from New York, New Jersey and Montreal to take part in the search. Many others contributed money for boots, jackets and food for the searchers.
"They would do this for anybody from our society because our religion teaches us that," Ms. Ausch said. "Each person cares for the other. It's a big loss, but we accept God's will. We just have to go on."
In Williamsburg, Isaac Abraham said it was not uncommon for Orthodox Jews to organize searches when one of their own goes missing.
"Usually when we go on searches we hope to bring someone out walking and talking," he said.
Along with his activities at the New Hampshire synagogue, Mr. Hauer was known as a matchmaker for the Satmars in Williamsburg, where he lived in a five-story brick walk-up.
In the Brooklyn neighborhood, others described Mr. Hauer as a popular and charitable man. "He would go out of his way to help everyone," said Eugene Singer, 51, a salesman. "He helped my brother once. He saw that he looked a little depressed because he was unemployed, and he got him a job making ties."
Acquaintances said Mr. Hauer had a 22-year-old daughter and several grandchildren.
The Associated Press quoted Milka Hauer, who explained how she sat on a rock waiting for her husband to return.
"I waited and went up farther and yelled and he didn't call," she said, "so I decided that he was in trouble."
Another woman, who said she saw Mr. Hauer on Sunday before returning from vacation, said: "A nice man goes for a walk and doesn't come back. Of course it makes you upset."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Hundreds of mourners filled the street in Williamsburg after midnight today for Abraham Hauer's funeral. (Alan Chin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: National Briefing Midwest: Michigan: Schools Make Cuts 

BYLINE:  By Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

 BODY:
 Public schools across the state are being forced to cut budgets and programs, citing a lack of state financing. 
Because of a property tax cut approved in 1994, some districts whose increases in state aid fell below the inflation rate are cutting teaching positions, increasing class sizes and charging students to compete in sports. The 1994 plan cut school property taxes up to 82 percent, moved the burden of school financing to the state from property owners and tried to even spending among districts. Gov. John Engler, who helped design the tax cut, said the education problems were not the result of a lack of resources. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

HEADLINE: National Briefing Education: Support For Gay Rights 

BYLINE:  By Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

 BODY:
 American teenagers are more likely than their parents to support the legalization of gay marriage and other protections for gay men and lesbians, a national survey of 1,000 high school seniors has found. 
The survey, conducted this year by researchers at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., found that two-thirds of the students supported the legal recognition of gay marriage. That compares with about a third of adults in Associated Press and Gallup Organization surveys. More than two-thirds of the teenagers also said gay couples should be permitted to adopt children. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
A creative executive, formerly of Kirshenbaum Bond, moves to Ogilvy & Mather in New York.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
A LEADING creative executive is joining the New York office of a giant agency.
 The executive is Bill Oberlander, who until early this year had been managing partner and executive creative director of the New York office of Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners. 
 Effective Sept. 17, Mr. Oberlander, who has also worked for McCaffrey & McCall and McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, will join the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, as one of five senior partners and executive creative directors. 
Mr. Oberlander, 41, is an art director and recently completed three years as president of the Art Directors Club in New York. He will be paired at Ogilvy New York with a copywriter, Dan Burrier, who is also a senior partner and executive creative director, on accounts like Motorola, the Perrier Group of America division of Nestle and Cotton Inc. Mr. Oberlander will also help Mr. Burrier oversee a program at the agency called Young Guns, which offers jobs to top graduates of advertising schools and programs across the county.
The hiring of Mr. Oberlander by Ogilvy New York is emblematic of the steps agencies seek to take during unsettling economic times to attract new clients and keep current clients happy. One way is to try to bolster creative firepower by assembling a cadre of well-known, award-winning senior executives.
"We have a pretty strong story for any client," Rick Boyko, co-president and chief creative officer at Ogilvy New York, said yesterday, adding that there was "a terrific stable of creative talent at senior levels running businesses."
One strength of the creative lineup, he added, is that like Mr. Oberlander, many of the executives had joined Ogilvy New York from other agencies including the BBDO Worldwide and DDB Worldwide units of the Omnicom Group; Foote, Cone & Belding, now part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies; and Wieden & Kennedy.
In an interview in which he discussed Mr. Oberlander's hiring, which is to be formally announced today, Mr. Boyko cited approvingly a quotation from David Ogilvy, the agency's founder, which he paraphrased as, "Hire people bigger than yourself, and you become an agency of giants."
Not bad for a paraphrase. The full quotation from Mr. Ogilvy, who died in 1999, is as follows: "If you always hire people who are smaller than you are, we shall become a company of dwarfs. If, on the other hand, you always hire people who are bigger than you are, we shall become a company of giants."
Mr. Ogilvy also had another pithy saying on staffing an agency: "If you ever find a man who is better than you are, hire him. If necessary, pay him more than you pay yourself."
Mr. Oberlander joined Kirshenbaum Bond, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network, in early 1990, when the agency, known then as Kirshenbaum & Bond, had billings estimated at $15 million. When he left in January, the agency had an office in San Francisco as well as in New York and billings estimated at $600 million. The accounts he worked on included Coach, Rockport, Snapple and Target.
Mr. Oberlander left Kirshenbaum Bond abruptly after being replaced unexpectedly by the agency's co-chairmen, Jonathan Bond and Richard Kirshenbaum, ahead of a planned reorganization. Two creative executives, Rob Feakins and Logan Wilmont, were named to assume his duties.
In an interview, Mr. Oberlander said he would prefer to "keep it about the future" rather than the past. But when asked to discuss what happened at Kirshenbaum Bond, which ignited much speculation among his colleagues and peers, he ascribed it to "partnership differences."
"Eventually, everything runs its course," Mr. Oberlander said. "It was more fun when we were younger and had less to lose. It came time."
Besides, "Ogilvy is a unique species in New York, an agency where being big doesn't make them bad," he added. "It seems the heart and soul of the agency comes out of the creative product."
As an example, Mr. Oberlander cited the Young Guns program, which he praised -- except for the name.
"Much to my chagrin," he said, laughing, "we had something at the Art Directors Club like 'Young Guns,' which we had to change to 'Young Bloods' or something."
Seriously, Mr. Oberlander said he was looking forward to helping Mr. Burrier and Mr. Boyko with the program, which recruits from places like the School for Visual Arts, the Adcenter at Virginia Commonwealth University, Creative Circus, the University of Texas at Austin and Michigan State University. One popular current campaign, the series of offbeat print ads and posters carrying the theme "Perrier in America," was produced by Young Guns teams.
"We make a promise to these young people that they won't just 'wrist out' other people's ideas," Mr. Burrier said, using a term meaning to execute something conceived by more senior employees. "It's a great way to find new talent."
Mr. Burrier and Mr. Boyko had overseen the Young Guns program with Mr. Burrier's previous art director partner, Peter Wood, who left Ogilvy New York in April to join Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmettterer/Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas Advertising, as worldwide head of art on the Volvo account.
"Peter and I were together at the agency for three and a half years," said Mr. Burrier, who joined Ogilvy New York from the Los Angeles office of BBDO. "It was just one of those found partnerships that went really well."
Asked whether he was hoping history would repeat itself in his new partnership with Mr. Oberlander, Mr. Burrier said, "Lightning strikes twice if you stick your head up high enough, or so one would hope."
Now that's a copywriter.

HEADLINE: Two Are Promoted as Enron Seeks Executive Stability 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
With its stock still suffering after the unexpected departure of its chief executive, the Enron Corporation today promoted a top official in its core energy-trading business to be the company's No. 2 executive as it begins finding new leadership.
 Greg Whalley, 39, was named president and chief operating officer. Also, the company promoted Mark A. Frevert, 46, to vice chairman. Both will join Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman and chief executive, in an office of the chairman. 
 The moves come two weeks after Jeffrey K. Skilling, a longtime protege of Mr. Lay who was the architect of Enron's wholesale energy-trading business, quit unexpectedly after just six months as chief executive. Mr. Lay, 59, has reassumed the role of chief executive and has extended his commitment to stay at the company until the end of 2005.
Mr. Skilling's departure, which he said was for "purely personal" reasons that he would not disclose, stunned investors, and the company's shares fell 14 percent in the next two days. In trading today, shares of Enron rose 40 cents, to $38.16, after peaking at $90 a year ago.
Mr. Whalley was president and chief operating officer of Enron Wholesale Services, the energy-trading unit that provides most of the company's operating income and revenue. A former officer in the Army, Mr. Whalley joined the company in 1992. He will "be somewhat more kind of the operations person on a day-to-day basis," Mr. Lay said in an interview.
Mr. Frevert was previously Mr. Whalley's boss as chairman and chief executive of Enron Wholesale Services. He started with a predecessor company to Enron, Houston Natural Gas, in 1984, and is completing a doctorate in economics from Rice University.
The announcement today clearly makes the two men, in particular Mr. Whalley, leading candidates to become chief executive, but Mr. Lay asserted that others at Enron, whom he declined to identify, were also potential successors.
"Obviously, these would be two of the people on the list," Mr. Lay said, but he said others include "various people depending on how they do the next two to three years." Finding a new chief executive, however, may take as long as four or five years, he said. "The main thing I need to convey is that I and the board are not in a big hurry on that."
In the interview, Mr. Lay said no one from Enron's board ever voiced disapproval of Mr. Skilling or in any way played a role in his departure, and Mr. Lay said that on several occasions he had asked Mr. Skilling to reconsider his decision to leave. He also said Mr. Skilling's personal reasons for leaving, while not health related, were "things with fairly short time fuses on them" and were "something he can't wait two or three years to address."
An immediate test for both Mr. Whalley and Mr. Frevert will be winning the respect and confidence of investors after the sharp slide in Enron shares this year as analysts questioned whether the company can continue to improve earnings as prices for natural gas and electricity -- its two biggest products -- have declined. The stock has also been hit by fallout from a number of missteps, including the troubled Dabhol power plant project in India and an expensive and unprofitable foray into trading telecommunications bandwidth.
Andre Meade, head of United States utilities research at Commerzbank Securities, said a chief problem was that energy trading and marketing account for a far bigger part of Enron's market capitalization than they do at other unregulated energy companies, but Enron's financial disclosures largely do not break down this business to show the profitability of different products and different regions.
"All that is compressed into one set of numbers, and it's really hard for analysts to determine where they are making money in a given quarter and where they are losing money," Mr. Meade said.
He added that Enron's having so much of its market capitalization tied up in a business that is so difficult for investors to understand "is really disconcerting."
Neither Mr. Whalley nor Mr. Frevert were available for comment, an Enron spokesman said. In the interview today, Mr. Lay, reiterating comments made to The Wall Street Journal, said he would try to make Enron's financials and business model more easily understood to investors.
"Analysts have expressed some concerns about that, and we're addressing those concerns," he said, though he added that "they'll probably never get all the information they want." Enron will break out more information on business segments and geographic results, he said, but he also said the company would probably not provide profit and loss numbers for natural gas and electricity -- by far the biggest products it trades. 
He also confirmed that Enron has "unwound" a series of complex deals it had entered into with partnerships that included Enron's chief financial officer, Andrew Fastow. The transactions had been done for hedging and tax reasons, he said.
Enron's financial statements include other complex transactions. For example, the most recent 10-K states that Enron might be required to issue new shares of common stock if the price falls below levels ranging from $28.20 to $55 because of "certain financial contracts." Enron's stock has been below $55 for the last three months, but the company has not had to issue shares, a spokesman said. Enron may end up not having to issue any shares, he said, and any that are issued are already accounted for in diluted earnings per share.

HEADLINE: Accord at VW Signals a Shift For Germany 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
Striking a blow against Germany's rigid work rules, Volkswagen reached an agreement today with the country's biggest labor union that should permit VW to demand longer workweeks and higher productivity.
 By American standards, the deal is modest and applies only to a sliver of Volkswagen's work force. But it is potentially important because it breaks out from Germany's nationwide collective-bargaining agreements and opens the door for other companies to demand customized deals. 
 It may be even more important in a negative sense: political leaders led by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder feared that if union leaders had torpedoed the talks and effectively killed 3,500 new jobs, Germany would be sending a deeply depressing message to domestic and foreign investors. 
German unemployment, which had declined the last year, hit 9.2 percent in July.
Today's agreement was reached only after talks collapsed in June and after Mr. Schroder personally pressed both sides to return to the bargaining table.
Mr. Schroder, who faces elections next year, is not expected to reach his own goal of reducing German unemployment to 3.5 million workers by the end of this year. And though he vowed to reduce unemployment through three-way discussions involving industry, labor and government, those talks produced little more than acrimony.
The Volkswagen talks began earlier this year, when VW proposed a "5,000 by 5,000" plan that would create 5,000 new jobs that paid a monthly wage of 5,000 marks (about $2,350).
The twist was that Volkswagen demanded much more flexibility than it normally had. It wanted the right to do away with overtime for anything less than 42 hours a week, and it wanted to make some of the pay dependent on reaching production targets.
IG Metall, the union that represents more than three million workers in the metal and electrical industries, treated many of those proposals as unacceptable, and talks broke down. They were revived this month, after Mr. Schroder stepped in and pressed both sides to try again.
Mr. Schroder has close ties to both sides. Before he became chancellor, he was premier of the state of Lower Saxony, where Volkswagen is based and which owns a 20 percent stake in Volkswagen. As premier, he was a member of Volkswagen's supervisory board and frequently championed its interests.
But the Social Democratic Party, Mr. Schroder's party, is also beholden to organized labor and most particularly to IG Metall, Germany's biggest union. The labor minister was previously vice chairman of IG Metall.
Today's agreement was reached after a 17-hour session that ended early this morning, and it covers only 3,500 workers because the two sides could not agree on how to treat another 1,500 workers in Hanover.
Under the agreement, Volkswagen will hire 3,500 workers to build minivans at a new factory at its headquarters in Wolfsburg. Volkswagen will be able to demand that workers put in up to 42 hours a week before being entitled to overtime.
Workers will be compensated through a system of so-called work-time accounts, which allows the company to demand up to 200 hours a year beyond its standard 35-hour workweek. That translates into as many as 30 Saturday shifts a year.
The time accounts will allow workers to put in fewer hours at other times of the year, so they still average a 35-hour week on an annualized basis. The deal may not reduce actual wages, but it should reduce overtime and give Volkswagen much more flexibility to fine-tune production.
The idea of time accounts is not new. It has been adopted in different forms by many manufacturing companies in different forms, including BMW, the maker of luxury cars based in Munich.
But Volkswagen is a much bigger and more conservative enterprise, so its bargaining effort had become a closely watched benchmark for much of German industry.
At least in theory, if workers fail to hit the company's production targets within their normal workweeks, they will have to work the extra hours without extra pay. In practice, that may never happen because the union leaders can argue that targets were missed because of company problems.
Josef-Fidelis Senn, head of Volkswagen's negotiating team, said the added flexibility would allow the new factory to save 20 percent in comparison with the standard union contract at its other German operations.
But union leaders said that they had softened Volkswagen's harshest demands and that wages at the new factory would still correspond to those set in the industrywide collective bargaining agreements.
They said Volkswagen had made a big concession on its demand that workers put in extra time if they failed to hit production targets. And while Volkswagen will be able to demand that workers put in as much as 42 hours a week, the average workweek over the course of a year should still add up to the standard 35 hours.
"We have established an example of how one can build cars while honoring the wage standards," said Jurgen Peters, vice chairman of IG Metall, at a news conference in Hanover.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Volkswagen's agreement allows it to link hours and productivity for a fraction of its employees. Workers assemble a Passat at a plant in Mosel. (Associated Press)(pg. C7)

HEADLINE: GREEN AND HEVESI EXCHANGE ATTACKS IN MAYORAL DEBATE 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
Mark Green and Alan G. Hevesi tangled over each other's ethics and credentials at a televised mayoral debate yesterday. Mr. Green questioned Mr. Hevesi's role as city comptroller in helping out a campaign contributor four years ago, while Mr. Hevesi mocked Mr. Green, the public advocate, as being unqualified to take over as New York's next mayor.
 As Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Green squabbled intermittently throughout the 60-minute session, a third candidate, Fernando Ferrer, sighed and said that viewers "must be wondering why we are talking above everyone's issues," in particular housing and schools. 
 The fourth major Democratic candidate, Peter F. Vallone, presented himself as the staid and mature government official, asserting again that Democrats should choose him to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani because Mr. Vallone had played a central role, as the City Council speaker, in pushing through programs that had improved New York's fortunes over the past 10 years. A fifth Democrat, George N. Spitz, a retired civil servant, also appeared in the debate, which was presented under the auspices of the Campaign Finance Board. 
But Mr. Green, after months of not attacking the other Democrats, surprised even his opponents by going after Mr. Hevesi. Within minutes of the opening of the debate, Mr. Green distanced himself from Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Vallone, saying that he thought it was undesirable for Mr. Hevesi to have arranged a meeting for a campaign contributor with a private business, Bell Atlantic.
Before their session was over, Mr. Green derided Democrats who "bicker among themselves with the current mayor" rather than looking to the future -- an allusion to Mr. Hevesi's weeklong fight with Mayor Giuliani. The debate came as Mr. Hevesi began broadcasting a television commercial critical of the mayor on corruption issues. Page B1. 
Mr. Green also criticized Mr. Hevesi's proposal for reforming the makeup of the Board of Education.
If Mr. Green sprinkled his typically nonconfrontational campaign appeal with occasional shots at Mr. Hevesi, the city comptroller was more intense in his approach to Mr. Green. He mocked the "small ideas" that he said Mr. Green was presenting to deal with expanding the city's public transit system, suggested that his opponent did not have the budgetary experience to deal with the fiscal problems that may await the next mayor, and said Mr. Green's biggest political strength might be his ability to get on television and into the newspapers.
"Mark Green, my good friend, is admirable when it comes to press conferences and press and asking questions and even bringing lawsuits," Mr. Hevesi said evenly, with a sidelong gaze at Mr. Green. "But being mayor of the city of New York requires experience in the global economy, it requires experience as a manager -- not running an agency of 40 people."
Mr. Hevesi's decision to go after Mr. Green had been expected by many Democrats in recent days. Mr. Green has consistently run ahead in polls leading up to the Sept. 11 primary, and Mr. Hevesi has been bunched more closely with the other two. And the comptroller has treaded some rough waters in recent days, as Mr. Giuliani has attacked him as an "ethically challenged" city comptroller; a number of Democrats have argued that Mr. Hevesi has reached a critical juncture as he seeks to handle Mr. Giuliani's attacks.
But Mr. Green's decision to go after Mr. Hevesi signaled an obvious change in strategy. It was unclear whether Mr. Green, in trying to knock back Mr. Hevesi, was worried that Mr. Hevesi's fights with Mr. Giuliani might increase his stature with Democrats in the primary, as Mr. Hevesi's aides believe. Alternatively, Mr. Green may see Mr. Hevesi's campaign as on the verge of collapsing, which would provide Mr. Green with the opportunity to win more than 40 percent of the votes, and thus avoid a runoff. If no candidate wins over 40 percent on Sept. 11, the top two vote-getters meet again in a runoff on Sept. 25.
Mr. Hevesi tripped up when a questioner asked him whether he agreed with a decision by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell not to attend a conference in South Africa on racism, because the resolution calling for the conference includes language critical of Israel. "The U.S. should be participating in a conference that deals with the issue of racism," Mr. Hevesi said, suggesting that he disagreed with Mr. Powell's decision.
After the debate, Mr. Hevesi's spokesman, Josh Isay, said that because part of the conference agenda was "equating Zionism with racism," Mr. Hevesi believed that Mr. Powell should not attend. Mr. Isay said that the comptroller was not aware of the details of the conference when he answered the question.
Mr. Vallone, in his response to the question, suggested that he approved of the decision by the Bush administration, and Mr. Ferrer said, "We have a moral obligation as a nation to speak up and speak out on human rights and civil rights abuses all over the world."
Mr. Green, afterward, laughed off Mr. Hevesi's criticism about his qualifications, and said that Mr. Hevesi was trying to run for mayor based on things he did in the State Assembly 20 years ago. "I could brush it off because the public knows of my record of results in the 90's, and can contrast it with his ads, which simply talk about bills in the 1970's and 1980's," Mr. Green said. "Let him talk about his record; I'm proud to talk about mine."
At the debate, sponsored by Newsday, WPIX-TV and WNYC-TV, in conjunction with the city's Campaign Finance Board, Mr. Hevesi accused Mr. Giuliani of trying to "smear me" and "involve himself in the Democratic primary" by attacking his ethics.
Mr. Hevesi has been criticized for arranging the meeting with a campaign contributor and Bell Atlantic, which never produced a contract between them. He has also been the subject of an unsubstantiated allegation that he took a $6,000 cash bribe to arrange the meeting; he has flatly denied that allegation.
Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Vallone both came to Mr. Hevesi's defense. Mr. Ferrer noted that Mr. Hevesi enjoyed friendly relations with Mr. Giuliani before beginning his race for mayor (a relationship that has given Mr. Hevesi some problems with Democratic leaders), but Mr. Ferrer went on to criticize Mr. Giuliani for raising questions about Mr. Hevesi's ethics.
"This is a matter of impugning someone's good name and integrity," Mr. Ferrer said. "I've known Alan for a long time. He has an unblemished record in the public service. This should not be a way in the closing days of the campaign to smear somebody's reputation."
Mr. Vallone also said he had "no question" about Mr. Hevesi's integrity, but went on to criticize him for his dispute with the Campaign Finance Board in which he sought, without success, to be permitted to have his campaign consultant and close friend, Hank Morris, work free for his campaign. Mr. Hevesi later compromised and agreed to pay Mr. Morris and then received his campaign matching funds. 
Mr. Green, who initially was silent as the dispute between Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Hevesi escalated last week, was notably more ambivalent in offering his view of it yesterday. He said he did not believe the bribery allegation, but then suggested that he operated on a higher standard in dealing with campaign contributors. "I actually can never remember using my public office to help a donor or a bundler get a private contract, which of course is not criminal, but it's, I think, undesirable," Mr. Green said.
The format of the debate included a strict 45-second limit on responses, which on a number of occasions stopped candidates in midsentence, or choked off exchanges, particularly after the moderator, Kaity Tong of WPIX-TV, warned that "if you are still talking when the red light goes on, I'm going to have to jump in and interrupt you, so don't make me go there!"
The pressure on the candidates was also lessened by Mr. Spitz's presence, which was permitted because he is enrolled with the Campaign Finance Board. Although Mr. Spitz himself describes his chances of winning as remote, he was given as much time as his opponents and espoused unconventional views like calling for the decriminalization of drugs.
The candidates all made clear, in response to an opening question, that they would protect some of the changes that had taken place under Mr. Giuliani, saying, for example, that they would not tolerate a return of squeegee men. "The Ferrer administration will not give the squeegee guys or aggressive panhandlers any reason to believe that they can harass or aggressively panhandle any New Yorker," Mr. Ferrer said.
Mr. Vallone said that he "conceived the plan" to put more police officers on the street (Mayor David N. Dinkins has disputed Mr. Vallone's recollection on that), and added, "There is absolutely no way I will let this city step back to where it was with squeegee men or anyone else."

HEADLINE: Economists Back Projection That It Will Be Necessary to Dip Into Social Security Surplus 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 

 BODY:
New budget projections from Congressional analysts and the White House show that the Bush administration and Congressional leaders are almost certain to violate their promise not to dip into the Social Security surplus to pay the government's bills, prominent economists said today.
 A White House report last week made clear that only an assortment of accounting changes -- described by Democrats as politically motivated gimmicks -- would prevent the use of Social Security to make ends meet in the budget during the rest of President Bush's four-year term. 
 And even then, the government would face an uncomfortably tight squeeze in order to leave Social Security untouched, with a margin of error of only about $1 billion, a pittance in an overall federal budget approaching $2 trillion a year.
The analysis from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office was more pessimistic. Its report, which was made public on Monday, suggested that the White House was too hopeful in its predictions about economic growth next year and about the impact of the $1.3 trillion tax-cut package that Mr. Bush pushed through Congress. 
"It appears that it's inevitable that we'll dip into the Social Security surplus," said Robert D. Reischauer of the Urban Institute, an economist who directed the Congressional Budget Office from 1989 to 1995. "From an economic standpoint, it's totally nonconsequential. But politically and symbolically, it's terribly important."
Congressional analysts found that $9 billion would need to be tapped from Social Security this year to cover shortfalls in the budget, and that $21 billion more would need to be drained from the retirement program over the next three years.
Because the Congressional analysts are required by law to make their projections on the basis of current government spending, the report does not factor in the huge spending increases that President Bush is expected to propose for the Defense Department and for his plan to develop a national missile-defense system. The price tag of those programs could approach $300 billion over the next 10 years.
It does not take into account the proposals from both parties for a prescription-drug benefit -- at least $200 billion over 10 years -- or for an expanded federal role in education, a signature issue for President Bush; it does not include the billions of dollars that Republican and Democratic lawmakers will want to set aside for hometown projects when next year's federal budget is completed this fall.
Allen Sinai of Primark Decision Economics in New York said today that the administration could avoid using Social Security revenues to cover other costs only "if the economy turned on a dime and suddenly began to grow faster -- and that's highly unlikely."
Mr. Sinai said the president's tax-cut package -- and more important, the souring economy -- had "torpedoed the budget surplus, which is really going to guarantee that the government will be dipping into Social Security funds."
The effect of even a large diversion of the Social Security surplus to other government programs does not threaten the current benefits received by more than 30 million retired workers and their dependents. For decades, the government used the surplus to pay off its other bills.
But any diversion is a violation of a fundamental promise made by both political parties during last year's presidential campaign. Republicans and Democrats promised in their platforms that the Social Security surplus would never be touched.
The Democratic candidate, Vice President Al Gore, was parodied for referring again and again in the campaign to the need for a "lockbox" to protect revenues paid to the government in Social Security taxes.
Mr. Bush used different words but made a similar promise.
"Our greatest generation deserves our greatest respect," he said as a candidate in December 1999. "This begins by keeping our word. We must reserve the Social Security surplus for Social Security itself."
In a campaign speech in May last year in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., Mr. Bush said that "for years, politicians in both parties have dipped into the trust fund to pay for more spending -- and I will stop it."
In the House in February, 211 Republicans joined with 194 Democrats to pass the "Social Security and Medicare Lockbox Act," which barred the use of Social Security surpluses for other spending. 
"We assure the American people that tax relief will not come at the expenses of Medicare or Social Security," Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois said at the time on behalf of the House Republican leadership.
Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, said the president would keep his word to preserve the Social Security surplus, if only by forcing Congress to make deep cuts in federal spending.
"The president has made it clear that he's going to control spending," Mr. Gilmore said today in a telephone interview from Ohio, where he traveled as part of his national "honesty tour" to defend the administration's budget record.
Mr. Bush would not allow Congress to "blow the lid off the budget through spending," he said.

HEADLINE: Maybe We've Just About Hit Bottom 

BYLINE:  By Ian C. Shepherdson; Ian C. Shepherdson is the chief American economist at High Frequency Economics, an independent research company.

DATELINE: VALHALLA, N.Y. 

 BODY:
The economic news this month looks bad enough to turn even an inveterate optimist into a pessimist. Gateway announced that it would lay off one-quarter of its work force, Lucent told 2,200 workers in the United States that they would lose their jobs, and at least 21 dot-coms shut their doors for good.
 If this unpleasant news continues over the next few months, driving up the unemployment rate, many say that there will be a further slowdown in consumer spending (by far the biggest component of the American economy). But this is not necessarily true. Although the future might seem grim for the newly unemployed, what is true of individuals is not necessarily true of the economy as a whole. 
 Yes, unemployment, which had been at a 31-year low of 3.9 percent, has been climbing since late last year. It now stands at 4.5 percent and will probably rise further. But this figure doesn't tell us that much. Rising unemployment is a consequence, not a cause, of an economic slowdown. For instance, the economy began to recover from recession in the second quarter of 1991, but unemployment continued to rise until mid-1992.
There are signs that we are at a similar point now -- at or approaching the bottom of the economic cycle. In polls taken over the past few months by the Conference Board, respondents have become more gloomy about the current state of the economy, but they have become more optimistic about the future. The number of people expecting the employment picture to brighten over the next six months has also risen. 
For most people, the important economic story of the moment is probably not the rising unemployment rate. Instead, most may be focusing on the stock market, which is volatile but not plunging, and they may be expecting the actions of the Federal Reserve, which has been cutting interest rates aggressively, to turn the economy around. Tax rebates have also probably lifted expectations.
Those of a gloomy disposition often argue that people are carrying much more debt than ever before, which might slow growth in consumer spending as unemployment rises. But consumer debt is only half the story. Consumers' debt has risen by nearly $4 trillion over the past 10 years, but their assets -- even after the plunge in the Nasdaq -- have risen by more than $20 trillion. Overwhelmed by debt? It doesn't look that way to the dispassionate eye.
Pessimists also claim that recovery will be delayed because the Fed's reductions in short-term interest rates have not been followed by significant declines in long-term rates, which affect mortgages and borrowing costs for companies. But the markets anticipated the economic slowdown well before the Fed did and drove these rates down in advance of the Fed's actions. The average 30-year mortgage rate, for example, is now just under 7 percent. This is only a quarter-point or so lower than when the Fed first cut rates in January, but it is more than a full point lower than the rate a year ago. No wonder the housing market is so strong.
Meanwhile, in the industrial sector, unwanted inventory -- everything from shoes to refrigerators to raw materials -- is now disappearing fast. Over the past six months, companies have reduced their stocks of durable goods like computers and cars at a very rapid 7.7 percent annualized rate, and they now hold less inventory than they did a year ago. In the past, inventory reductions at this pace have always signaled strong rebounds in production within a few months.
This will do little immediately to address the other problem facing manufacturers, particularly in the technology sector -- what to do with the now-idle factories and equipment they bought in the late 1990's. These investments helped drive economic growth to an average of 4.2 percent between 1997 and 2000, but as the past year has clearly shown, growth at that pace cannot be maintained for long.
A return to growth of about 3 percent would be great news by all but the crazy standards of the dot-com boom, and it is within reach -- rising unemployment or not.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Sun Expects Another Losing Quarter

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
Sun Microsystems said today that it expected to report its second consecutive quarterly loss because demand for its products had continued to fall.
 Sun, which makes computer server systems, warned Wall Street that its operating expenses for its first fiscal quarter would probably exceed its revenue, even though it has cut spending. Citing a sharper-than-expected decline in sales in Japan and Europe, the company said its revenue goal of $3.7 billion seemed out of reach. 
 "It will take a very large month of September, in terms of demand, in order for us to hit the break-even point," Michael E. Lehman, the chief financial officer of Sun, said in a conference call with analysts. "At this date, I would not count on that happening."
Mr. Lehman did note that orders taken in the United States lagged the company's expectation only slightly.
Wall Street expected a first-quarter profit of 2 cents a share on revenue of $3.8 billion, according to a poll of analysts by Thomson Financial/First Call.
In trading ahead of the announcement, shares of Sun fell 13 cents, to $13.43. Shares fell to $12.76 in after-hours trading.
After reaping the benefits of exuberant spending by telecommunications providers and dot-coms in 2000, Sun is suffering from the sharply cut budgets -- or even bankruptcies -- of those customers. The downturn arrived at a time when Sun was introducing new servers and storage systems. The new products on the horizon give customers another reason to wait to buy.
Anticipating the introduction of those new systems, Mr. Lehman said he expected a noticeable improvement next quarter.
Sun, based in Palo Alto., Calif., reported its first quarterly loss since 1989 last month, but predicted that it would at least break even with $3.7 billion in revenue this quarter, which ends on Sept. 28. Despite today's warning, Mr. Lehman said, the company will not cut research and development to try to weather the downturn better.
"We are consciously willing to sacrifice maximization of near-term earnings to protect key investments," he said.
Thomas D. Kraemer, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, applauded Mr. Lehman's priorities, saying that "cutting R.& D. would be like using leeches to cure a disease." But Mr. Kraemer, who before the conference call cut his estimate on Sun to a loss of 2 cents a share from a penny-a-share loss, said Sun might have to start laying off employees to keep its business plan in line with today's economic reality.
Earlier this month, Sun said that fewer than 2 percent of its 43,000 workers would lose their jobs, but that some would remain within the company in new roles. So far, Sun is one of the few high-technology companies that have refrained from widespread layoffs.

HEADLINE: Gasoline Prices Jump in Midwest, Hinting of Wider Spikes 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
Starting out on a day of shopping, Barbara Graivier stopped at her local Amoco gas station in downtown Chicago and found that prices had jumped again.
 "Oh, my God," she said, staring at the price of $2.10 a gallon for regular unleaded gasoline. "I was here last weekend and it was $1.99. This is just ridiculous." 
 Nearly everyone that came through the Amoco station this afternoon said the same thing. Kristen Gruidl put just $7 worth of gas in her Jeep Wrangler because of the high prices. Another man bought $10 worth of gas, about four and a half gallons, enough to get to the airport in his Honda Accord. "This is crazy," he said, speeding away.
The reaction is similar across the Midwest, where gas prices are soaring ahead of the busy Labor Day weekend, reviving motorists' suspicions that price-gouging may be taking place. Tight supplies in the Midwest are also raising the prospect that other regions could be hit with higher prices later in the year, if refiners shift production capacity away from diesel or heating oil to meet gasoline demand.
Here in Chicago, a volatile summer for motorists is closing out with the highest prices in the nation. Gas prices climbed in the days leading up to the Memorial Day weekend, then dipped sharply going into the July 4 weekend. Since then, the price of regular gasoline has shot up about 50 cents a gallon, with much of that rise coming over the last month.
Energy analysts and government officials dismiss the notion that refiners or gas station operators are profiteering as the summer driving season ends. Spikes above $2 a gallon last summer led to federal investigations that found little evidence of price-gouging, and experts say that seems to be the case now, too.
"We're of the opinion nothing strange is going on," said Joanne Shore, a senior analyst at the Energy Information Administration. "There's no evidence of unusual market behavior. All the increases and the decreases in wholesale prices get passed through."
Instead, experts are blaming tight inventories in the Midwest and a fire earlier this month that disabled a giant Citgo gas refinery in Lemont, Ill. The fire has made it difficult to supply major hubs like Chicago and Milwaukee with the special blends of reformulated gasoline that are required by law in those cities.
Yesterday, the Environmental Protection Agency tried to ease the bottleneck by granting a waiver to Citgo so that the company could speed a more widely available gas blend to market. Refineries in the Gulf Coast are scrambling to meet the Midwest's demand, diverting supplies that would otherwise be shipped to other parts of the country. But that is not an easy fix, because pipelines -- the least expensive means for shipping fuels between regions -- are already full. 
"If we have supply disruptions here in Chicago, we can't just run next door to Iowa or Indiana; you have a special blend here," said Tom Mueller, a spokesman at BP, the British oil company that merged with Amoco. "The last couple of years, the pipelines have been full, and you have jet fuel, diesel and gasoline coming up; it's all scheduled well in advance."
So while much of the nation is benefiting from relatively stable gas prices that average about $1.48 a gallon of regular unleaded gas, the average price in the Midwest jumped to $1.69 a gallon last week. 
In Chicago, government statistics indicate that the average price spiked to $1.79 a gallon. But do not tell that to consumers or gas station managers here. Prices seem to be rising faster than number crunchers can calculate.
"The average price now is about $2," insisted Sultan Noorullah, one of the owners of an Amoco station in Rogers Park, a northern Chicago neighborhood.
Several other Chicago gas station managers agreed. In a random survey of 10 gas stations in Chicago, all reached by telephone today, the average price was reported to be $1.99 a gallon, with prices at several stations in the more affluent areas hovering near $2.10 a gallon.
"This is a perfect example of what we've been saying for two years," said Geoff Sundstrom, a spokesman for AAA. "The U.S. simply does not have enough refining capacity to meet the growing demand for gasoline."
Most analysts do not expect the spike in gas prices here to last much beyond the Labor Day weekend, because the holiday signals the end to the busy summer driving season. But the region's capacity problems could reverberate for months. 
The Citgo refinery in Lemont normally processes about 163,000 barrels a day, accounting for 5 percent of the region's gasoline, and it is not expected to restart for six months. Meanwhile, a government report released today showed that gasoline stocks in the Midwest fell sharply last week, to 48 million barrels, the lowest level in a decade. And distillate stocks, including diesel and heating oil, are also low, hinting at higher diesel and home heating oil prices in the fall and winter.
"In the Midwest, we're going into the high demand season and the stocks are off about 20 percent," said Jake Bournazian, an energy economist at the Energy Information Administration. "This could be very bad for farmers. Their fuel costs could be very high."
So there is little leeway for further bad news. "Distillate levels have been flat at a time when they should be rising," said Jay Saunders, an energy analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "We don't think they're at levels to be overly concerned about, but another refinery outage or a cold spell in November could mean pretty high heating oil prices."
