HEADLINE: Ferrer the Campaigner Offers an Old-Style Approach 

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

 BODY:
It was a muggy evening at the Calvary Baptist Church in Queens when Fernando Ferrer, the Democratic mayoral candidate, grasped the microphone and stood up. Alive with promises of deliverance, booming like a prophet from his party's past, he took a few minutes to go through millions of dollars.
 "Pay them like professionals!" Mr. Ferrer exclaimed, pushing his 30 percent pay raise for the city's teachers. 
 "The most ambitious housing plan this city has ever seen!" he said, promising 150,000 new homes at this mayoral forum. 
"After-school programs at 200 middle schools!" he added.
"Hallelujah," someone called from in the pews, and the others whooped and clapped.
As he crisscrosses the city seeking the Democratic party's nomination for mayor, Mr. Ferrer is proudly carrying the hopes of his party's oldest and most orthodox wing. In stump speeches and neighborhood tours, Mr. Ferrer, 51, often seems like a candidate from another era, the old-style populist coaxing votes from the city's precincts with promises of government largess. 
Earlier this month, Mr. Ferrer stood among the Rolando Paulino All-Stars -- the Bronx team that finished third in the Little League World Series last weekend in Williamsport, Pa. -- as the players, coaches and supporters waited for a bus to take them to an earlier-round game in Bristol, Conn. The bus came courtesy of Mr. Ferrer and the treasury of his Bronx borough, where Mr. Ferrer has been the president since 1987. Cost to taxpayers: about $700. 
"Numero uno!" Mr. Ferrer shouted as he stood among the young baseball players. "Numero uno!" 
Even if it had nothing to do with Mr. Ferrer's mayoral aspirations, the favor was not lost on the team's supporters who are old enough to vote. "Mr. Ferrer is always there for us," said Joan Dalmau, a league volunteer, as she climbed into the air-conditioned bus. "Always."
Mr. Ferrer was there again for them yesterday, leading the cheers when the Little Leaguers were honored in a daylong celebration throughout the city.
Mr. Ferrer's liberal election platform is part of his vision to reach out to what he calls the "other New York" -- the millions of residents he says have been left out of the city's economic boom and alienated by the policies of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. 
Mr. Ferrer said most of his initiatives could be paid for without new taxes. In lieu of specifics, he typically offered his hard-scrabble childhood in the South Bronx as proof of his sincerity. 
"When I talk about affordable housing, it comes from the perspective of a kid who grew up in a five-story walk-up without heat and hot water," Mr. Ferrer told the church crowd in Jamaica, Queens. "I want New Yorkers to know where I came from." 
Mr. Ferrer's pitch seemed to resonate with many likely voters, especially those in the city's minority communities. 
"I thought Mr. Ferrer was very down to earth," said Chris Durham, who attended the mayoral forum at the church. "I had to endure things like that myself. You have to have been there to know what he is talking about."
While Mr. Ferrer talks often about his roots in the South Bronx, he rarely makes direct ethnic appeals, even before friendly audiences. 
"I guess I'm not breaking any new ground here tonight by telling you I am a Puerto Rican from the Bronx," Mr. Ferrer told a crowd at the Madison Avenue United Methodist Church in Harlem. "But if that is the only reason that you are going to vote for me, wrong reason, wrong reason. Go back to the drawing board and think again."
Mr. Ferrer clearly believes that "the other New York" is everywhere -- not just in the South Bronx, but in the city's more robust neighborhoods as well. Even there, Mr. Ferrer's pitch never wavers.
During a recent meeting at a Polish-American club in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Mr. Ferrer seemed to offer himself a chance to back away from his expensive vision. Instead, he congratulated himself for it. 
"Some people say I'm just another tax-and-spend liberal," Mr. Ferrer said at the John Smolenski Memorial Democratic Club. "That means I'm willing to stand up for what I believe in."
It is in these middle-class neighborhoods where Mr. Ferrer's populist pitch sometimes falters. In the wood-paneled confines of the Polish-American club, Mr. Ferrer wheeled out his usual stump speech, with promises of health care, housing and teacher pay raises. He departed without taking questions, prompting some to wish that Mr. Ferrer had stayed to listen to their worries about a new power plant that may be built nearby. 
"I'm not convinced," said Dr. Jolanta Kulpa-Subernat, a pediatrician who lives in Greenpoint. "He's certainly sincere. But what he said didn't relate to our neighborhood."
It often seems that Mr. Ferrer is trying to meet each of New York's voters before the Sept. 11 primary. He often starts his day at dawn, shaking hands with commuters, bleary-eyed and caffeinated alike, at some far-flung subway stop. Then, typically, he heads to one of a half-dozen events in any of the city's five boroughs -- a black church in Brooklyn, a parade in the Bronx, a lunch in Staten Island, a news conference at City Hall. Like most of the mayoral candidates, Mr. Ferrer is perpetually behind schedule, arriving late, leaving early, always apologizing. 
But he almost never fails to show up. His black limousine raced to its final destination of the day, the rooftop of the Brooklyn Children's Museum, where a group of Lubavitcher Jews was holding a barbecue to raise money for their schools. Mr. Ferrer was supposed to arrive at the tail end of the event, at 9:30 p.m. But it was 10:30 p.m. before he finally pulled up, and a handful of the event's organizers greeted him with a cold beer and a kebab off the grill. 
"I can't tell you his positions on all the issues, but as a judge of people and character, I can tell you that Freddy is very, very straight," said Rabbi Yitzchok Hecht, as he scraped the charcoal from the grill. "Freddy is a good friend of the yeshiva. We think he's a mensch."

HEADLINE: United States Backs Plan to Help Chinese Evade Government Censorship of Web 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
The United States government agencies that once tried to breach the Iron Curtain with radio broadcasts are taking the information war to the Internet, hoping to finance an American-based computer network designed to thwart attempts by the Chinese government to censor the World Wide Web for users in China.
 Government officials and private architects of the plan say the program would be financed by the International Broadcasting Bureau, parent agency of the Voice of America, which has been presenting the American view abroad -- mostly by radio -- for decades. It would mark a significant expansion of the long-running information war between China and the United States. 
 The agency is in advanced discussions with Safeweb, a small company based in Emeryville, Calif., which has received financing from the venture capital arm of the Central Intelligence Agency, In-Q-Tel. The discussions were confirmed by parties on both sides. 
Safeweb currently runs its own worldwide network of about 100 privacy servers -- computers that help disguise what Web sites a user is seeking to view -- which are popular with users in China. The privacy servers have been a continuing target for the Chinese government, which has blocked most of them in recent weeks.
The bureau would provide money for new computers to run Safeweb software specifically tailored for the Chinese audience and intended to be more resistant to blocking by the government. It would also cover some of the costs of network bandwidth to carry the the Internet traffic, but would not act as host for the computers itself.
The plan would initially pay for around a dozen computers, with an option to grow to a larger number after the new federal fiscal year begins on Oct. 1. The project would be financed from a Congressional allocation of $5 million last year intended to improve broadcasting to China, including both Internet and radio. Of that $5 million, $800,000 was approved for "Internet and multimedia enhancement," some of which is scheduled for use on this project. 
"We recognized that we have an obligation to reach out to our audience in ways that are effective, that includes the Internet," said Tish King, a spokeswoman for the International Broadcasting Bureau.
To that end, Voice of America also started VOANews.com to make news available worldwide on the Internet. Currently, audio broadcasts in over 53 languages are streamed live and archived on the site. Text is archived in almost all the languages.
Voice of America has been developing an Internet strategy to reach an audience in China with a daily newsletter in Chinese that is e-mailed to 180,000 people and a Chinese-language news Web site.
In addition to a Chinese-language Web site, Radio Free Asia also maintains Web sites aimed at ethnic minority groups in China like Tibetans and Uighurs, who are concentrated in the northwest region of Xinjiang.
But the Chinese government has sporadically jammed the radio broadcasts from Voice of America since 1989 and from Radio Free Asia since 1997, a year after it began, specifically those in Mandarin and Tibetan. The government has also blocked the Chinese-language Web sites of Voice of America since 1997 and Radio Free Asia almost since it began in 1998.
For Chinese leaders, the Internet is a doubled-edged sword, a rapidly evolving medium that brings economic opportunity but remains beyond complete control.
Internet use in China is growing dramatically, seeping from urban universities and businesses to homes and affordable Internet cafes all over the country. The Chinese government estimates there were over 26 million Internet users in July, compared to only 9 million at the end of 1999.
Periodically, the government tries new ways to tighten control, including police raids. Since April the government has waged a campaign to shut down thousands of unlicensed Internet cafes, and the government has publicized the arrests of over a dozen "Internet dissidents" over the last three years.
The government maintains an elaborate set of rules that requires Internet service providers to electronically filter content that may be pornographic, anti-government, violent, unhealthy or superstitious.
Among sites that are blocked for the vast majority of users are those of The Washington Post, Amnesty International and various sites identifying with the Falun Gong spiritual movement, which the Chinese government has accused of being a cult. However, users can access other news sites including ABCnews.com, the British Broadcasting Corporation and USA Today. 
Until early this month, the site for The New York Times on the Web was blocked. The blocking was lifted after an interview with President Jiang Zemin by top editors at The Times in which President Jiang was specifically questioned about the blocking of the site. 
Chinese Web users have nevertheless found methods to get around the censorship. In a recent study by researchers at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in Beijing, more than a quarter of Internet users admitted to occasionally using Internet proxy computers, which work similarly to those of Safeweb, while 10 percent admitted to frequent use. That was much higher than was expected, said Guo Liang, one of the researchers.
Among the most popular masquerade services is Safeweb, an 18-month-old company. The technology, dubbed Triangle Boy (after a character in an episode of the sitcom "Seinfeld"), can fool an electronic filter into thinking Web content is coming from a benign computer server instead of a blocked site like Human Rights Watch.
But the service has become a target for the Chinese government, which has engaged in a cat-and-mouse game with Safeweb.
"They are becoming increasingly aggressive," said Stephen Hsu, chief executive of Safeweb. "We get these frantic e-mails from users saying they are totally cut off now."
In addition, Safeweb says, the Chinese government is now blocking e-mail sent to users who request Triangle Boy e-mail addresses. As a response, Safeweb is encouraging users to sign up for free Web-based e-mail accounts at non-Chinese services like Hotmail and Yahoo.
Part of the proposal being financed by the International Broadcasting Bureau would have the Triangle Boy servers change their Internet addresses on a regular basis -- perhaps as frequently as every few hours -- to make them more difficult for the Chinese government to find and block.
Despite government efforts to rein in the Internet, it is playing an emerging political role in China. The study by the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, one of the most rigorous Internet studies in China to date, found that 67.5 percent of adult users believe the Internet gives people more opportunity to criticize government policies. And more than 74 percent agree the Internet allows people to "express their political views" and to learn about politics.
"We want to force the Chinese government to accept the pro-democracy consequences of the Internet," said Dr. Hsu. "Up until now the Chinese government has been amazingly successful at having their cake and eating it too."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Economy Edges Up 0.2%, Bolstered by Consumers
The American economy grew more slowly in the second quarter than at any time in eight years, the Commerce Department reported. Still, the new numbers suggested that if consumers continue to spend at their present level, the nation may avoid a recession.
 Instead of shrinking in the second quarter, as many forecasters had feared, the nation's output of goods and services rose by 0.2 percent at an annual rate. Consumers kept the economy above water, stepping up their spending in the spring and early summer -- and, possibly, setting the stage for stronger growth in the current quarter. Page A1. 

Stocks Slump on Economic Data
Stocks fell sharply on the report of economic growth. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 131.13 points, or 1.3 percent, to 10,090.90. The Nasdaq composite index fell 21.81 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,843.17, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 12.91 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,148.60. C7.

Official to Review Pilot Allegations
The inspector general of the Transportation Department has agreed to review allegations that the Federal Aviation Administration failed to enforce safety regulations at American Airlines. It is the latest chapter in an increasingly bitter battle over the working conditions of airline pilots. C4.

Judge Begins Latest Microsoft Case
Taking her first action in the Microsoft antitrust case, Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly ordered lawyers for the government and the company to confer and jointly prepare a report outlining the remaining issues in the case and procedures to resolve them. The judge gave the two sides two weeks to come up with the status report and said she would meet with lawyers on Sept. 21. C4.

Sun Expects to Post Quarterly Loss
Sun Microsystems said that it expected to report its second consecutive quarterly loss because demand for its products has continued to fall. It also said that its revenue goal of $3.7 billion seemed out of reach. C4.

Air Bags Killing Fewer Children
Air bags are killing fewer children than they did five years ago, government data show, and safety experts give most of the credit to parents who are keeping children 12 years old and younger out of the front seat. A12.

Profit Falls 23% at Credit Suisse
Credit Suisse said that losses on private equity investments, dwindling income from investment banking fees and the high costs of integrating an acquisition depressed its profit by 23 percent in the second quarter. Lukas Muhlemann, chairman and chief executive, said he foresaw little change in third-quarter profit. Executives said they hoped to continue paring costs. World Business, Section W.

Samsung and Toshiba Weigh Link
Samsung Electronics of South Korea said that it was considering a proposal to take over semiconductor manufacturing from Toshiba of Japan. World Business, Section W.

Paper Maker Reports a Gain
The Jefferson Smurfit Group, a paper and packaging manufacturer, reported slight growth in first-half revenue and profit, as the downturn in the United States offset gains in Europe. World Business, Section W.

New Economy Loses More Luster
Recent revisions to productivity data reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics show how thin new-economy thinking has been all along. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Computer Associates Directors Survive Challenge

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

DATELINE: ISLANDIA, N.Y., Aug. 29 

 BODY:
Computer Associates International soundly defeated an effort yesterday by the dissident investor Sam Wyly to replace four directors, including Charles Wang, the company's founder and chairman.
 At least 60 percent of the shares were voted in favor of the current board, while fewer than 20 percent were cast for Mr. Wyly's slate, Computer Associates said. The remaining shareholders abstained. 
 "The entire C.A. slate has been re-elected," the company treasurer, Michael A. McElroy, said at 10:40 a.m. at Computer Associates' annual meeting yesterday, as a ballroom full of Computer Associates shareholders and employees erupted in robust applause. More than 1,500 people, mostly supporters of the company, attended the meeting, which was held in a hotel across from the company's headquarters on Long Island.
"So I guess we know what we're going to do tomorrow," Mr. Wang said after the applause died down.
The announcement turned what had been a tense gathering into a corporate pep rally, punctuated by several long waves of applause for Mr. Wang and Sanjay Kumar, the chief executive. 
"We should all get down on our hands and knees and kiss the ground that they walk on," one shareholder bubbled during the question-and-answer session. "I love you, too, Dad," Mr. Wang said.
The vote's outcome did not come as a shock. Nearly 30 percent of the company's shares had been pledged to the incumbent board since the fight began. As a result, Mr. Wyly's investment company, Ranger Governance, would have had to win more than 70 percent of the remaining shares to oust Mr. Wang. 
Still, the size of the company's victory was unexpected. Mr. Wyly, a 65-year-old Texas billionaire, had spent about $10 million this summer to argue that the company needed a new direction after a half-decade in which its stock underperformed both the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and other software companies.
Those arguments seemed to resonate with advocates of corporate governance. Mr. Wyly's bid was supported by Institutional Shareholder Services and by Proxy Monitor, which advise investors how to vote in proxy fights. The California Public Employees Retirement System, the nation's largest pension fund, also supported Mr. Wyly. 
Computer Associates has had credibility problems on Wall Street at least since 1998, when it announced a huge revenue shortfall shortly after giving its three top executives a $1.1 billion bonus. Last October, the company confounded investors again by changing its accounting practices, making it all but impossible for investors to compare current results with those of previous years. Under standard accounting rules, Computer Associates will lose more than $1 billion this year.
But Mr. Wang and Mr. Kumar apparently convinced investors that Ranger's proposal would have left the company with a divided board and complicated its turnaround efforts. The company's largest investors, including Fidelity Investments, the Boston mutual fund giant, which owns more than 10 percent of Computer Associates, overwhelmingly supported the current board.
As for small investors, at least those at the meeting said they were satisfied with Computer Associates' management and suspicious of Mr. Wyly's motives. "I thought his ideas were not good for the company," a shareholder, Melvin Young, said.
In addition, shareholders who lived on Long Island said they feared Mr. Wyly would move Computer Associates' headquarters to Texas, where he lives. Computer Associates is "good for the Long Island economy," said Nina Smith, a retired teacher who lives in Huntington.
Computer Associates shares fell 71 cents, to $32, yesterday.
At a news conference after the meeting, Mr. Wang called the proxy battle "a rather sobering experience." He said he believed that Computer Associates needed to reach out to investors, the media and clients. "The main takeaway for me is we need to continue to communicate all the things we're doing for our customers."
Mr. Wang also urged Mr. Wyly to respect the shareholders' decision. "We hope he goes away and lets us continue to build our business," Mr. Wang said. "There is no plan to call him, there is no plan to meet with him."
But Mr. Wyly may not be finished jousting with Mr. Wang. Only a few minutes after Mr. Wang called for Mr. Wyly to disappear, Mr. Wyly held his own news conference to vow that Ranger would continue to monitor Computer Associates. 
Mr. Wyly said that Mr. Kumar had promised institutional shareholders in the days before the vote that within a few months it would replace at least 2 of its 10 board members with new directors. After winning the vote, the company has already begun to back off that pledge, Mr. Wyly said.
"There's a question of performance -- will they perform," Mr. Wyly said in a telephone interview yesterday. "If they don't keep the promises, they're probably looking at another challenge."
Mr. Kumar said Computer Associates planned to appoint new directors. But he said he had never promised publicly or privately that current board members would resign if new members were added. In an article last Friday, Newsday quoted Mr. Kumar saying, "There are people on the current board who have said, if new people come on, that they have done their service to shareholders."
"We have not made any assurance to anyone that any director will leave," Mr. Kumar said yesterday. He added that he expected all the current directors to serve at least until the company's next annual meeting.

HEADLINE: Data Suggests Weak Growth, Not a Recession 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The American economy grew more slowly in the second quarter than at any time in eight years, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Still, the new numbers suggested to many economists that if consumers continued to spend at their present level, the nation could avoid a recession.
 Instead of shrinking in the second quarter, as many forecasters had feared, the nation's output of goods and services rose 0.2 percent, at an annual rate, the government said. Consumers kept the economy above water, stepping up their spending in the spring and early summer -- and, possibly, setting the stage for stronger growth in the current quarter. 
 Because consumers purchased a lot of merchandise that was already sitting on shelves, inventories fell $38.4 billion, a much bigger reduction than the Commerce Department had originally thought. That suggests merchants now may have to begin placing new orders to restock their shelves. If so, the stepped-up industrial production needed to fill the new orders would give the economy a lift. 
That was the widely shared hope yesterday, even though stock prices fell after an initial rally. Page C7. 
"The mix was pretty favorable," said Peter Hooper, chief domestic economist at Deutsche Bank North America.
"The inventory sell-off was more than we thought it would be, and that paves the way for a pickup," he added
For a nation braced for the start of a recession, the Commerce Department's announcement that the economy grew at all in the second quarter was in itself a lift, even though the gain was smaller than the department's initial estimate last month that output had expanded 0.7 percent in the April-to-June period.
Analysts said the new report suggested that the country might in time look back on a slowdown that lasted many months. It has already lasted since the spring of last year, when the boom suddenly gave way to tepid growth of less than 2 percent in each of the last four quarters.
"My best guess is that we will see a small positive number for the third quarter, maybe about 1 percent, possibly a bit more," said Dean Baker, an economist at the Center for Economic and Policy Research. 
Other forecasters, more optimistic than Mr. Baker, predicted that growth would reach 2 percent in the current quarter.
That would be a substantial improvement on the minuscule growth in the second quarter, but not enough to stop the layoffs and shrinking corporate profits that have been hallmarks of the weak economy over the last year. 
"We have $40 billion in tax rebate checks to support the consumer in the coming weeks," noted Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch.
Stock prices initially rose on the news that the gross domestic product had managed to expand in the second quarter rather than contract. Several Wall Street analysts suggested that the growth, although slight, would suppress talk of recession in the media, and the worries that such speculation spurs. But a sell-off soon developed, perhaps in response to less happy details in the Commerce Department's latest report. The Dow Jones Industrial average fell 131.13 points, or 1.28 percent, to close at 10,090.9, its lowest level since April 11. The Nasdaq was down 21.81 points, or 1.17 percent.
Corporate profits, which had shot up in the late 1990's, declined for the third consecutive quarter. Pretax profits were 14.7 percent below their levels in June of last year. 
Capital spending, also a big source of strength in the booming 1990's, declined for the second consecutive quarter, shrinking at an unusually large annual rate of 14.6 percent. That was slightly more than the 13.6 percent drop in the government's original estimate last month. With profits shrinking, there is not much incentive to invest in new computers, machinery and all the other tools used to produce goods and services. 
Still, profits fell more slowly in the second quarter than in the first -- a 3.6 percent drop versus 6.8 percent. "I would interpret that as fairly rosy compared with where we were in the winter and spring," said Brent Moulton, director of the division that calculates the gross domestic product at the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis.
A broad inflation index that is included in the output report -- a broader measure than the widely cited Consumer Price Index -- suggested that the inflation rate was inching down. The index of gross domestic purchase prices, which covers purchases by households, business and government, rose at a very mild 1.4 percent annual rate in the second quarter compared with 2.7 percent in the first. 
A falling inflation rate removes an obstacle to further reductions in interest rates when the Federal Reserve's policy makers meet again in October. To spur borrowing and encourage spending, the Fed has already cut short-term interest rates seven times since January. 
There were other drags on the economy. With growth slowing in Europe and Asia, exports from the United States fell more than originally estimated. And government spending was slightly weaker than originally thought, particularly at the state and local levels. 
Even more troubling, in Mr. Hooper's view, market indexes, having drifted down in recent weeks, are near their lows of last spring.
"If stock prices drop noticeably more, then the likelihood of consumers' continuing to expand their spending, even at the moderate second-quarter pace of 2.5 percent a year, goes down," he said. "And if consumer spending stops growing, that means either that inventories will go up tremendously or firms will have to cut production."
Other analysts noted that if many employers emulate the Ford Motor Company's newly announced decision to eliminate executive bonuses, such actions could also translate into a drop in consumer spending.
So far, though, consumers do not seem to be pulling back. Retail sales, for example, rose in July, except for motor vehicles. And factory production, which had been falling for months, stopped doing so last month. Meanwhile, American workers' wages continued to rise in the second quarter faster than inflation. 
"As long as the consumer holds up," Mr. Hooper said, "we are likely to see this sort of improvement."

HEADLINE: Ford Motor Will Not Pay Annual Bonus ToManagers 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 29 

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company, which is struggling with falling auto sales and the Firestone tire recall, said today that it would not pay bonuses this year to 6,000 middle-level and senior managers, including its chief executive, Jacques A. Nasser.
 This would be the first time since 1992 that Ford has not paid bonuses to executives. The announcement came months earlier than usual for major corporations to act on executive compensation. Most companies generally do not decide the level of executive bonuses until late in the fourth quarter, when they are able to gauge full-year financial results. 
 Ford bases its bonuses primarily on whether the company meets profitability and customer satisfaction goals, NickSharkey, a company spokesman, said. The automaker paid $440 million in bonuses in 2001, or about $75,000 per eligible employee. Mr. Nasser received a $7.7 million bonus last year, as part of his total compensation of $17.8 million.
Ford's action increased concern among economists that other companies might quickly take similar steps, using the sluggish economy as an excuse. If so, the impact could go far beyond the executive suite, because many companies' employee compensation plans, like profit-sharing, are tied to the same financial criteria as payments to executives.
As much as $30 billion is paid out each year in variable employee compensation, including executive bonuses, said Richard Berner, chief United States economist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. The three big Detroit auto companies paid $1 billion last year in employee and executive compensation. Half of it went to members of the United Auto Workers union, who receive profit sharing under their contracts with the auto companies. That $1 billion is the equivalent of 2.6 percent of the companies' annual payrolls. 
If more companies decrease compensation plans, "the slump in corporate profits will thus translate into a bigger hit to consumer incomes than in the past," Mr. Berner said. "The question is how big. It's one of those things that makes you think consumer spending growth will be restrained in the future."
Word of Ford's decision not to give a bonus to managers took a while to trickle out. Ford's top 300 executives learned of the decision on Aug. 1, in a memorandum from David Murphy, the Ford executive vice president who is in charge of human resources. Mr. Sharkey said it was left to those executives to share the news with their subordinates, either personally or in memos.
The move, which was not announced publicly by Ford, was reported yesterday in The Detroit News and confirmed by the company.
Mr. Sharkey said the company decided to take the action after Mr. Nasser and other senior managers reviewed the automaker's second-quarter results, which it reported on July 18. The company lost $550 million, including a $2.1 billion after-tax charge to replace Firestone tires on a range of vehicles, including the Ford Explorer. Since August of last year, Ford has replaced 14 million Firestone tires and it is facing many lawsuits from consumers over accidents involving the Explorer.
Ford has suffered most among Big Three companies from a downturn in sales of cars and trucks, with annual sales down 14 percent through July. On Aug. 17, Ford said it will take charges of up to $900 million the rest of this year, and cut up to 5,000 white collar jobs, or 10 percent of its salaried work force. And, it advised analysts to reduce their full-year profit forecasts from $1.20 a share to 70 cents a share. 
Many fear the worst is not over. Nicholas Scheele, named on July 12 as group vice president for Ford's North American operations, has been drafting a turnaround plan that the company expects to unveil before the end of the year.
Stephen Girsky, Morgan Stanley's auto industry analyst, said the bonus move is meant to alert Ford employees, suppliers, dealers and others connected to the company that Mr. Scheele's plan will mean more pain. "This is part of a bigger agenda that they are setting the stage for," Mr. Girsky said.
He sees an increased likelihood that Ford will have to cut its dividend. However, Ford's chief financial officer, Martin Inglis, said earlier this month that the dividend is safe "and that's still true," Mr. Sharkey said.
Ford's chief competitor, the General Motors Corporation, has made no decision yet on whether it will eliminate its executive bonuses, said a G.M. spokesman, Brian Akre. G.M. pays bonuses to about 3,500 executives, basing them on a series of financial, customer-satisfaction and other targets that must be met for payments to be made.
Through the second quarter, G.M. had fallen short of achieving those goals, said a company official close to the data, but the automaker is not ready to declare that bonuses will not be paid.
Chrysler, which suffered deep losses in 2000, did not pay bonuses last year, and has deferred raises to employees as part of a corporate overhaul announced in January. About 1,500 executives are eligible for bonuses. 
Under the terms of the 1998 DaimlerChrysler merger, this is the final year in which American executives will be paid under the compensation standards that were in place when Chrysler was acquired by Daimler-Benz. Generally, German executives are paid lower salaries than their American counterparts. Chrysler has not yet determined what its new compensation standards will be or whether they will change.
Outside the auto industry, cases in which compensation is being canceled are starting to accumulate. On July 31, Media General Inc., the publishing company based in Richmond, Va., told its 3,200 employees not to expect their annual holiday bonus, which in the past has equaled one week's pay or just more than $500 a person. The step will save the company $1.9 million.
Said Mr. Berner of Morgan Stanley, "A lot of things will start coming out of the weeds. We don't even know the scope of this thing."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Belgium: Economic Growth Declines 

BYLINE:  By Paul Meller (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Belgium's economic growth fell 0.6 percent in the second quarter of this year compared with the previous quarter, the first such decline in two and a half years, according to figures released by the Belgian National Bank. 
Analysts said the slowdown in the United States, and the effect it had on Belgium's neighbor Germany, was a considerable factor in the decline. According to the report, imports declined 2 percent, but exports fell 6.5 percent. Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt, above, said he expected the economy to grow 2 percent this year and 2.5 percent to 3 percent in 2002. Paul Meller (NYT)

HEADLINE: Fair to Fill 400 Teacher Posts Draws 3,000 

 BODY:
About 3,000 people showed up at a job fair in Brooklyn yesterday to apply for 400 jobs as New York City school teachers, Board of Education officials said.
 Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the board, said the turnout for the fair was the largest that anyone could remember and twice what board officials had expected. 
About half of the applicants had no teaching credentials, she said, and they appeared to be recent college graduates looking for work. The job fair, at a hotel in Downtown Brooklyn, had been advertised in New York City newspapers. 
 "This may be an illustration of the state of the economy," Ms. Feinberg said.
"Many of the applicants came just because they saw an advertisement for a job, without realizing they needed credentials." 
Many of the applicants with credentials were certified as elementary school teachers, but the board was seeking those certified in areas facing a teacher shortage: math, Spanish, science, special education and bilingual education.
Ms. Feinberg said she did not yet know how many of the 400 vacancies had been filled, but she said the board expected to fill all teaching posts by Wednesday, when school begins.

HEADLINE: Corrections 

 BODY:
 Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the dating of recessions connected two statistics incorrectly in discussing jobs in the United States. While total employment has declined 0.2 percent since March, it has not fallen to 4.5 percent. The 4.5 percent figure is the unemployment rate, which has risen from 4.3 percent in March.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-11

Israelis Leave Arab Town After Halt in the Shooting
The Israeli army withdrew its tanks and soldiers from Beit Jala in the West Bank early today, ending Israel's longest stay in a Palestinian-ruled area after a little over two days. Israel had agreed to pull out if Palestinian gunmen there stopped shooting at Gilo, a nearby Israeli neighborhood. Reports said the gunfire in Beit Jala stopped around midnight, and the Israeli forces began moving out five hours later. A8

Secretary of State Colin L. Powell phoned Yasir Arafat with assurances that the United States was pressing Israel to leave Beit Jala, and then he called Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and his foreign minister, Shimon Peres, to request that withdrawal, administration officials said. But it was not clear whether that figured in Israel's decision. A8

HEADLINE: Odds Are Dim for European Rate Cut 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
Ernst Welteke, a council member of the European Central Bank, said today that it was not the bank's job to fine-tune economic growth, suggesting that policy makers will not reduce interest rates when they meet on Thursday. 
 "The E.C.B. doesn't have the job of steering the economy," Mr. Welteke said in a speech at a banking conference in Frankfurt. "The best contribution monetary policy can make to growth and employment is to keep prices stable." 
 The speech was the first by an official of the bank in a month and came a week after figures showed the German economy stalled last quarter.
"I thought they'd cut rates tomorrow, but there's no point expecting that any more," said Guillaume Sciard, a money manager at Barclays Asset Management France in Paris. 
The central bank's policy makers have kept rates unchanged since May 10, the only time they lowered the price of money this year, by a quarter-point. The Bank of England has cut its main rate four times this year. The Federal Reserve has cut United States rates seven times in the period.
"The ability to fine-tune economic growth is obviously being overestimated," Mr. Welteke said.
The European Central Bank's main responsibility is to combat inflation.
The German economy, Europe's largest, stalled in the second quarter, while Italy's shrank 0.1 percent. The weakening economies mean inflation will probably ease in coming months. 
The inflation rate in the dozen nations using the euro declined to 2.8 percent in July from 3.4 percent in May. The bank says it wants to keep inflation below 2 percent, a goal it has missed for 14 months. Preliminary figures from Germany and Italy suggest it is likely to decline again in August. 
Even so, annual money supply growth, which the central bank uses as a gauge of future inflation, rose in July, to 6.4 percent from 6.1 percent in June. The bank has said it wants to keep growth to 4.5 percent.

PERSON: Michael L. Dertouzos 

HEADLINE: Michael L. Dertouzos, 64, Computer Visionary, Dies 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
Michael L. Dertouzos, a computer scientist with a knack for explaining the ways that high technology affects people's lives, died on Monday night in Boston. He was 64. 
 The cause of death is unknown, pending an autopsy. 
 Mr. Dertouzos, a faculty member of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology since 1964, became the director of the institute's Laboratory for Computer Sciences in 1974. Under his leadership, the laboratory developed many of the technologies that underlie today's computers, including one of the best-known methods for scrambling data, the RSA encryption system, and innovations that helped bring the World Wide Web into popular use. 
Charles M. Vest, the president of M.I.T., described Mr. Dertouzos as "larger than life," saying: "He was at once a leader, builder, visionary and caring human being. Few individuals have so personally and profoundly shaped their institutions and professional fields."
Mr. Dertouzos was instrumental in creating a home within his labs for the World Wide Web Consortium, a forum of companies and organizations that promotes the development of the Web. He recruited Tim Berners-Lee, the inventor of the Web, to the labs.
Though he worked in some of the highest realms of computer science, Mr. Dertouzos always insisted that technology be designed to serve people and not the other way around. In 1999, for example, the labs announced the "Oxygen Project," a $50 million effort undertaken with the M.I.T. Artificial Intelligence Laboratory to make computers easier to use, the institute said, and "as natural a part of our environment as the air we breathe."
Mr. Berners-Lee, in a tribute posted on the Web (www.w3.org/People/ Berners-Lee/2001/MLD.html), wrote, "Michael had been promoting the vision of the information marketplace long before the Web came along." 
In the tribute, Mr. Berners-Lee recalled Mr. Dertouzos's ability to cut through confusion to get things done. It was early in the life of his fledgling organization, and he recalled that the small group was "frankly quite adrift." At that moment, he recalled, Mr. Dertouzos "took us in hand" and held "one dramatic eight-hour meeting in which the mission, goals and structure of the team was in place, and everything looked at once logical and possible."
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Berners-Lee recalled his friend as being "very effective -- but unbelievably human and warm at the end of the day, and much more interested in the human than in the project." 
Michael Leonidas Dertouzos (pronounced der-TOO-zohs) was born in Athens on Nov. 5, 1936. His father was an admiral in the Greek navy, and his mother was a concert pianist. Although he recalled dreaming of going to M.I.T. as a young man, he won a Fulbright Scholarship to attend the University of Arkansas, where he earned bachelor's and master's degrees. He worked briefly at Baldwin Piano and then entered the M.I.T. doctorate program, earning the degree in 1964; he never left.
During the Carter administration, Mr. Dertouzos was chairman of a White House advisory group that helped to redesign computer networks there, and represented the United States in a delegation to the 1995 G-7 Conference on the Information Society. He was co-chairman of the World Economic Forum on the Network Society in Davos, Switzerland, in 1998. In his free time, he was an avid sailor and woodworker.
Mr. Dertouzos, a resident of Weston, Mass., married Hadwig Gofferje in 1961. They divorced in 1993. In 1998 he married Catherine Liddell, who survives him. He is also survived by two children, Alexandra Dertouzos Rowe and Leonidas M. Dertouzos of Boston, and a granddaughter. 
A scientist in his own right, Mr. Dertouzos held patents on such inventions as a thermal printer, a graphical display system and a graphic tablet. He also tried to communicate his vision of science and technology to a broader audience in eight books, including his last, "The Unfinished Revolution: Human-Centered Computers and What They Can Do For Us" (Harper-Collins), which was published this year.
He foresaw technological change in his books and speeches. In 1976, he predicted that there would be a personal computer in one of every three homes by the mid-1990's, and described the vast online information marketplace that the Internet would become in antediluvian 1980. 
"He is one of the truly articulate spokesmen for the field," said David D. Clark, a senior research scientist at the laboratory. "It's a big loss for us, because there are very few people who had their arms so much around what our field is, and what it should aspire to be." 
In "The Unfinished Revolution," Mr. Dertouzos sought an elusive harmony between technology and humanity. He wrote that intractable problems like the ethics of genetic engineering, school violence -- everything from choosing a school to running a nation -- would require the kind of thinking that transcended "pure technology" and "pure faith." He wrote, "We need to bring these back together if we want to find our way through the maze of an increasingly complex world."
Bridging that gap is difficult, he wrote, but essential.
"We will be better off and we will be finishing the ultimate Unfinished Revolution," he wrote, "if we reach for these goals using all our human dimensions in concert, standing once again in awe before the sunset, the wheel, and what may lie behind them."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
A tarnished new economy loses more luster with revised productivity data.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a collection of essays, "Unconventional Wisdom: Alternative Perspectives on the New Economy." He teaches at Cooper Union. E-mail: challenge@ mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
THE overly romantic faith in a new economy has already done plenty of damage. Just ask all those investors in Nasdaq stocks. But recent revisions to the productivity data reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics show how thin the new- economy thinking has been all along.
 First, the revisions cast doubt on a central new-economy argument by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and others. They argued that accelerating productivity gains in 1999 and 2000 were evidence that the computer revolution was at last providing a foundation for more rapid economic growth in the long run. Those gains, however, turn out mostly to have been the product of a counting error. 
 Second, the revisions seriously call into question the 10-year projections of federal budget surpluses made by the Congressional Budget Office, on which this year's $1.35 trillion tax cut was based. 
Third, the long-term trend of productivity, if properly measured, looks significantly slower than was thought only a couple of months ago -- and, contrary to some reports, remains well below historical rates of growth.
Productivity is the amount of goods and services the nation produces per hour of work. Only when the nation's businesses produce more per worker can they increase profits and raise wages. The growth of gross domestic product is the sum of increases in productivity and the labor force.
Many have long been arguing that information technology is helping business raise productivity substantially and, indeed, from 1995 to 2000, productivity was reported to have grown at nearly 2.9 percent a year. That was double the 1.4 percent rate of growth from 1973 to 1995.
But largely because of overestimates of computer software sales and consumer spending, the actual rate of productivity growth was, in fact, only slightly above 2.5 percent a year. This amounts to a reduction of somewhat less than four-tenths of a percentage point a year.
Can such a reduction in the annual rate of growth make that much of a difference? The answer is a resounding yes, especially when considering its timing.
For one thing, the faster rates of productivity growth in the late 1990's, which lent so much confidence to Mr. Greenspan and others about the maturing of the new economy, were significantly reduced. The 2.6 percent growth rate in 1999 was cut to 2.3 percent, and the stunning 4.3 percent rate in 2000, which converted many a skeptic to the new- economy cause, was cut to 3 percent.
This is hardly a deepening computer revolution. To the contrary, the more modest gains add weight to the argument by the economist Robert Gordon of Northwestern University that the rapid productivity gains of the late 1990's were largely a result of a cyclical pickup in growth. They were in line with gains typically made in the faster-growth years of past business cycles, when companies were forced to use labor more efficiently.
Furthermore, the projections of 10-year budget surpluses made by the budget office now look highly dubious. In January, it increased its 10-year estimate of productivity growth to 2.7 percent a year from 2.2 percent based on the rapid five-year growth in the late 1990's. With such an assumption, the budget office projected a $5.6 trillion federal budget surplus over 10 years.
The 2.7 percent projection was disturbingly optimistic even before the revisions. It was only slightly less than the rate of growth of the fastest five years of the business cycle. Typically, economists believe a long-term trend is the average rate of growth over the course of an entire business cycle. From 1990 -- the start of the cycle -- to 2000, productivity growth was closer to just 2 percent a year. 
With the revisions, the budget office productivity forecast is even faster than the actual rate of growth in productivity in the last half of the 1990's. This week, the budget office adjusted down its forecast of the future surplus and cut the expected long-term rate of annual productivity growth to 2.5 percent. But this is still too optimistic. Further downward adjustments are almost certain when the next forecast comes out in January.
Finally, when analyzed for how much income higher productivity might add to the economy, the long-term trend of annual productivity growth is probably weaker than 2 percent. This is because G.D.P. now includes software sales as an investment. As Dean Baker, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research, points out, investment in computer software becomes obsolete much more quickly than does investment in more traditional equipment.
Such investment contributes less to business revenue and profit than does traditional investment and therefore creates less income to pay higher wages and taxes. Businesses deduct depreciation from their profits to account for this obsolescence.
If depreciation were deducted to measure productivity, it would have grown 35-hundredths of a percentage point a year more slowly than reported from 1995 to 2000. This would have cut the average rate of productivity over the course of the cycle to about 1.8 percent a year.
One last important point. Some argue that an annual rate of productivity growth of even 1.8 percent or so is almost equal to the long-term average of about 2 percent since 1870. So why worry?
But since the 1960's, and especially since the 1980's, G.D.P. and productivity data have been adjusted upward to account for the improving quality of products. No such adjustments have been made to the historical data. Had they been made, they would probably have raised the long-term rate of productivity growth to 2.5 or 3 percent.
None of this means there was no improvement in America's economic prospects in the late 1990's. There is perhaps an increase of five-tenths of a percentage point a year in the long-term productivity growth trend, and over time, this will be significant.
But promises of a once-in-a-century transformation are not supported by the facts. More disturbing, such optimism on the part of influential Washington policy makers has provided the foundation for the $1.35 trillion tax cut the nation now has to live with, and perhaps more mistakes to come.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Ferrer's Vision of the 'Other New York'

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

 BODY:
 Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and mayoral candidate, is broadcasting a new television commercial, scheduled to begin today on New York stations.

PRODUCER -- Axelrod & Associates

ON THE SCREEN -- The commercial opens with a split frame, with a smiling Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on one side, and a succession of scenes on the other: a Yankees ticker-tape parade, the New York Stock Exchange and Times Square at night. The ad cuts to a listless schoolboy, to a parent cradling a child, to apartment buildings and a couple walking with police lights and sirens behind them. Mr. Ferrer speaks to an applauding group. His campaign slogans flash on the screen: "The Ferrer Plan: Qualified Teachers in every classroom." "More after-school programs." "Promote Community Policing. Ban Racial Profiling."

THE SCRIPT -- A narrator says: "In Rudy's New York, everything is fine. But how about the other New York, where our schools are struggling, and one out of four working people have no health plan? Where housing costs are out of reach, and fear divides people and police?

"Fernando Ferrer is fighting to make New York work for all of us, to put a qualified teacher in every classroom and after-school programs in every neighborhood, to protect our safety and our rights.

"Democrat Fernando Ferrer," the narrator concludes, "A mayor for all New Yorkers."

ACCURACY -- Mr. Ferrer has campaigned on a pitch to "the other New York," the one he says has been left out by Mayor Giuliani and the economic boom. But polls show that many poor New Yorkers have benefited from the reductions in crime and years of economic growth. Schools and housing, though, are listed as top concerns.

SCORECARD -- The images are intended to draw the contrasts Mr. Ferrer has made in his campaign. This commercial is also a direct appeal to minority residents, particularly black and Latino New Yorkers, whose relations with the police have been strained over police misconduct issues.
 DEXTER FILKINS

HEADLINE: CHANCELLOR MAKES A $150 MILLION CUT IN SCHOOL BUDGET 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
After weeks of bickering with City Hall over the Board of Education's budget, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that he had ordered $150 million in immediate program cuts, including less spending for after-school classes, athletic and arts programs, lab equipment, computer software and teacher training. 
 The cuts, which amount to 1.3 percent of the Board of Education's $11.5 billion budget, result from what Mr. Levy called "a significant shortfall" in revenue the board had expected from the city and the state this year. Many of the programs are favored by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani or have only recently regained spending levels they reached before the 70's fiscal crisis. 
 The last-minute cuts are not likely to smooth the way for next week's school opening, when problems often come to light. 
In human terms, the cuts mean that more than 2,300 jobs would be eliminated, Mr. Levy said, including 1,406 classroom paraprofessionals and administrative aides, 558 teachers who would have been hired to help reduce class sizes in the lower grades, and nearly 400 supervisors and administrators. Many of those cuts, however, will result from vacancies that will go unfilled or from the merging of existing positions. 
In addition to the $150 million in cuts, new programs costing $40 million will be deferred until next school year, Mr. Levy said, including the expansion of classroom libraries and Saturday classes in science and in English for non-native speakers. Special in-school suspension centers for disruptive students, a change ardently sought by the teachers' union, also will be delayed.
Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor, continues to press Mr. Giuliani to direct more money to the board, but Mr. Levy said the start of school next Wednesday and Thursday forced him to act. 
There was still the possibility of a last-minute decision that would prevent some of the cuts. Late yesterday, Mr. Vallone released a draft agreement, involving his office, the mayor and the board, to release $80 million of additional money that would be earmarked for some of the after-school and weekend programs. It was unclear, though, what conditions Mr. Giuliani would set for his consent.
In explaining his need to act quickly, Mr. Levy said: "As of today, we face a $190 million budget shortfall from both state and city funds, a problem that is largely the result of increases in mandated costs, including rising labor contract expenses, increases for special-education contracts, and the need to recruit certified teachers to meet Regents requirements. I cannot in good conscience start schools without any preparation for the shortfall."
The cuts announced yesterday are in addition to the $100 million in administrative savings that will result this year from Mr. Levy's plan to restructure the schools' central administration. That plan, which was announced earlier this month, included eliminating or transferring 1,200 administrative jobs and would save $300 million over three years, Mr. Levy said. 
Many of the cuts announced yesterday would be put into effect beginning next week by local district superintendents, who will decide what specific jobs and programs to eliminate.
The new cuts intensify an increasingly bitter war of words between Mr. Levy and Mayor Giuliani, who has consistently portrayed the Board of Education as a fiscal sinkhole that should be able to squeeze plenty of waste from its nearly $12 billion budget.
Mr. Giuliani was once again dismissive of Mr. Levy's plans. He said yesterday that Mr. Levy was "trying to get attention" and that the cuts were "intended to help other political campaigns." He declined to say which candidates he meant, adding, "You'll have to figure that out," but his comment seemed most likely to be intended for Mr. Vallone or Alan G. Hevesi.
Mr. Hevesi, the city comptroller, has been urging that the mayor provide more money to the Board of Education. When City Hall reached a budget agreement this summer, it included a clause saying that the board would receive the additional money if it trimmed its administrative structure enough. 
Last week, Mr. Vallone also urged the mayor to agree to restore money that the city was withholding from the board's budget, saying that Mr. Levy appeared to have met those conditions.
But Mr. Vallone has objected to Mr. Levy's statements that the administrative changes amounted to actual cuts, since the new budget is $200 million larger than last year's. Mr. Levy, however, says that mandated cost increases and the effect of inflation cut the board's spending power by $120 million below last year.
Since the city budget was adopted in June, Mr. Levy has warned that it left the board short of the money it needs to keep existing programs at their current levels. Mr. Levy also warned that without additional money, many of the programs championed by Mr. Giuliani in his State of the City and budget addresses earlier this year could not be started. 
Close to half of the 2,300 jobs that would be eliminated were to be filled by members of the United Federation of Teachers. The president of the teachers' union, Randi Weingarten, said yesterday that the budgetary dispute was "an unnecessary crisis" created by "legislative gridlock and political infighting."
Some longtime observers of city politics and the school system said the contemplated cuts were remarkable in light of the city's overall robust financial situation. 
Noreen Connell, executive director of the Educational Priorities Panel, a coalition of civic groups, noted that the city budget passed in June included $500 million in tax cuts. "Why should the Board of Education be the banker for tax cuts that all of the city's budget monitors viewed as a bad idea?" she said.
Others gave Mr. Levy more of the blame. The Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, said cuts could have been made without affecting students so directly. "I don't believe enough reductions have been made at the central Board of Education, where there is an infamous bloated bureaucracy, and where substantial savings can be realized that could back into the classrooms," Ms. Fields said. 
While Mr. Levy might have been able to delay the cuts, Robert Berne, the vice president for academic affairs at New York University and a longtime observer of the Board of Education, said that doing so would be inconsistent with Mr. Levy's management style. 
"It's obvious that there's a huge game of chicken going on here," he said. "I know the school system well enough to know there is not $190 million of painless cuts that can be made. These cuts are going to have effects on real kids who will not learn as much as a result."

HEADLINE: Boasts in 6-Way Race: Experience and Endorsements 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Among the myriad open City Council seats this year, few have attracted as many candidates with the political credentials and connections as those in the six-way race in the Democratic primary in the 39th Council District.
 The candidates' resumes cover the spectrum of local politics in what is commonly known as brownstone Brooklyn, but their names are known outside the borough and each one can boast of influential endorsements. 
 Steven R. Banks, the director of the Homeless Rights Project of the Legal Aid Society, has made a name for himself as an advocate for the homeless.
John W. Carroll is president of a powerful Democratic club in Brooklyn, and has also served as counsel to several neighborhood and preservation groups. 
Bill de Blasio, a member of the community school board in District 15, is a veteran Democratic strategist who worked for Andrew M. Cuomo at the Department of Housing and Urban Development and was the manager of Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign last year. 
Paul Bader, a longtime neighborhood advocate who owns a print and design shop, is married to United States Representative Nydia M. Velazquez.
Craig H. Hammerman has been the district manager of Community Board 6 for 11 years. 
And Anthony J. Pugliese is a carpenter who has been a longtime community activist and an organizer for his union.
The district stretches from the relatively affluent Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens sections of Brooklyn through a portion of Park Slope and Kensington and into Borough Park.
For the last 10 years, the district has been represented by City Councilman Stephen DiBrienza. But Mr. DiBrienza is barred under the city's term-limit laws from running for re-election and is now seeking the Democratic nomination for public advocate.
The race in the 39th District is being watched not only because of its candidates, but because the district's campaign issues are as disparate as its neighborhood identities are distinct. In some areas, there is concern about the proposed restructuring of the Gowanus Expressway. Most of the candidates support a plan to replace the highway with a tunnel. In other areas, there are great concerns about skyrocketing rents as developers find new projects to lure higher-paying tenants.
Mr. Bader, 48, has established strong ties through nearly 30 years of involvement in civic groups in Carroll Gardens and beyond. In this campaign he has spoken with particular passion about the Council's role in ensuring that city contracts are awarded in a cost-effective way, particularly amid projections of a slow economy.
The political roots of Mr. Carroll, 48, are in the Park Slope and Kensington sections of the borough, where he was a founding member of the Central Brooklyn Independent Democrats, a politically robust club in Brooklyn. Mr. Carroll, who once ran for State Senate, has emphasized his desire to study whether an electric power company owned by the city would provide cheaper rates than a privately owned one.
"A public power company doesn't have to produce a profit for its shareholders," Mr. Carroll said.
Mr. Banks, 44, emphasized his long history of legal work as evidence that he has the legislative background for the Council. "I've written dozens of laws that the Council members have passed," he said. "Through the work I have already done, I've gotten money for seniors and victims of domestic violence."
While all of the candidates discuss proposals to improve education, Mr. de Blasio, 40, said that his work on the school board had given him expertise on the subject. He talks about the role he played in developing secondary programs for the district. "We need to have an increase in teacher salaries, but the city also has to come up with the will to get hundreds of millions from the operating budget for public education," he said.
Mr. Pugliese, 47, said that his major thrust, if elected, would be to develop more programs to help middle-class residents in the district become homeowners. 
And Mr. Hammerman, 36, discussed the need for stepped-up police patrols in the district.
The politics of the district have made the race utterly unpredictable. Mr. Bader has been supported by Martin Connor, the Democratic leader of the State Senate, and Assemblywoman Joan Millman. Mr. de Blasio has been endorsed by former Mayor David N. Dinkins and many large unions, including the United Federation of Teachers.
Mr. Carroll has received the support of several local elected officials, including State Senator Marty Markowitz, who is running for Brooklyn borough president, and United States Representative Major Owens. And Mr. Banks has been endorsed by former Mayor Edward I. Koch and a number of advocacy groups. Mr. Pugliese has been endorsed by District Council 37, the city's largest municipal labor union.
Mr. de Blasio has raised the most in contributions, at $116,500. Mr. Banks is next, with nearly $105,000 (he has also raised money from more individual contributors -- nearly 700 -- than the other candidates). Mr. Pugliese has raised about $65,500, Mr. Bader about $53,500, Mr. Carroll about $45,600 and Mr. Hammerman reported contributions of about $31,400. All of the candidates have received the full $75,350 in city campaign matching funds, except for Mr. Pugliese, who has not received a payment as yet.
Handicapping this crowded race is even more complicated because the voters in the district have a history of being fiercely independent. "I don't know how much political endorsements matter in a race like this," Mr. Hammerman said. "What wins this race is grass-roots support."

HEADLINE: Council Endorsements: Brooklyn 

 BODY:
Brooklyn voters have a chance this year to enliven New York's City Council with the kind of energy, intelligence and independence unrivaled in city politics in many years. Here are our recommendations in seven important Democratic races in the Sept. 11 primary.
 33rd District (Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Williamsburg, Greenpoint): David Yassky, a professor at Brooklyn Law School, was Charles Schumer's firepower when Mr. Schumer, now senator, was in the House of Representatives. He helped create the Brady bill and the Violence Against Women Act and helped get more than 6,000 new police officers on the streets of New York City. Mr. Yassky has an uphill battle against the Democratic organization's candidate, Steven Cohn. Mr. Cohn, a lawyer, has a long record of community activity, but he harks back to the city's old political patronage era rather than forward to something better. We enthusiastically endorse David Yassky. 
 35th District (Crown Heights, Prospect Heights, Clinton Hill, Fort Greene): Letitia James, a former assistant attorney general for Brooklyn, is the Democratic organization's candidate in this race. But Ms. James, who has compiled a fine record as a legislative counsel in Albany, seems to have the strength of character to chart an independent course. Her main opponent, Peter Williams, is the director of housing and community development for the National Urban League. Mr. Williams has an impressive background of city activism, but we endorse Letitia James, with the hope that she will recruit Mr. Williams to advise her on housing and development issues.
39th District (Borough Park, Kensington, Windsor Terrace, Park Slope, Carroll Gardens, Cobble Hill): Even in a year when the quality of City Council candidates is exceptional, this race stands out. Bill de Blasio, a local school board member, is better known as the campaign manager for Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate race. Steven Banks, a Legal Aid lawyer, has a national name for his work on behalf of the homeless. John Carroll is an attorney who pioneered the development of low- and moderate-income housing in his Windsor Terrace neighborhood. Any of the three would make a fine Council member, but we endorse Bill de Blasio, who has the most potential as leader for the district and the city. 
40th District (Central Brooklyn): Una Clarke is one of the many term-limited Council members attempting to bequeath her seat to a relative. Her daughter, Yvette Clarke, is a politically sophisticated candidate with experience in economic development. Another strong candidate is Jean Vernet, a community activist from the National Coalition for Haitian Rights. But he does not have the energy level that we think Ms. Clarke would bring to the job. Our endorsement goes to Yvette Clarke, in the hope that she will use her mother's better instincts in fighting for social services while avoiding political divisiveness.
44th District (Midwood, Borough Park, Bensonhurst): Two candidates stand out in this race to replace the outgoing Council member Noach Dear -- Simcha Felder, chief of staff to Assemblyman Dov Hikind, and Bob Miller, an attorney with a long record of civic work in the district. Bob Miller's well-thought-out proposals to improve schools in the area earn him our endorsement.
45th District (Flatbush, Flatlands): Kevin Parker, special assistant to State Comptroller Carl McCall, is an African-American running against two opponents who argue that the district should be represented by someone with Caribbean roots. What the area residents really need is an energetic and intelligent Council member who wants to serve everyone with equal vigor. That description best fits Kevin Parker, and he gets our endorsement.
47th District (Brighton Beach, Bensonhurst, Coney Island, Gravesend): Susan Lasher, the wife of the outgoing Council member, is running to continue "the Lasher legacy." Although Mrs. Lasher has an appealing personality, this diverse district needs to be represented by someone with a broader vision. Domenic Recchia, an attorney and school board member, is well versed in education issues but he seems too focused on the neighborhoods where he has his political base. Alec Brook-Krasny, who immigrated from Moscow in 1989, is less politically sophisticated but he appears to be genuinely committed to reaching out to all the neighborhoods in the district. His election would also give the city's Russian-American community a much-needed connection to city affairs. We endorse Alec Brook-Krasny.

HEADLINE: TIGHTER FINANCES WON'T CURB GOALS, PRESIDENT ASSERTS 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 29 

 BODY:
President Bush vowed today not to let the economic slowdown or the evaporating federal surplus deter him from increasing the military budget, beginning work on a missile shield or increasing spending on education.
 Mr. Bush outlined his agenda for the autumn, before thousands of cheering veterans at the annual American Legion Convention, only hours after the Commerce Department released revised figures for economic growth in the second quarter of this year, showing an anemic 0.2 percent. Mr. Bush said the figure showed that an economic "recovery is very slow in coming." 
 Mr. Bush said the continuing weak economic performance proved that the tax cut he signed into law in the spring and tax rebate checks now being mailed by the Treasury, were exquisitely timed to provide an economic stimulus. 
"With the tax reduction already in place, Americans will have more of their own money to spend, to save and invest, the very things that make our economy grow," Mr. Bush said.
And he responded to Democrats who had argued that the tax cut contributed to the disappearance of the non-Social Security surplus, challenging them to think twice about the alternative.
"Now there are some who are second-guessing tax relief," Mr. Bush said, which he called "the right prescription at the right time."
"I presume those who now oppose tax relief are for raising your taxes," he added. "That would tie an anchor on our economy, and I can assure you I won't allow it."
Even as Mr. Bush prepared to return to Washington on Thursday after his 25-day working vacation, Congressional Democrats were honing their attacks. 
Democratic leaders in both houses sent Mr. Bush a letter today urging him to specify how he would pay for his increase in military spending and other programs, clearly trying to tempt the president into going first in describing what programs he would scale back or eliminate.
The administration last week projected a $1 billion surplus beyond Social Security revenue, then the Congressional Budget Office projected that the current budget would dip $9 billion into the Social Security surplus. Both parties have vowed not to take that step.
"It is imperative that you provide specific guidance on how you intend to pay for the additional initiatives that you are calling for," the Democrats wrote. "We would appreciate the opportunity to meet with you to receive the benefit of your thinking." 
The letter concluded, "For Democrats, saving the Social Security surplus is not a symbolic goal -- it is a shared commitment we have made to the American people and one that we thought you shared." 
A White House spokesman, Scott McClellan, said this evening that "the letter was odd," because Mr. Bush already had a meeting scheduled with the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, on Tuesday, and one with the House minority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, on Friday.
While Mr. Bush has not detailed any cuts, his spokesman said, there would be no need to dip into the Social Security surplus if Congress stuck to the budget that Mr. Bush sent it. 
The statement appeared to be an effort to make Mr. Bush be the first to declare that the agreement might have to be violated.
Mr. Bush continued to outline his counterstrategy today. He is demanding that that Congress pass the military budget first and the education budget second, so that those areas are not squeezed when Congress confronts the hard choices that it will ultimately have to make if it avoids spending surplus money generated by Social Security taxes.
"Near the end of the process," the president said, "suddenly we hear that Congress is about to go over the budget, so the items that have been saved for last are the ones most likely to get cut. And guess which -- guess what usually has been saved for the last? The defense bill -- leaving our national security at the mercy of budget games and last-minute cuts."
It is far from clear that Mr. Bush can persuade Congressional leaders, especially in the Democratic-controlled Senate, to deliver the spending bills in the order he desires. Nor did he suggest today how he would deal with the other priorities he listed: more benefits for veterans, prescription drug benefits for the elderly and modernization of Medicare. 
He never once mentioned his energy agenda, which would also cost billions and is bound to face close scrutiny. In fact, in laying out his agenda for the autumn he never even mentioned the energy crisis, even though it was a staple of his speeches earlier this year.
Mr. Bush looked tanned today and sounded optimistic, and he told another audience here, at a park dedication ceremony this morning, that "our batteries are recharged" after time on his ranch. 
In his speech to the veterans, he called for compromise.
"I return to Washington tomorrow ready to make my case and ready to work with folks on both sides of the aisle," he said.
But he added: "Dick Cheney and I didn't seek our offices so we could just settle in and mark time. We didn't come to rubber stamp the status quo."
The president's relaxed air could be endangered after the Labor Day weekend. The revised surplus figures give him and the Democrats virtually no room to operate. They cannot increase spending for new programs, including many Mr. Bush listed today as priorities, without coming up with compensating cuts. Already there are whispers in the Republican camp about whether the ban on spending the Social Security surplus makes sense, especially at a time of economic downturn, when classical Keynesian economic theory would call for more government spending as an economic stimulus.
"Remember, until a year or two ago, no one ever distinguished between the Social Security surplus and the non-Social Security surplus," a Bush economic adviser said the other day, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "That doesn't mean we should spend the Social Security funds. But we have to remember that this is an accounting distinction that is relatively new, and this is the first time it's being tested."
Some Democrats, though not Mr. Daschle and Mr. Gephardt, are already arguing that the goal could be economically dangerous. In an op-ed essay today in The Wall Street Journal, Robert B. Reich, a secretary of labor under President Bill Clinton and now a professor of social and economic policy at Brandeis University, argued that "this fictional 'lock box' was harmless enough when the economy was booming but makes no sense when it is slowing."
Mr. Reich said "Democrats should stop their bellyaching about 'raids,' " arguing that eventually those constraints would undercut both economic recovery and traditional Democratic commitment to education, mass transit and child health care. 
That may be so, but the mantra of protecting the surplus was a creation of the Clinton administration, after Mr. Reich left to return to academia. It quickly became the orthodoxy for both parties, because each wanted to show that it was the more fiscally responsible. Turning back on that pledge now would be politically painful, maybe impossible.
This afternoon, returning to Waco, Tex., Mr. Bush performed a ceremony to honor former President Ronald Reagan, whose name he often invokes in discussing his strategy of cutting taxes and shrinking government. He decommissioned a former Air Force One, which took its last flight carrying the president today. The plane is a specially configured Boeing 707, tail number 27000, which began flying in 1972, when President Nixon used it.
It was closely identified with Mr. Reagan, who flew it to Berlin in 1987 and demanded that Mikhail S. Gorbachev tear down the Berlin Wall. Earlier, it was also used by President Jimmy Carter, in the hours after his presidency, to greet the 52 Americans who had just been released from captivity in Iran. 
The plane will be kept on display at the Reagan Library in California.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 31, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about President Bush's vow to increase military and education spending referred incorrectly in some copies to an effort to make him declare that the Social Security surplus might have to be used. A letter in which Democratic leaders asked Mr. Bush to specify how he would pay for his proposals appeared to be such an effort. A statement from a White House spokesman that Mr. Bush had scheduled a meeting with Democratic leaders was not.
