HEADLINE: From Brazil, An Emerging Steel Giant; 
A Family Company Shops Abroad for Acquisitions

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil 

 BODY:
Exactly 100 years ago, a German immigrant named Joao Gerdau bought a small, struggling nail factory here. Today, that company, now run by four of his great-grandsons, is one of the fastest-growing steel producers in the world -- and the envy of every Brazilian corporation eager to establish an international presence.
 No matter that steel is a perpetually troubled industry all over the world or that Metalurgica Gerdau S.A. is still based in this state capital of about 1.5 million in the extreme south of Brazil, far from the country's industrial heartland. By shopping abroad for bargains with the same tenacity it has always shown at home, Gerdau has been able to transform itself into a global business -- demonstrating how once-obscure companies from emerging nations like Brazil are becoming increasingly important on the international economic stage. 
 "This is an agile, aggressive group that throughout its history has shown an ability to rapidly identify and exploit opportunities," said Germano Mendes de Paula, a professor of economics at the Federal University of Uberlandia and an expert on the Brazilian steel industry. "They are a company with a high degree of specialization, but they have always been pioneers." 
Worldwide, Gerdau has 12,000 employees, operates in six countries and produces more than seven million tons of steel a year. The company's growing international profile includes four mills in the United States, where in 1999 Gerdau acquired AmeriSteel, the second-largest producer of reinforced steel bars in the American market.
"We started with a regional focus and then went searching for a national position," Jorge Gerdau Johannpeter, the company's president and chairman, said in an interview here.
"Once we achieved that," Mr. Johannpeter said, "we came to the conclusion that if we wanted to maintain our focus in steel, we had better seek an international position because the world was already moving toward globalization and more open markets, and we couldn't afford to be left behind."
The Brazilian steel industry, whose annual production of 25 million tons makes it the eighth largest in the world, was created with United States aid during World War II to help supply the Allied cause. Gerdau entered the business in 1948, after earlier trying manufacturing ventures in areas like furniture.
Over the next three decades, the company grew gradually, snapping up the factories of domestic competitors farther north and building new plants in its home region. Its focus was always on "long steel" products, which are used in the construction industry, and items like rods, barbed wire, and, yes, the humble nail that gave the company its start.
Traditionally, Brazilian companies have been so captivated by the potential of their nation's huge domestic market that they paid little attention to the world outside. But Gerdau's managers have always been quick to adopt foreign innovations, as one might expect of an immigrant family that has maintained its ties to relatives in Hamburg and New York.
"My father was born abroad and was director of a German bank, which means he inspected all the branches here in South America," said Mr. Johannpeter, who spent part of his childhood in Buenos Aires and, in addition to Portuguese, speaks English, German and Spanish. "So he had an internationalized mentality, open to the most modern management and financial technologies of the time. That was very much a part of our culture and upbringing."
From the beginning, for instance, Gerdau operated with a mini-mill system that had proved successful elsewhere, deliberately avoiding larger integrated plants, which require bigger investments and are less flexible, so it could decentralize its production and put its factories closer to both markets and the sources of raw material.
That way, the company was able to capitalize on the enormous natural competitive advantage that Brazil enjoys in steel production.
"Economically, there are few places in the world where it makes sense to be producing steel," said Mauricio Reveco, Latin American steel analyst for Salomon Smith Barney in New York. "Brazil is one of those places, though, and the reasons are clear: you have cheap iron ore, labor that is less expensive than in the United States or Europe, and abundant energy sources."
But in Brazil, too, there are limits to growth, and when Gerdau began to look outside the country with the intention of becoming an international producer, it sought a steady but measured expansion. The process started in 1980 with the purchase of a small company over the border in Uruguay, and accelerated with the acquisition of mills in Cambridge, Ontario, in 1989 and Winnipeg, Manitoba, in 1995.
Along the way, Gerdau also established footholds in Argentina and Chile in the 90's through the acquisition of producers there. But the company's most prominent venture came in 1999, when it entered the United States market in a big way by acquiring a 75 percent interest in AmeriSteel from Kyoei Steel of Japan for $272 million.
The AmeriSteel transaction increased Gerdau's overall output more than 50 percent, tripled its production outside Brazil and raised the company to the 25th-largest steel producer in the world from the 46th, according to rankings compiled by the International Iron and Steel Institute. It was also in 1999 that Gerdau's American depository receipts began trading on the New York Stock Exchange. On Wednesday, they closed at $6.50, up 24 cents. 
With the downturn in the world economy, Gerdau's expansion overseas has proved to be a double-edged sword. Brazil continues to grow, albeit more slowly.
But with nearly half the company's production now taking place abroad and with a glut of steel and slumping demand having led to declining prices, analysts warn that Gerdau is more vulnerable than in the past to market fluctuations.
In the first half of this year, Gerdau's profitability rose 6 percent in local currency terms, compared with the similar period last year. But because the Brazilian currency, the real, has declined in value by almost one-quarter against the United States dollar this year, in part because of the economic turmoil in neighboring Argentina, Gerdau reported a 15.8 percent drop in profit in dollar terms, to $98.9 million from $117.5 million.
"This is going to prove to be a very tough year for them, but it should not be catastrophic," said Thomas de Mello e Souza, who follows the Brazilian steel industry for Merrill Lynch in Sao Paulo. "They are really good operators who have shown a high level of competence and flexibility in difficult situations in the past."
To complicate matters further, President Bush in June asked the United States International Trade Commission to determine whether current levels of steel imports are harming American producers.
Saying he was "deeply concerned" by what he described as a pattern of "foreign government intervention in the market and direct financial support of their steel industries," Mr. Bush held out the possibility that he might soon impose restrictions on imports of steel.
The announcement was criticized by European and other governments, who said it was contrary to the spirit of free trade. But as Professor Mendes de Paula noted, any restrictions on imports from Brazil, which has been a target of previous complaints from the United States about the dumping of steel, may actually help Gerdau.
"Unlike other Brazilian steel companies," he said, "Gerdau supplies the American market not through exports but primarily via its own domestic production. Since they are already in the American market, any kind of protectionist measures are likely to bring them more benefits than difficulties."
Mr. Johannpeter, Gerdau's president, was critical of Washington's stance, dismissing accusations of dumping and suggesting that the United States look more closely at larger producers, especially in Asia. "The problem is not the behavior of Brazilian steel producers, who are extremely competitive," he said. "It is the world that is bombarding the United States with steel, not Brazil."
But Mr. Johannpeter also indicated a willingness to expand Gerdau's presence in the United States once the world economy starts looking up again. Analysts said such a move would be logical and would help insulate the company from political and economic volatility at home and abroad.
"They need to digest their acquisition of AmeriSteel," Mr. Reveco of Salomon Smith Barney said. "But after that, they might very well want to consider something else."
Its rising international visibility notwithstanding, Gerdau remains very much a family company. Three of Jorge Gerdau Johannpeter's brothers -- Frederico, Klaus and Germano -- hold top management posts in the company, supervising finance, production and sales, respectively, and several members of the family's next generation have also been brought in.
Mr. Johannpeter's eventual successor will presumably be found among this young generation, a group of people who started work in the family tradition of sweeping mill floors. No matter who the successor turns out to be, the direction of Gerdau's future expansion seems clear.
"There are sectors in which you have to be a world player in order to avoid being destroyed by your competitors," Mr. Johannpeter said. "Steel is one of them."

A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a Brazilian company that is one of the world's fastest-growing steel producers misstated the action shown. The worker was using a grinder, not soldering equipment.

HEADLINE: THEATER GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.
+ means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.
++ means tickets were at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.

Broadway

"BLAST!" One ends up feeling bad about criticizing the nice young men and women whose Vegas-friendly enhancements of drum-and-bugle-corps routines make up this supposed extravaganza. Mostly in their 20's, they are brass players and percussionists, dancers and jugglers, a glowingly good-looking bunch, and irrepressibly cheery, too. But it is hard to shake the notion that this is a halftime show, complete with flag-waving, party-colored lighting and broad, bland choreography, that has wandered onto Broadway by mistake as if it had gotten lost on the way to the stadium (2:00). Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53rd Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $80 (Bruce Weber).

*+ "CONTACT." Susan Stroman's sparkling anthem to the transforming powers of dance has yet to succumb to the anemia that often befalls long-running musicals. A return visit to this Tony Award-winning show found it in a robust, muscle-flexing state of health. This three-part self-described dance play has ripened into mellowness, with a newly relaxed expansiveness that doesn't dilute its intoxication factor. The attitude speaks of performers who are so comfortable with the contours of their parts that they can riff on them a bit, jazz style, sounding new emotional notes. The original stars -- Karen Ziemba, Boyd Gaines and Deborah Yates -- are on board through Sunday (2:00). Beaumont, Lincoln Center (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $60 to $90 (Ben Brantley).

++ "42ND STREET" (Tony Award for best revival of a musical). There's nothing like precision tap-dancing to turn an audience into a lab full of case studies for Dr. Pavlov. Witness this opulent revival, directed by Mark Bramble and choreographed by Randy Skinner, in which every other production number has us beating our flippers together like the seals at feeding time. A largely labored resurrection of the last musical staged by the fabled Gower Champion, inspired by the classic 1933 movie, the show features Harry Warren and Al Dubin's priceless Depression-era songs, Michael Cumpsty as a tyrannical director and an extremely enjoyable Christine Ebersole (Tony winner for best actress in a musical) as his tyrannical star. Otherwise the evening's charms are largely limited to its full-strength tapping (2:40) Ford, 213 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4100. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $90 (Brantley).

*+ "THE FULL MONTY." This hearty Americanized singing adaptation of the popular English film about a motley male troupe of amateur strippers gives off a blaze of pure mass appeal. The show calculatedly pushes as many buttons as an elevator operator, but mercifully it doesn't hammer at them. With a winning, ear-catching pop score by David Yazbek and a lively gallery of performers who seem truly in love with the people they're playing, "The Full Monty" is that rare aggressive crowd-pleaser that you don't have to apologize for liking. Well, for the most part. The book, by the multiple Tony Award-winner Terrence McNally, is sometimes as lame and pandering as a midseason replacement sitcom. Fortunately "The Full Monty" has more to do than just talk. And as long as it lets its ideally cast ensemble translate blue-collar blues into vigorous song, it's impossible not to smile. And, yes, the men do take off all their clothes (2:45). O'Neill, 230 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $90 (Brantley).

+ "IF YOU EVER LEAVE ME . . . I'M GOING WITH YOU!" Do you by any chance make a habit of crashing wedding receptions, anniversary banquets and family reunions? Do you get your kicks from watching strangers in festive formal wear as they show home movies and make toasts of mutual admiration? If so, you may enjoy the party that Renee Taylor and Joseph Bologna have given for themselves at the Cort Theater, a self-addressed valentine to their 36-year marriage. Others will find less to savor in this anthology of old jokes, autobiographical snippets, and scenes from the couple's plays, written and directed by the two stars. Even the personal stories have hardened into shtick-shaped molds. The show's title, with its self-contained set-up and punch-line, pretty much says it all (1:30). Cort, 138 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. Today at 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m.; no performance this Monday ; Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $65 (Brantley).

* "MAJOR BARBARA." The Roundabout Theater Company's elegant, eloquent and very funny production of Shaw's 1905 play sending up the societal worship of money -- and the convolutions of logic that defend it -- is less an interpretation than a celebration of this playwright's winking, topsy-turvy didactics on the subjects of politics, poverty and faith. In a world where spin-doctoring has become the rule in public discourse, inoffensiveness is prized and forthrightness has become suspicious, Shaw's notion that the rhetoric that protects a system of Darwinian economics is a hypocrisy has only gained in relevance. And the director Daniel Sullivan, whose strength is in crystallizing the dramatic voice of the playwright, has made Shaw's tasty ironies crystal clear, so that with a first-rate cast led by Cherry Jones, Dana Ivey and the British actor David Warner, making his American stage debut, the star of the show is the playwright himself (2:30). American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212) 719-1300. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $40 to $65 (Weber).

* "THE PRODUCERS" (winner of 12 Tony Awards). How do you single out highlights in a bonfire? Anyone who sees this sublimely ridiculous show is going to be hard pressed to name a favorite moment. (Is it the singing pigeons? Adolf Hitler doing Judy Garland?) Mel Brooks's wildly energetic stage adaptation of his 1968 cult movie is as full of gags, gadgets and gimmicks as a master vaudevillian's trunk. But the production is so much more than the sum of its gorgeously silly parts. It is, to put it simply, the real thing: a big Broadway book musical so ecstatically drunk on its powers to entertain that it leaves you delirious, too. With the assistance of the director and choreographer Susan Stroman and the happiest cast in town, led by Nathan Lane (Tony winner for best actor in a musical) and Matthew Broderick. (Mr. Broderick will be on vacation from Tuesday through Sept. 9, when Jamie La Verdiere and Jeffry Denman will alternate in the role.) in the performances of their careers, Mr. Brooks has put on a show that is a valentine to every show there is, good and bad, about putting on a show (2:45). St. James, 246 West 44th Street, (212) 239-5800. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $100; extremely limited (Brantley).

*+ "PROOF" (Tonys for best play and direction of a play). An exhilarating, assured new play by David Auburn that turns the esoteric world of higher mathematics literally into a back-porch drama, as accessible and compelling as a detective story. A mystery about the authorship of a particularly important proof, it is also about twin enigmas: genius and love. Without any baffling erudition, the play presents mathematicians as both blessed and bedeviled by the gift for abstraction that ties them achingly to one another and separates them, also achingly, from concrete-minded folks like you and me. Perhaps most satisfying, it does so without a moment of meanness. Directed by Daniel Sullivan with the pace of a psychological thriller and performed by an exemplary cast, most notably Mary-Louise Parker (Tony winner for best actress in a play), "Proof" reaches into the most competitive and difficult intellectual terrain and finds -- guess what? -- good people (2:00). Kerr, 219 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $19 to $69 (Weber).

+ "STONES IN HIS POCKETS." Watching Sean Campion or Conleth Hill take a step forward is an exercise in suspense: when his foot touches the floor, it is entirely possible that he will no longer be the sex, age or nationality that he was a second before. These two human Etch-a-Sketches, the entire cast of Marie Jones's play about an American film crew in an Irish village, offer overwhelming evidence that there are special effects the movies will never do better than the theater does. It should be noted, however, that the pleasures of "Stones" are less literary than kinetic. Its satire of those superficial, egomaniacal folk who make movies is awfully familiar stuff. And Ms. Jones burdens an essentially comic play with a thudding tragic center. The evening's joys come from its two actors splitting like amoebas into different personalities (2:20). Golden, 252 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $70 (Brantley).

* "URINETOWN: THE MUSICAL." No matter how satiric, referential or allegorical the story behind this cheeky, exuberant new musical suggests itself to be, it is fundamentally an extended bathroom joke, and that's not a bad thing. The premise is that a water shortage has rendered an unnamed city so arid that private toilets are insupportable. So everyone has to use public latrines, which are controlled by a greedy corporation that keeps raising prices until the poor revolt. Absurd? Of course. But the show's real concern is to make sport of the Broadway musical, particularly the kind with a social conscience, from "The Threepenny Opera" to "Les Miserables." And with its cagey score, grinning and mordant in a Kurt Weill mode; its boisterous choreography; and a cast that is thoroughly committed to straight-faced silliness, the show is so intelligently calibrated in its audacity that it can provoke enthusiasm even in those weary of musicals about musicals (2:10). Henry Miller, 124 West 43rd Street, (212) 239-6200. Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays; at 2:15 and 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $75 to $85 (Weber).

Off Broadway

+ "BAT BOY." Even if high camp is not your style, this outlandish but witty musical may very well make you laugh. Derived from a dubious tabloid story about the discovery in a West Virginia cave of a creature who is half boy, half vampire bat, it's a tongue-in-cheek Gothic morality tale bent on revealing the bat in all of us. The title role is played by Deven May, a gifted, athletic young actor with a dexterous singing voice who is equipped with Vulcan ears and pointy teeth. He's doomed, of course, particularly once the secret of his parentage is revealed. But long before the climax, the show establishes its credentials as an omnibus parody, garish in almost every respect but constrained below the bar of foolishness by the vivacious direction of Scott Schwartz and the winking lyrics of Laurence O'Keefe. Mr. O'Keefe also wrote the tuneful score, which is largely devoted to lampooning Broadway schmaltz (2:20). Union Square, 100 East 17th Street, Chelsea, (212) 307-4100. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $35 to $50 (Weber).

*+ "FORBIDDEN BROADWAY 2001: A SPOOF ODYSSEY." This 18-year-old satirical revue, which manages to see its subjects with both religious reverence and diagnostic cool, has established itself as a vital index to the health of the mainstream American musical. Never mind box-office figures. "Forbidden Broadway," created by Gerard Alessandrini, is looking for signs of creative life, and according to its current reading such a pulse is growing fainter by the minute. Fortunately, this show manages to find something deliciously tart in the current blandness of musical theater. And if Broadway has become more about marketing than about product, the show is perfectly willing to point its satirist's rifle at the appropriate corporate targets (Disney, American Airlines) as well as at the usual sacred-monster stars. Directed by Mr. Alessandrini and Phillip George, the four ensemble members bring an intoxicating energy even to the portrayal of robotic performers (2:00). Douglas Fairbanks, 432 West 42nd Street, (212) 239-6200. Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8:15 p.m.; Wednesday and Saturdays at 2:30 and 8:15 p.m.; Sundays at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $49.50 and $55 (Brantley).

+ "TICK, TICK . . . BOOM!" Two round numbers, 30 and 90, glare ominously in this chamber piece from Jonathan Larson, the creator of the rock musical "Rent." Mr. Larson turned 30 in 1990, and in this self-conscious self-portrait in song he gave vent to his concern that time was running out on him. Given that the composer died of an aortic aneurysm at 35,you might expect a slightly prurient morbidity. As directed by Scott Schwartz and performed by Raul Esparza, Amy Spanger and Jerry Dixon, the show emerges as an amiable public exercise in soul searching. Compared with "Rent," it feels small and conventional. But if you look at it as a sort of sketchbook for that Broadway hit, "Tick" has its gentle fascination, while reminding us of what an infectiously tuneful composer Larson could be (1:30). Jane Street Theater, 113 Jane Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 7 and 10 p.m.; Sundays at 7 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $55 (Brantley).

Last Chance

+ "ANNIE GET YOUR GUN." Crystal Bernard as Annie Oakley and Tom Wopat, returning to the role of Frank Butler, which he originated in this production, are the current stars of this revisionist take on Irving Berlin's most famous musical. Staged by Graciela Daniele, from Peter Stone's strained adaptation of Herbert and Dorothy Fields's original book (2:40). Marquis, 1535 Broadway, near 45th Street, (212) 307-4100. Through tomorrow. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $35 to $75 (Brantley).

+ "THE DINNER PARTY." Neil Simon, in an experimental mood, has come up with one of the more bizarre mutants in theater history. This strained comedy about a gathering of mysteriously interconnected Parisians in an opulent restaurant is a French farce with a Brooklyn accent, a Strindbergian sexual slugfest with a laugh track. Those unfamiliar with Mr. Simon's earlier work could be forgiven for assuming that Doc, his professional nickname, is short for Dr. Moreau, H. G. Wells's hybrid-making mad scientist. Directed by John Rando with lots of verve and little subtlety, the play features plenty of those familiar Simon one-liners, which keep going off at the oddest moments like tardy kernels of popcorn. The prevailing mood, however, is rueful as the play considers the casualties of the sex wars. The results are as ungainly as the runners in a three-legged race (1:40). Music Box, 239 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Through tomorrow. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $45 to $70 (Brantley).

+ "LOBBY HERO." Motives come in every shade but black and white in the convincingly muddled world of Kenneth Lonergan, the Oscar-nominated screenwriter of "You Can Count on Me" and the author of the first-rate plays "This Is Our Youth" and "The Waverly Gallery." The meaty but unfulfilled "Lobby Hero," directed by Mark Brokaw, charts the bruising relationships among four people in uniform -- two doormen and two police officers -- as they experience the corrosive effects of sexual jealousy, police corruption, racial defensiveness and a clumsy yearning for honor. Everything works intellectually, and the dialogue is often terrifically tasty. But by the end, the Ping-Pong presentation of self-deceptions and self-justifications starts to feel weary. Glenn Fitzgerald is miscast as a phlegmatic professional screw-up. But Heather Burns, Tate Donovan and Dion Graham implode with sadness and charm, demonstrating that nobody loves a loser the way Mr. Lonergan does (2:10). Houseman, 450 West 42nd Street, (212) 239-6200. Through Sunday. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $45 and $50 (Brantley).

*+ "THE PLAY ABOUT THE BABY." This funny, harrowing dramatic fable, which features a four-member ensemble led with spectacular style by Brian Murray and Marian Seldes, is as explicit and concise a statement of what Edward Albee believes as he is ever likely to deliver. It is presented in the form of what might be called cosmic vaudeville, in which two old pros in this old world teach a pair of untried tyros just how bleak and dangerous the universe can be. Not, you might think, a subject for steady laughter, except of the dry and rueful variety. But while "The Play About the Baby," directed with sharpness and agility by David Esbjornson, offers nothing at all reassuring about human destiny, it has a marvelous time being negative. It also radiates a cocky confidence that the theater is the only place that could deliver such dour home truths so entertainingly (2:00). Century Center, 111 East 15th Street, Union Square, (212) 239-6200. Through tomorrow. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $60 (Brantley).

+ "ST. LUCY'S EYES." People who buy tickets just to see Ruby Dee onstage will find her at a kitchen table, snapping string beans and dispensing casual wisdom. This is the kitchen table on which Ms. Dee's character is about to perform an illegal abortion on a very frightened 17-year-old girl. It is Memphis in 1968, one day before the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Fans of Ms. Dee, who is 76, will not be disappointed in her warm, graceful performance, but it's not the production's only asset. The play is an insightful, largely satisfying drama by a promising new playwright, Bridgette A. Wimberly, whose language has the power of authenticity. The play stumbles in Act II, turning into an echo of the B movie "Madame X," but until then it is a nicely done study of comfort, karma, judgment and old women's dreams (2:00). Cherry Lane, 38 Commerce Street, West Village, (212) 239-6200. Through Sunday. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $55 (Anita Gates).

* "TOPDOG/UNDERDOG." There are many levels of deception practiced in Suzan-Lori Parks's vibrant story of battling brothers in close quarters. Directed with high wit and flair by George C. Wolfe, and starring the wonderful Jeffrey Wright and Don Cheadle, the play divides the world into a seesawing population of hustlers and victims. It even goes so far as to suggest that any human exchange involves sham, that a person can be himself only when no one else is watching. And when the person is a black man in the history lesson that is Ms. Parks's United States, the existential lies multiply. Then again, not being yourself can be a very fine art, especially as demonstrated by actors as fine as Mr. Wright, playing a former three-card monte master, and Mr. Cheadle, as an agile shoplifter. The result: the most exhilarating fraternal standoff since Sam Shepard's "True West" (2:15). Public, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 239-6200. Through Sunday. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $45 (Brantley).

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 496 words

HEADLINE: HOME VIDEO; 
The Importance Of the Box

BYLINE:  By Peter M. Nichols 

 BODY:
"People who put up money for movies now are completely star-driven," the director Michael Steinberg said. "That's their insurance. Even if you have the next Julia Stiles and a great script, they balk. They say: 'What if the movie stinks? Who do I put on the video box?' " 
 Mr. Steinberg's "Wicked," made in 1997 and released this week on cassette and DVD by Columbia TriStar, has the real Julia Stiles on the box, which leads to a tale of independent filmmaking as it has evolved over the last few years. As it often does, the trail winds through the Sundance Film Festival, where "Wicked," a darkly comic take on the Electra story set in suburban California, was shown in 1998. 
 Mr. Steinberg co-directed "The Waterdance" (1992) with Neal Jiminez, and his "Bodies, Rest and Motion" (1993) also appeared at Sundance. "Wicked," his third film, already had a distribution deal when it came to the festival. "A bad move," he said. Imagine a filmmaker thinking that. At the time, however, conditions were still encouraging for a risky film and, he said, his movie might have done better with Sundance exposure.
At the start he was unsure of "Wicked," which is about the efforts of a possibly murderous 14-year-old to seduce her father. "I needed a young girl who was going to be a movie star," he said. Rachael Leigh Cook was considered. Katie Holmes, then 17, was physically too mature. "Then, out of the blue, I got a fax from Julia Stiles," Mr. Steinberg said. "She'd gotten the script and wrote me this little letter." Later they talked on the telephone. "She had this deep voice," he said.
Ms. Stiles, a 15-year-old New York schoolgirl, was flown to California, prepped and put before the cameras. Mr. Steinberg said Paramount had planned to release the movie in 300 theaters but backed out during final negotiations. In the meantime, it had appeared at Sundance, and there were no takers after the deal fell through. "If you don't sell your film there within a month or two, they're moving on," Mr. Steinberg said. "The next crop is coming through."
"Wicked" never appeared in theaters. A dispute over the soundtrack shelved the movie for a year and a half before Columbia TriStar picked it up for video. "By then Julia was a star," Mr. Steinberg said. Ms. Stiles had appeared in "10 Things I Hate About You," had made "Save the Last Dance" and was good material for a video box. Many independent films obviously aren't that lucky, especially risky ones.
Mr. Steinberg said that paradoxically, "The Blair Witch Project" and its huge box-office success helped change the landscape for the worse. "With bigger money there are higher stakes, so movies become more general and formulaic," he said. 
As if in retaliation, independent movies that break out, like "Blair Witch" or Doug Liman's "Swingers," often have no stars. Audiences are driven by reviews and genre. 
"But the economics have changed," he said. "It's much harder to release them unless you have a lot of star power."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Julia Stiles, center, with William R. Moses and Chelsea Field in "Wicked," newly released on video and DVD this week. (Columbia TriStar Home Entertainment)

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 3098 words

HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION; 
A Place Excused From Change

BYLINE:  By CHARLES STRUM 

 BODY:
Between two drowsy villages in southern Vermont -- Poultney on the north and Wells on the south -- lies Lake St. Catherine, the product of tectonic upheavals and a glacier that retreated north 12,000 years ago.
 It is not a big lake, but at seven miles long (and 833 acres), it is big enough. About 500 cottages have lake frontage; 100 others are set back. There are quiet coves, rocky shallows and a lily pond favored by dragonflies. 
 I was a boy on St. Catherine for 15 summers, from 1948 to 1962. In rented cottages called Al-Mar and Hillside, on the northwest shore, my parents and I took August vacations of two or three weeks, just long enough to last a lifetime. 
Those Eisenhower summers reappear in mind's-eye snapshots: a dewy path of pine needles leading down to the pump. A daily visit to Samson's bait dock. Blindingly hot hours in a wooden rowboat, trolling for bass. Afternoon swims. Cool nights on the sleeping porch. A drive to Poultney for iodine, Coppertone and a milkshake at McShane's Pharmacy.
As weekend destinations go, Poultney and St. Catherine were not on the A-list, nor are they now. Why would they be? Besides the cottages at the lake, where generations of summer people stay for a week, a month or the season, few places take transients, and there's not much to do; that is, you have to make your own fun. Fifty years ago, the drive from New York City was seven hours, mostly along Route 7, including bathroom breaks, lunch at the Blue Benn diner in Bennington, Vt., and the inevitable rural traffic jam -- the kind that forms behind a tractor on a two-lane road. Today, it's four hours-plus, including tractor.
Drawn by memory and something more, I drove back alone for a few days this summer. I was hoping, I suppose, to see if the past had the potency to animate the present -- a fancy way of saying that I wanted to know if village and lake had cheated time, surviving unravaged even as I had begun to trudge into middle age.
What I found was as reassuring as the Grover's Corners of Thornton Wilder's "Our Town," as described by the Stage Manager:
"Nice town, y'know what I mean? Nobody very remarkable ever come out of it, s'far as we know. The earliest dates on the tombstones up there in the cemetery say 1670. They're Grovers and Cartwrights and Gibbses and Herseys -- same names as around here now."
Wilder's observations have the comforting ring of durability, a theme he strikes in the play's famous opening lines, which note the town's precise latitude and longitude. They identify it indelibly, like a fingerprint. A community's geography and those who share it create permanence. You can add or subtract a shop or a barn. You can tear up the train tracks and close the old mill. But you cannot change what is.
Still, it is easier to say what Poultney is not. It is not famous or fancy. It is not Colonial Williamsburg, though it has many Early American and Victorian houses that have been declared landmarks. Nor is it a ski town, like Stratton or Killington, about 45 minutes away. The boutiques and outlets are in Manchester, 30 miles south. Poultney's most glorious residents -- Horace Greeley, founder of The New York Tribune, who learned the printing trade there, and George Jones, a co-founder of The New York Times -- have been dead for more than a century. They left town long before that. At its prosperous best, around 1910, Poultney's 45 square miles bulged with 3,600 people, about the same as now.

Conflicting Accounts
Settled in 1761, the village was named for Sir William Poultney, the earl of Bath, who was secretary of war in Sir Robert Walpole's cabinet in the reign of George II. The origin of the name Lake St. Catherine, also called Lake Austin on early maps, is less certain. Two accounts remain popular. The first is that more than two centuries ago, one Nov. 25, St. Catherine's Day, Jesuit missionaries arrived at the lake and so honored her name. The second suggests that nostalgic 18th-century British immigrants named a town, then in the colony of New York, for St. Catherine's Point on the Isle of Wight, the last view they had of their homeland. Vermonters, the story goes, later adopted the name for the lake.
In the early 1800's, St. Catherine supported a gristmill, a sawmill, a tannery and a cheese factory. The first hotel went up before the Civil War, a time when spending the season meant shipping wardrobe trunks by rail. By the 80's and 90's, hotels and dance pavilions dotted the shore, and summer visitors included President Grover Cleveland, Pierre Lorillard, William K. Vanderbilt, Lillian Russell and Jay Gould, the railroad tycoon.
From the 1870's on, families of means from Albany and Schenectady as well as from Granville, N.Y., and other nearby towns, began to build summer cottages. Local families built camps for fishing. Some were large, some not. Many of them are in use today by descendants of the original builders.
As the automobile made the seasonal train trip obsolete, the popularity of the hotels and amusement pavilions dwindled. Most burned or were torn down. The last well-known pavilion, Idylwild, built in 1914 and in use through the 1950's, was razed in 1969.
But St. Catherine was never gaudy, and that's the way people like it.
"It's off the beaten path," said Philip M. Alden, a retired management consultant who bought his lake cottage as a "newcomer" in 1978. "There are no interstates near here. We have not been overrun. That's one of its appeals. It's a quiet lake mostly, the exception being on Saturday and Sunday afternoons in midsummer, when we do suffer a bit with loud outboard motors.
"We are like the dinosaurs," said Mr. Alden, who is about to conclude his fifth consecutive one-year term as president of the Lake St. Catherine Association, a volunteer group that keeps its eye on the environmental and cultural health of the lake. "But we are not obsolete."

A Father's Gift
I have never known life without Poultney and the lake. They were my father's discovery. He first traipsed into town as a young man in the early 1930's during a few weeks of hiking around southern New England. The story goes that he left New York on something called the Albany night boat, then hitchhiked his way northeast to Granville, whose slate and marble industry anchored the area's economy in the 19th century and whose quarries still operate along 25 miles of the Vermont-New York border. Dad arrived in Poultney the next day and quickly made friends with people whose families had settled there before the Revolution.
Twenty years later these Vermonters became my friends as well: the Hayneses, Agnes and Joe and Lydia and Harold; Louise Greer and her elderly parents; Al and Margaret Clark, who owned Al-Mar, at the lake; and the ancient George Haynes -- father of Harold, Joe and Margaret -- whom I called Grandpa and who died in the early 1950's, 90 some years after being a water boy in the Civil War.
They are gone now, like Wilder's fictional families, and have taken up residence in the old cemeteries of the village. But they left some reminders. You can still see Joe Haynes's name, for instance, on a plaque in the United Baptist Church (originally called the Baptist Meeting House) on the Green in East Poultney. Al-Mar is now insulated and updated but still perched near Hillside, above the lake. And if you stop at the pharmacy (the McShanes sold it years ago, and the soda fountain is gone) you can chat with Pat Dillon. She has worked there since 1942 and remembers almost everyone.
This Poultney, the "Our Town" Poultney, was where I was headed when I left New York and turned the car onto the New York State Thruway, bound for Glens Falls. I had decided against scenic Route 7 and in favor of arriving in record time. My error was in forgetting that while the distance between Glens Falls and Poultney is barely 25 miles, it's on secondary roads. I lost a half hour but gained some glorious views of ripening field corn and the purple Taconic hills.
Because I was staying only a few days, a house on Lake St. Catherine was out of the question, so I reserved a room at a Victorian bed and breakfast called the Bentley House. This turreted old home sits a couple of blocks from the end of Main Street, opposite Green Mountain College, a four-year school that was a women's junior college for a time but now has wider offerings, including a well-regarded program in environmental studies.
The Bentley's owners since last October are Denise and Bob DiMaio, who also bought a deli, Preseau's Place, on Main Street. They are from the suburbs west of Philadelphia. Brian and Robin Turro -- he from Vermont, she from Massachusetts -- are also newcomers, and they opened Rockin' Robin's Cafe, an Italian restaurant a few doors from Preseau's.
Both families say the risk is worth it. While other destinations are overrun, Poultney is not. But it's not far from places that are, and its few inns, restaurants and antiques shops may become a quiet suburb for overburdened resort hubs.

Old Businesses Remain
Their entry into the local economy has been unobtrusive. Main Street evolves very slowly. Boice's meat market is gone, as is Lynch's Ben Franklin five-and-dime. The former Williams Chevrolet showroom (1922) has been put to other use. But some old, established businesses remain, among them Williams hardware and Mart's sporting goods. Joe DeBonis's law office hasn't moved. Neither has the West Dinette, now called Tot's, a slate-roofed building from the 1890's that has looked the same, inside and out, for as long as most people can remember. (It was once Dick's Dairy Bar, when Dick Haynes, Harold's son, owned it. He sold it and went to work for the power company.)
While I returned this summer as an outsider, I had some inside help. My principal informant was Ruth Czar, who, with her husband, Jonathan, has lived in Poultney since the 1950's. Mr. Czar taught at Green Mountain College for many years; Mrs. Czar is the president of the Poultney Historical Society.

A Perpetual Motion Machine
She and I met for breakfast at Perry's Main Street Eatery. It and Tot's at the other end of the street serve the stick-to-your-ribs breakfasts their customers expect.
At 76, Mrs. Czar is a perpetual motion machine. From Perry's, where she talked gaily about the past as if it were the present, we drove to the old schoolhouse (1896) at the Green in East Poultney. The tower still holds the bell -- you can pull the rope and ring it -- and the rest of the drafty two-story structure holds the files and exhibits of the historical society.
Mrs. Czar pulled out the files on Lake St. Catherine, and a handful of albums with photos and postcards of the old village. Then she went off to lunch, leaving me alone with the rusted scythes, band instruments, threadbare military uniforms and tombstone rubbings.
After an hour of browsing, it struck me that over the years I had straddled two worlds in Vermont. I had been both summer person and honorary native. I thrived in the continuity of life in the village and around the lake, arriving each summer as the sweet corn was picked and listening to my Vermont friends as they talked about buying a new car from Harold Wescott or reminisced about who had died over the winter.
On my first night in town, I drove to the lake at twilight, taking Route 140 -- Main Street -- to East Poultney, turning right at the Baptist church and crossing the Poultney River on a narrow bridge. Within two miles I approached another landmark, the cupola of the old Griffith barn on the left. The lily pond came into view on the right, and then Ferncliff Road, the lake road.
I turned in, drove slowly for about a mile and pulled up to a parking pad overlooking the lake. A boy with a big smile was dawdling on the road and asked if I had come to see the people in the dark, unoccupied camp next to his. No, I said, I actually wanted to see that other one. Hillside. Did he live there?
He did, and he led me up the slate and stone steps strewn with pine needles, past the shower room and up one more steep incline to the back door. His mother, Peg Richards, had been warming a late supper. (It's not called dinner in Poultney.)
I explained who I was and why I had come. And I was home.
But I was unprepared. The lake camp of my memory had shrunk. Everything was in the same place, but the broad, screened-in sleeping porch with the dining table on the right was narrower and shorter than I remembered. The kitchen, while newer, was galley size. The living room lacked the cast-iron Franklin stove but seemed somewhat smaller, like a ship's cabin, as did the two bedrooms upstairs. I could have sworn there were at least three bedrooms.
Yet it was the same, too. The wooden studs and beams were still exposed and sturdy. The view of the lake was unchanged.
Hillside had endured. Not only because it was there, but because of Jackson, Keisha, Kim and Jonathan, four of the Richards's seven children who greeted me that night.
"You lived here?" asked Jackson, who had met me at the car. "Did you ever catch any fish? Did you get mosquito bites like me?"
Yes, I said. Yes. Yes. I also told them about the cranky old woman who scolded me whenever I spilled water from the pump. Her cottage, fixed up and repainted, is still at the water's edge, just below theirs.
I told them about Samson, the taciturn old man in undershirt and khaki trousers with whom my father dickered for bait. Samson spoke with an unrecognizable accent, when he spoke at all. On sunny mornings, the buckets on his dock smelled of fresh, wet earth (his nightcrawler cache) and the silver minnows swam in thick schools in a pool he had built at the shoreline.

Passing the Days
In a chat a few weeks later, I asked Mrs. Richards how she and her husband, Mick -- she is an administrator and he a teacher at nearby Castleton State College -- had come to St. Catherine. Their children range in age from 8 to 14, and their summers were the main consideration.
"We wanted a place on the lake, and we had been looking for an old-fashioned cottage," she said, meaning a rustic camp, not a four-season home. When a real estate agent showed it to them, they "immediately loved it," she said. They bought it a year ago.
"It was important to have the cottage now," she said, "because we have a little less time with them to make these kinds of memories."
And how do they spend their days?
"Oh, they take the kayak out, they swim, they fish, though they don't catch much," Mrs. Richards said. "They go hiking or for walks, the big ones watch after the younger ones."
One of the older girls baby-sits for a child in a nearby cottage. They all use what's known as the neighborhood float, a floating dock just offshore that was built by another cottage owner.
On rainy days they shop for groceries or run other errands. When it's time for ice cream, they go to Sam's Dog House, a celebrated local joint on Route 22A in Hampton, N.Y.
And in the evening, Mrs. Richards said, "We play cards, games, Chinese checkers. I don't think the kids are ever bored."
Nor was I. Not at Hillside. The memories they are making are much the same as mine. And in their bathing suits and T-shirts, eating plums on the dock or catching fireflies at dusk, the children define the summer and defy the passage of time.

The Simple Life in Vermont

Poultney, Vt., is about 225 miles north of New York City.

What to Do

LAKE ST. CATHERINE STATE PARK, 3034 Vermont Route 30 South; (802) 287-9158. Sunning and swimming on the east side of the lake. Camp sites are available, as are rowboat and kayak rentals by the hour or the day. There is plenty of good hiking around the lake. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to dark. The park closes for the season on October 15. Admission through Labor Day: $2; $1.50 for children 4 to 13; under 4, free; free for everyone after Labor Day.

FARMERS' MARKET. Main Street, 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. most Thursdays through mid-September. Information: (802) 773-4603.

POULTNEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY. On the Green in East Poultney; (802) 287-5268. Poultney's attic. Get someone to play the melodeon on the second floor of the 1896 schoolhouse. (Melodeons look like pianos but have bellows instead of strings and hammers, and they sound like harmonicas.) Other buildings maintained by the society include the melodeon factory (1854) and the former Union Academy Building (1791). Hours: June through today, 1 to 5 p.m. Appointments may be possible; call for details. The magnificent 1805 Baptist Meeting House is on the Green.

GOLF. Lake St. Catherine Golf Course, Route 30, two miles south of Poultney; (802) 287-9341. Eighteen holes, open to the public. Tee times can be reserved up to a week in advance. Hours: Daily, 8 a.m. to dark. Admission: weekdays, $13 for nine holes; $23 for 18 holes; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, $16 for nine holes; $30 for 18 holes. Motorized and pull carts are available: $16 for nine holes; $28 for 18 holes.

Where to Stay

BENTLEY HOUSE BED AND BREAKFAST. 399 Bentley Avenue; (802) 287-4004 or (800) 894-4004. A restored Victorian house at the end of Main Street near Green Mountain College. Most rooms have queen-size beds with private baths. Rates: $50 to $85.

POULTNEY INN. 236 Main Street; (802) 287-4270. Rates: $65 to $85 for a double room.

VICTORIAN SUITES INN AT POULTNEY. 2541 Vermont Route 31; (802) 287-5505. Built in 1890 and restored in 1997. Each suite has a kitchen, private bath and sitting room. Rates: Weekends and holidays, $110 for a one-bedroom, $130 for a two-bedroom; mid-week, $70 for a one-bedroom, $95 for a two-bedroom. Weekly rates available; call for details. No credit cards.

Where to Eat

PERRY'S MAIN STREET EATERY. 253 Main Street; (802) 287-5188. Breakfast, lunch and dinner. Regular American food.

TOT'S DINER. 25 Main Street; (802) 287-2213. Breakfast and lunch in a cafe that hasn't changed much in five or six decades.

ROCKIN' ROBIN'S CAFE. 150 Main Street; (802) 287-9243. Brian and Robin Turro run this family-owned Italian restaurant, with sidewalk tables and a full bar.

SAM'S DOG HOUSE. Route 22A, Hampton, N.Y.; (518) 282-9204. Where the kids will want to go for a hot dog and ice cream.

Getting There

BY CAR: Take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway (Interstate 87) north to Exit 20, then take U.S. 9 north to Route 149, go east to U.S. 4, then north to Route 30 and east into Poultney.

BY TRAIN: Amtrak runs trains from Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan to Whitehall, N.Y., 10 miles from Poultney. There is no bus or train into Poultney. Information and reservations: (800) 872-7245.

More Information

POULTNEY AREA CHAMBER OF COMMERCE. (802) 287-2010.

ON THE WEB: www.djmcadam.com /poultney.html

PUB-DATE: August 31, 2001
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; Automobiles; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1045 words

HEADLINE: When Hot Cars Go Cold 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
THE Lexus SC 430 is the chief object of automotive desire this summer. Demand is high, supplies are short and dealers are charging thousands of dollars over the $60,000 sticker. But to Jay Shoemaker, the elegant convertible is old news.
 Mr. Shoemaker of San Francisco got his SC 430 in March, and he has already sold it, pocketing $8,000 in profit. When he ordered the car in December 1999, he was the second person on Lexus's waiting list. 
 Now he is looking ahead to his 2002 Mercedes SL500, which he ordered a year ago and plans to pick up in Europe next April. It will be the 74th car that Mr. Shoemaker, 49, has owned, most of them convertibles and all but five of them imports.
"My average tenure for owning a car is one year, although if I really like it, maybe two years," said Mr. Shoemaker, chief executive of the Coppola Companies, a collection of businesses -- including a winery and movie studio -- owned by the filmmaker Francis Ford Coppola. "I generally try to be early on the curve so if I don't like it, I can always get rid of it without losing my shirt."
While the market for generic cars and trucks has been buoyed by discounts and incentives, there is strong demand for a handful of hot models. Aside from the SC 430, there are waiting lists for the Ford Thunderbird roadster, the Acura MDX sport utility and even the Honda Odyssey minivan. Their scarcity makes them all the more desirable, said Ron Pinelli, a consultant with Autodata in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.
"When something is in short supply, you feel special because you have it," Mr. Pinelli said. "Despite the economic downturn, there are still plenty of people with the money to buy whatever they want."
Automakers both love and fear trend surfers like Mr. Shoemaker. Their early-bird purchases help to kindle interest in new cars, but their fickle tastes have been picked up by the broader market. Shoppers looking at an array of vehicles, with a wide range of prices, are now eager to drive the hot new thing. Carmakers are scrambling to figure out not just how to generate heat, but how to keep hot cars from getting cold.
Wesley Brown, an analyst with Nextrend, a market research firm in Thousand Oaks, Calif., says vehicles have become personal accessories as much as transportation. "We've become a much more fashion-oriented, image-oriented society," he said. "We're always looking for what's going to make me look great, what's going to make me feel great."
That is one reason Peter Steinlauf bought his SC 430. Mr. Steinlauf, 54, chief executive of Edmunds.com, a Web site for car buyers, fell in love with the SC when he saw the first pictures of it a year ago. The romance continued upon delivery. "You sure feel very popular" behind the wheel, he said. "Strangers stop you to talk about it."
There is a price to be paid for being first. Some California dealers are charging premiums of $10,000 and more for the 2002 Thunderbird, which starts around $35,000. One dealership that is charging only the sticker price is Albion Motors in Albion, Mich., about 100 miles west of Detroit. Seven customers have placed nonrefundable deposits of $5,000, said Andrew Blackledge, the dealership's Internet sales manager.
Trouble is, Albion Motors will get just two 2002 T-Birds; its prospective buyers are on waiting lists for 2003 and 2004 models.
Even those guaranteed to get T-Birds may wait longer. Production was halted on Aug. 15 because of a cooling system problem, and resumed only yesterday.
Such glitches can contribute to a car's losing its buzz, said Art Spinella, founder of CNW Marketing Research of Bandon, Ore. His research indicates that interest in the T-Bird, which has been repeatedly delayed, may already be fading. Mr. Spinella conducts focus groups in which he shows photos of coming cars and asks consumers to rate their interest. An average score is 100. On his first test of the T-Bird, conducted in June 2000 in Florida and California, buyers gave it a score of 140. By January, its score had dropped to 129.
Another Ford vehicle, the hulking Excursion S.U.V., shows how quickly a hot vehicle can go frigid. When Ford unveiled the Excursion in 1999, the company expected it to be a huge success. But even before the Excursion came to market, environmentalists attacked it as an excessively large gas-guzzler. Soon after, gasoline prices spiked.
"A lot of high-income people just decided, 'Enough is enough,' " said Michael Luckey, analyst with the Luckey Consulting Group in Pompton Plains, N.J.
At the height of its popularity, Albion Motors sold about 10 Excursions a month. It now sells about 2, Mr. Blackledge said.
Interest remains high in the Honda Odyssey minivan, still a suburban status symbol three years after it came to market. Odyssey sales are actually down slightly this year -- not for lack of buyer interest, but because of a production quandary. Both the Odyssey and the Acura MDX sport utility are built at a plant in Alliston, Ontario, that is at full capacity. Honda has had to cut Odyssey production to build more MDX's.
At the moment, the scales are tipped in favor of MDX, which has a four-month waiting list; the Odyssey wait is generally about three weeks nationwide, said a Honda spokesman, Andrew Boyd. Supplies of the Odyssey should ease up late this year, when Honda opens a factory in Alabama that will be devoted to the minivan.
But even the biggest sensation of the late 1990's, the Volkswagen New Beetle, has struggled to stay in the limelight. When that car came out in 1998, "you could have sold truckloads if you could have gotten them," said Gary Smith, general manager of Halbinsel Volkswagen in Escanaba, Mich., who sold the first New Beetle in the country.
Since then, the cars have become widely available and deals abound. Edmunds.com says customers across the country have been paying an average of $400 below the $17,325 sticker of a basic New Beetle.
But Mr. Smith is already looking ahead. He is awaiting a convertible version of the New Beetle, for which he already has one order, though VW still hasn't said when that car will go on sale. Mr. Smith is also lobbying for VW to build a new Microbus based on a design study that was shown to the public last year. "If they ever decided to produce it," he said, "it would be a smash."

HEADLINE: Big Decision On Future Of Polish Oil Is Looming 

BYLINE:  By PETER S. GREEN 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Aug. 30 

 BODY:
The Polish government is expected to make a preliminary decision in the next few weeks on the sale of a stake in the country's largest oil refinery, a move that could reshape the region's oil industry.
 As oil companies go, the refinery, Polski Koncern Naftowy Orlen S.A., hardly seems like much of a prize. While it is relatively modern, the refinery, known as PKN, relies exclusively on imports it does not control, mainly from Russia. Many of its retail gas stations in southern Poland have been bypassed by post-Communist economic growth. And foreign companies, including a rival from tiny neighboring Slovakia, are taking its customers. 
 The planned sale by Poland's treasury ministry of a 17.6 percent stake, for about $400 million, has opened a window on the fierce competitive pressures battering the oil and gas markets of Central and Eastern Europe. The region's existing energy companies are struggling to fend off domination by cash- and resource-rich Russian energy companies and by sophisticated Western European and American oil companies.
Polish authorities are rushing to secure a sale of PKN and a second refinery in the Baltic port of Gdansk, before elections next month, when the current government is expected to lose to a left-wing slate. The opposition has said it opposes the sales.
The region's two largest players, Mol of Hungary and OMV of Austria, have put in bids that would effectively merge their companies with PKN, while PKN itself says it plans to pursue again efforts that were rejected by Polish antitrust regulators last year to acquire the refinery.
Talks on selling the Gdansk refinery to Rotch Energy Ltd., a British oil-trading company, appear stalled. The PKN bids are sealed for now, but local press reports say both Mol and OMV have proposed mergers with PKN that would make the combined company the region's largest energy concern. The deal could be the largest cross-border merger in Central Europe's history.
The reports say OMV has offered about 26 zlotys a share ($6.14) in cash and Mol has offered about 25 zlotys a share, mainly in equity, valuing the stake at more than $400 million. PKN shares are now trading at 17.5 zlotys.
Both Mol and OMV are the largest retailers in their home markets. Expanding locally is the only way they can remain independent. Their local targets are smaller companies and the most likely target, after Poland, is the state-owned Czech refining and retail conglomerate, Unipetrol. Mol recently acquired control of Slovakia's Slovnaft refinery and its retail network, and now has 800 gas stations across the region. OMV is present in 10 former Communist countries. Both also drill for oil and gas across the world. OMV has gas fields in Pakistan and Australia, while Mol is drilling for oil in Siberia with the Russian oil giant Yukos.
Demand in Central Europe's four largest countries is growing about 3 percent annually, making the oil sector in the region highly attractive for strategic and portfolio investors.
OMV's chief executive, Richard Schenz, said in an e-mail message that he expected his company to emerge as the region's strongest, but he added: "We do not believe that 'merger mania' will go on forever or to that respect is the end to all means. Studies have shown -- also for the oil industry -- that smaller companies can also achieve a very good scale of economics."
But many analysts say that by bulking up, the local companies merely make themselves more attractive takeover targets for both Russian and Western companies including the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, which recently bought the DEA gas stations from Germany's RWE group, and BP, which acquired Veba Oil from E.On of Germany last month, winning a large network of Aral gas stations in central Europe.
OMV has a market capitalization of about 2.8 billion euros ($2.55 billion); PKN is about 1.8 billion euros ($1.64 billion) and Mol is about 1.7 billion euros ($1.55 billion). By contrast, BP-Amoco has a market capitalization of $191 billion.
"All these companies believe the larger they become, the less likely they are to be takeover targets, but I argue the opposite is true," said an analyst, Gergely Varkonyi, of ING Barings in London. "This industry is about size and economies of scale. If anyone is going to expand into the region, obviously they will look at the largest player."

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Greenspan Stands Alone

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; Thomas L. Friedman is on vacation.

 BODY:
There are three great economic powers in today's world -- the United States, Europe and Japan. In principle, each of these has two potent recession-fighting tools at its disposal. One is monetary policy: the central bank can print money and drive down interest rates. The other is fiscal policy: the government can try to support a flagging economy by cutting taxes and increasing spending. 
 In practice, however, almost the entire burden of fighting what has become a global slowdown is being borne by U.S. monetary policy. And you have to wonder whether the Federal Reserve, acting on its own, can really do the job. 
 Why does the Fed stand alone? Start with Europe. In terms of sheer purchasing power, Europe is America's equal; now that most European countries have adopted a common currency, managed by a single central bank, you might expect Europe and the United States to be twin pillars of global economic stability.
But the institutions of Europe's Economic and Monetary Union were designed to fight the last war -- they constitute a Maginot Line protecting the Continent from inflation, but make it almost impossible to respond to economic threats that come from a different direction. In particular, the charter of the European Central Bank requires it to defend price stability -- full stop, end of sentence. And bank officials have disavowed any responsibility for growth and employment.
What about fiscal policy? European countries don't have much room for maneuver, given large public debts and the looming burdens of an aging population. And whatever room for maneuver they might have had was taken away by Europe's Economic Stability and Growth Pact, which prevents even temporary deficit spending. Hesitant suggestions by some finance ministers that these rules be relaxed have been harshly criticized by the central bankers; so European fiscal action to fight a slump is pretty much out of the question. 
Then there's Japan. After years of immense spending on public works, Japan has a debt of 130 percent of G.D.P. -- and it, too, has an aging population. So it can do no more by way of fiscal policy; in fact, retrenchment is the order of the day. 
At the same time, conventional monetary policy has reached its limit in Japan, since short-term interest rates are already zero. The Bank of Japan could do more, if it was willing to adopt unconventional measures, like targeting a positive rate of inflation -- a course of action supported by some of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's advisers. But Japan's central bank has refused to make any significant moves in that direction. And Mr. Koizumi's own finance minister has denounced calls for radical monetary policy, warning of runaway inflation even as his country slips into a deflationary spiral. 
And then there's us. What are we doing to fight the slowdown?
America does, of course, have its tax cut. But the peculiar "back-loaded" timing of that cut makes it a very poor recession-fighting measure. The rebate checks are not much more than pocket change -- $40 billion, or 0.4 percent of G.D.P. The big tax cuts, which will eventually rise to almost 2 percent of G.D.P., won't come until the middle of the decade. And the decision to lock in trillions of dollars in future tax cuts actually depresses the economy now, since those future cuts do little to encourage current consumer spending but do raise long-term interest rates.
Can we pump up the economy with additional tax cuts or temporary public spending? Not safely; those huge future tax cuts have created a grim long-term financial outlook, and any further tax cuts would make the outlook even grimmer. Of course, the administration might do the responsible thing, making room for additional tax cuts now by canceling some of those big tax cuts scheduled for 2004 and later. And pigs might fly. 
It's a dismal picture: a combination of intellectual confusion, narrow-minded officials and sheer fiscal folly has removed most of the tools that the world's major economies might be able to use to help us get through these troubled times. The only institution that isn't paralyzed is the Fed, which keeps on cutting rates, hoping that it will finally accomplish something. Or to change metaphors a bit, the whole burden of avoiding a global recession now rests on Alan Greenspan's shoulders.
Presumably Atlas won't shrug. But what if the task is beyond his powers?

HEADLINE: Army to Move Some Weapons Out of Europe 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 

 BODY:
In the latest sign that the military is shifting its focus toward Asia, the Army said today that it planned to move combat weapons currently stored in Europe to the island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean.
 The move would involve arsenals in Germany and Italy that store weapons for wartime use. Military officials said there were no current plans to transfer any of the Army's 65,000 soldiers stationed in Europe, though the idea had been discussed at the Pentagon. 
 But just moving weapons and equipment out of Europe, where the American military has been a major presence for decades, is likely to raise concerns among the European allies that the United States' commitment to their region is waning. 
"It's a signal once again that we're going to shift our available resources around to fit the strategy as it evolves," Thomas White, the secretary of the Army, told reporters today at a breakfast meeting. 
Since taking office, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld has made clear he considers the Pacific to have rapidly growing military significance for several reasons: the rising power of China; the economic importance of South Korea, Japan, Hong Kong and Singapore; the instability of Indonesia; and the development of long-range ballistic missiles in North Korea.
His views have fueled unease among the NATO allies and rumors in the Pentagon of imminent cuts in American military forces in Europe. More than once, Mr. Rumsfeld has had to assure the allies that NATO remained vital to American interests. 
But Mr. Rumsfeld has also pressed the chiefs and secretaries of the armed services to begin studying ways to position themselves better for possible conflict in Asia. 
The Army's decision to move so-called pre-positioned weapons from Europe to Diego Garcia is clearly one of the results. Officials said they could not immediately provide details on the amount and type of weapons being moved. The Navy stations cargo ships for transporting troops and equipment on the island, a British dependency that is 1,000 miles southwest of India, about equidistant from Indonesia and the Arabian peninsula.
"There is going to be a heightened awareness or concern about the Pacific region," Mr. White said. "I think we in the Army will have to look at that very closely, look at stationing around the Pacific rim and look to see if there are opportunities to posture ourselves better to respond to contingencies and future operational requirements in the region."
Mr. White acknowledged that there might be diplomatic fallout with Europe if the United States began reducing its military commitment on the continent. 
"We will have to very deliberately engage NATO and our alliance partners in the Pacific and consult with them as the changes are made," he said. "Certainly there are strong strategic implications both on the political and military side that have to be dealt with as we change the posture, if that's what the secretary of defense and the president decide to do."
But Mr. White also said he would prefer not to remove any American soldiers from Europe, largely because they are well positioned for moving in and out of peacekeeping missions in the Balkans. 
He also argued that even if large numbers of American troops were no longer needed to maintain stability in Europe, those European bases were ideally located for dispatching troops to hot spots elsewhere in the world.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Russians Deem Arrest Insult to Their Industry

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 30 

 BODY:
The arrest and arraignment of a Russian programmer in the United States have provoked outrage in this country's computer programming industry.
 Programmers from St. Petersburg to Novosibirsk are talking about the charges brought against Dmitri Sklyarov, a 26-year-old programmer from Moscow, who was arrested in Las Vegas on July 16, after he spoke at a computer hackers' convention about his program that lets readers disable encryption software for electronic books. Mr. Sklyarov's employer, ElcomSoft, based here, also faces charges. 
 In Moscow today, the same day Mr. Sklyarov was arraigned in San Jose, Calif., a group of protesters tried to march in front of the United States Embassy, but were stopped by the police. 
"It's rubbish," said Gregory Nickonov, chief technical officer of Actis Systems, an e-business services concern that provides technical help to companies. People in information technology, he said, "have begun to think U.S. law is crazy," adding, "It's the same as buying a loaf of bread, and when you find the middle isn't baked, you come back to show the baker and get put in jail."
People here are angry mainly because they think that Mr. Sklyarov was singled out unjustly. And whatever the outcome of the case, they say, the arrest has hurt Russia's image, reinforcing stereotypes associated with this country's programmers.
"The image of Russian programmers now has a new negative," Natalya Kaspersky, head of Kaspersky Lab, Russia's leading antivirus software development company, said in an e-mail message. The company, she said, "puts enough energy into giving our partners an accurate picture of us as a stable and legitimate company," adding that "against the background of what has happened, that's harder to do."
Even before the Sklyarov case, Russia was battling an image as a center of software pirating. With the collapse of the Soviet Union and the sharp drop in wages that followed, Russia was plunged into economic free fall, and pirating flourished. Today, street-side shops are packed with a wide array of pirated software. 
"Cracking and getting around things is a huge industry here -- for 10 or 15 bucks you can get anything that's out there," a Western manager of an American software company said.
ElcomSoft is one of the few Russian companies that creates commercial software products for sale outside the country. Begun in 1990, ElcomSoft began by writing software on order for companies like Hyundai and Visa International. By 1996, its founders -- two brothers, Aleksandr and Vladimir Katalov -- steered the business away from fulfilling orders for big corporations and began their own work. Now, they sell products like software that bypasses lost passwords. "We decided it's better to try to create our own programs -- that's more interesting, more alive," Aleksandr Katalov said by phone from California, where he is involved in the Sklyarov case.
The company employs about 20 programmers, who work from home in various Russian cities.
Although programmers in general here seem to be upset over the Sklyarov case, there are dissenting voices. 
Anton Nosik, president of Rambler Internet Holding, which owns the Web portal www.rambler.ru, said ElcomSoft, though not Mr. Sklyarov specifically, should be held responsible for the decryption software. The product appears to have been aimed at the counterfeiters' market, Mr. Nosik said, adding: "If you produce cracks, you should face the responsibility. It's a tool enticing someone to produce a counterfeit. This doesn't look like a libertarian move to me; it looks like commercial blackmail."
